ALBANY, June 23 Commuting time between New York City and the suburbs would be reduced and railroad beds made safer and less bumpy with part of an allocation of $250-million in rail-improvement-bond money that was approved today by both houses of the Legislature.
Parents, pupils, teachers and staff members protesting scheduled cuts in the education budget staged classroom boycotts yesterday in demonstrations at four elementary schools on the upper West Side.

HOUGHTON, Mich., June 23 (AP) The oldest norrow-gauge railroad engine in the Upper Peninsula leaves tonight for Allaire, N.J., where it will enter steam service with the Pine Creek Railroad. The engine is being put back into service after a 30-year retirement.
Even the presence of Carlton Fisk behind the plate for the first time since last June 28 was of little help to Jim Burton, a rookie left-hander, last night at Fenway Park in Boston.

TAMPA, Fla., June 23 Representative L.A. Befalis, Republican of Florida, testified today at the trial of former Senator Edward J. Gurney and three co-defendants that he had never received secret campaign funds from Mr. Gurney or his aides.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 23 (AP) A Dutch Army bomb-disposal squad blew up a suspected bomb found on the steps of the United States Embassy today. An embassy spokesman later announced that the device, which was blown up with a small charge, was a fake.
One hundred minority workers seeking construction jobs staged a protest yesterday morning across from a City College site at which there were violent confrontations last month.

WASHINGTON, June 23 An emerging major issue in Federal tax policy, namely, whether new tax incentives ought to be provided to encourage business investment in productive equipment, was squarely joined today as the House Ways and Means Committee opened hearings on tax reform.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The United States and the Soviet Union have reached virtual agreement on the draft of an accord to outlaw techniques for changing the weather for military purposes, American officials said today.

NEW DELHI, June 23 Amid scenes of chaos in India's Supreme Court building, lawyers for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi fervently appealed to the court today to let her remain in office during the coming weeks while it reviews her conviction for electoral corruption.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan refused today to delay the implementation of a court-ordered busing plan designed to improve racial balance in Boston public schools.
TRENTON, June 23 (AP) In an unusually exhaustive opinion, the New eJrsey Supreme Court today significantly broadened and codified the rights of inmates who face prison disciplinary charges.

MEDINAH, Ill., June 23 The ancient game of golf is a maddening and almost mystical form of torture that tries men's souls, as your next-door neighbor can tell you, and it tried the souls of 150 of the world's best golfers here for most of the last week.
CAIRO, June 23 A new process of negotiation through diplomatic channels got under way today as the United States conveyed to Egypt the latest Israeli views on a disengagement in Sinai.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today that Mayor Joseph Alioto should get a new trial in his $12.5-million libel suit against the publishers of Look magazine.
The State Charter Revision Commission's proposals for decentralized city government were criticized in Queens yesterday in the fourth of five "grass roots" public hearings.

In June, 1971, Schenley Industries was merged into Glen Alden, the company that was to become the Rapid American Corporation, and minority shareholders of Schenley have been trying to get a better price for their shares ever since.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The Federal Energy Administration decided today to conduct what a spokesman termed "a sweeping, in-house investigation" of charges that political pressures were exerted to obtain Federal licenses in an oil deal involving Edward M. Carey, brother of Governor Carey of New York.
The latest Oriental self-defense craze sweeping the country is called Bing Pu, after its philosopher-founder, an ancient Mongolian monastery abbot who was worred about crime in the yurts.

Per Wahloo, who achieved worldwide recognition for the detective novels that he and his wife, Maj Sjowall, created while their children slept, has died. His death, at the age of 48, was announced yesterday in Malmo, Sweden, where he lived.

By what weird process have skeptical Americans, who once thought Mr. Dooley and Will Rogers had the last word on politics, come to regard "Government information," particularly when it is "classified Government information," as sacred?
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) President Ford announced today 13 winners of the 1974 National Medal of Science, the nation's highest award for achievements in science, mathematics and engineering.
John F. Harding, former executive vice president and general counsel of Cowles Communications, Inc., died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in New Fairfield, Conn. He was 67 years old.

Frank Agolia, a deputy picture editor of Sports Illustrated magazine, died yesterday in Chicago of an apparent heart attack suffered while covering the United States Open golf tournament. He was 46 years old and lived at 40 East Grant Avenue, Colonia, N.J.
Florence Weinberg, an artist known for her oil paintings of groups of people, died Sunday at her home, 244 East 68th Street. She was 81 years old.
The John F. Kennedy Library Corporation narrowed its selection yesterday to two proposals for building the controversial multimillion-dollar complex, United Press International reported.
ATLANTA, June 23 Secretary of State Kissinger tonight warned Turkey, as well as American allies in general, against thinking they are "doing us a favor by remaining in an alliance with us."
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The House today defeated a bill that opponents said would have been the first step toward credit allocation in the United States.

ROME, June 23 The United Nations World Food Council faces "an awesome responsibility" in the fight against world hunger, its executive director, John A. Hannah, said today at the opening session of the council here.

RALEIGH, N.C. Twentyseven-year-old Jesse Thurman Fowler is known on Central Prison's death row as a man of high good spirits, especially for the kind of place death row is. He has a quick, broad smile and seems almost jaunty, wearing a green fatigue cap with the bill turned up, a black nationalist flag drawn on it and the words "Death Before Dishonor" neatly lettered around it.
Eugene Collins Pulliam, publisher of newspapers in Arizona and Indiana and a voice of stanch Republican conservatism, died yesterday after collapsing at his Phoenix home. He was 86 years old.

A 43-year-old bank guard,' who had been disarmed by a holdup man and who had seen his gun used to kill an off-duty policeman during a robbery last January, was shot in the stomach and neck yesterday afternoon as he struggled to, keep his weapon from two armed holdup men attempting to rob the same Chase Manhattan branch near Gramercy Park.

A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl who had been missing since last Friday was found dead yesterday in a vacant building about half a mile from her home in the Cypress Hills section. Detectives said she had been strangled with the blueand-green scarf that was tied around her neck.

ALBANY, June 23 Commuting time between New York City and the suburbs would be reduced and railroad beds made safer and less bumpy with part of an allocation of $250-million in rail-improvement-bond money that was approved today by both houses of the Legislature.

BUENOS AIRES, June 23 The Argentine Government announced today that it and the First National City Bank have signed a letter of intent under which the United States bank would raise $250-million in credits for the financially ailing country. A final agreement could be reached in the next two months, according to informed sources.

What Wendy Gell calls her "wristies," or fantasy bracelets, are worn by such performers as Bette Midler, Paul McCartney, Roberta Flack and Lorna Luft, but their appeal combining as it does nostalgia with a sense of humor reaches beyond the show business world.

The American Electric Power Company, Inc., the nation's No. 1 private producer of electricity, disclosed here yesterday that it had been subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to produce company documents related to its "non-utility properties."

A long-smoldering feud between the strict-disciplinarian principal of a Queens high school and the more permissively inclined administration of the city school system broke into open warfare yesterday over the issue of freedom of the student press.

EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., June 23 At least 44 Vietnamese who came here in the evacuation of their country in April have decided that they want to go back, and State Department officials have arranged for the first steps of their journey home.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Economics has said there is "no support" for allegations by the agency's antitrust lawyers that major oil companies have understated natural gas reserves in a manner "tantamount to collusive price rigging."
LONDON, June 23 (Reuters) The Soviet Union announced today that it would phase out one of its three Antarctic whaling fleets as a gesture to growing conservationist pressure.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Supreme Court postponed today any re-examination of its 1972 ruling that capital punishment is unconstitutional. A ruling now is unlikely before early 1976.

And now we have the moonshine gap. With no Central Intelligence Agency money and no electronic devices or spy satellites, Prof. Vladimir G. Treml, an economist at Duke University, has discovered that the Soviet Union has outstripped the clandestine efforts of American moonshiners.

LONDON, June 23 Foreign Minister James Callaghan said tonight that he would not fly to Uganda despite President Idi Amin's assertion that such a trip would be necessary to save the life of a British subject.

ELIZABETH June 23 "I really don't know what happened last Tuesday," said Henry Garcia, a 19-year-old Cuban-born sophomore at Kean College in Newark. "But that really doesn't matter. There have been a lot of small things happening, especially at this corner."

Government security prices recovered enough yesterday to wipe out sharp morning losses, thanks to the growing view in Wall Street that the latest credit-tightening move by the Fed eral Reserve is temporary.

The city shipped 200 nursing home patients to new private facilities during the Christmas holiday of 1973 without asking them whether they wanted to move or giving them medical examinations, according to testimony at a state hearing yesterday.
Foolish Pleasure and Ruffian will be on the track today at Belmont Park, where their $350,000 match race will take place on July 6.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Mayor Beame told a Congressional inquiry on the fiscal plight of the cities, at a hearing convened today at his behest, that the financial community was setting social and political policy for New York City.
BRUSSELS, June 23 (UPI) The dollar began the week on the upswing, rising in value today on all European money markets.
The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, Milwaukee, disclosed yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the company's marketing practices.
WASHINGTON, June 22 On election night, 1972, Sargent Shriver's friends serenaded the defeated Vice-Presidential candidate with a parody of "I Can't Get Started."
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Supreme Court postponed today any re-examination of its 1972 ruling that capital punishment is unconstitutional. A ruling now is unlikely before early 1976.
ALBANY, June 24 Governor Carey asked the Justice Department today to investigate allegations that he had used his influence as a Congressman to help his brother's company benefit from a big oil deal.
Will Graham, founder of the Will Graham Company, an advertising agency at 405 Lexington Avenue, died yesterday at his home in Essex, Conn. He was 51 years old.

What can you do with a shrew? You can tame her, and Shakespeare did. You can blame her, and who hasn't? But it seems that you can even defame her.
WHITE PLAINS Westchester County will receive nearly $100,000 in Federal funds this Friday to support the introduction of a pretrial release program for prisoners.

LUXEMBOURG, June 24 The foreign ministers of the nine European Common Market countries agreed in principle at a meeting here today to give a large-scale emergency loan to Portugal to help create jobs.

MEXICO CITY, June 24 One of the basic themes sounded at the International Women's Year world conference here this week has been that of the goals of the poor countries vs. those of the rich. The United States is certainly among the rich, but now it is beginning to sound a little like a poor country.

A bitter budget dispute between the city and leaders of the three major religious philanthropic federations broke into the open yesterday, with the agencies charging that proposed new city contracts could force drastic reductions or even closings in mental health programs that serve 350,000 people.

BALTIMORE, June 24 Tempers boiled over tonight as the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles threw fists and baseballs in humid 90-degree weather. Keeping his cool, however, was Catfish Hunter, who hurled a four-hitter that led the steaming Yankees to a 3-1 victory and into first place in American League East.

JERUSALEM, June 24 Israel proposed a new disengagement agreement with Egypt that would last three to four years and would include a land corridor to an oilfield at Abu Rudeis in what is now occupied Sinai.

The Pittston Company, one of the nation's largest coal producers, announced yesterday that it would spend $350-million over the next five years in a nine-mine expansion program aimed at increasing annual production by 1.5 million tons of coal suitable for use in the production of steel.

BUDAPEST, June 24 (Reuters) Leaders of nine Communist countries, including the Soviet Union, began talks here today on economic coordination for the next five years, with problems of energy and raw materials high on the agenda.

Turning down a plea by Dr. Max Jacobson, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Albany has ruled that his revoked medical license will remain revoked until the court hears his appeal and makes a final decision. The 75-year-old East Side physician had requested a stay of the revocation, which was voted by the State Board of Regents in April.

ALBANY, June 24 The controversial proposal that would have permitted savings banks to offer checking account, in return for financing a mortgage pool for allegedly "red-lined" areas was killed today in the Senate after the state's commercial banks lobbied heavily against the measure.
LAKEWOOD, June 24 (UPI) The Lakewood Board of Education has rescinded its support of a controversial plan to bus 124 students to achieve racial balance at two elementary schools.
WHITE PLAINS, June 24 The Amateur Athletic Union's national junior women's track and field championships opened at Loucks Memorial Field today.

Another lunch cart has been added to the city's sidewalk vender scene and, although its offering of low-calorie meals sets it off from others, its firstday run-in with a police officer was probably typical.

DEMAREST, N.J. The service station operator, last fortress of rugged individualism, may well be on the road to extinction. Many consumers who have suffered crude and sometimes insolent injustices at the hands of these men may welcome their demise.

Dr. Estelle Young, a resident dermatologist at the New York University Medical center, was married last evening to Dr. Bruce H. Littman, a research and clinical fellow at the Harvard University Medical School. The ceremony was performed in Temple B'nai Sholom in Rockville Centre, L.I., by Rabbi Dov Schwartz.

The Budget Bureau, asserting that 70 per cent of city agencies are now generating surplus funds by curtailing expenditures, said yesterday that the city might well end its fiscal year next Monday with a "balanced budget."

The Cleveland Indians rallied with four runs in the ninth inning and knocked the Red Sox out of first place in the American League East last night, beating Boston for the second successive evening in Fenway Park, this time by 8-6.

WASHINGTON, June 24-George Meany, the top spokesman for organized labor warned today that the continuing high unemployment deemed acceptable by the Ford Administration "can tear this country apart" and called for a crash program to create jobs.

The entire book-publishing industry which, if a company in its own right, would rank 43d in a list of the 500 largest industrial corporations registered $3.5-billion in sales last year. And although business is good, profits are "generally flat," according to the Association of American Publishers.
New Census Bureau estimates show that 11,000 more people moved out of Connecticut than entered it from April 1, 1970, when the decennial census was taken, to last July 1.
Yesterday's Eastern Airlines crash reinforced a fact of airline life that has been pointed up in repeated accident surveys. The most dangerous part of a flight is the final approach and landing.

WASHINGTON, June 24 A top State Department official expressed unhappiness today with the deprivation of human rights in South Korea and the Philippines, but he said that for security reasons the United States would continue its support of both allies.
For thousands going nightly this week to fill Madison Square Garden, along with the streets outside, the lure is the hot, raunchy rock 'n' roll of Mick Jagger and the Rolling Stones.

Elana Katz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Katz of Peoria, Ill., was married last evening to David Mandelbaum, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Bernard Mandelbaum of New York. Rabbi Steven Riskin and Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I.
William Hansen, a stage and screen actor, died Monday at the Motion Picture Television Country Home and Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 64 years old and lived in Los Angeles.
Record profits for the fiscal quarter ended June 30 were forecast yesterday for Paine Webber, Inc., holding company for the brokerage house of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The former top officials of the two Federal agencies that approved licenses in an oil deal involving Edward M. Carey, brother of Govenor Carey of New York, said today that they had no knowledge of any political pressures that were brought to bear to obtain those licenses.

MINNEAPOLIS For six years, the Reserve Mining Company has been embroiled in one of the nation's most protracted environmental controversies a case that has caused a cancer scare, produced mountains of expert testimony, resulted in dozens of fruitless hearings and meetings and bounced from one Federal courtroom to another.
OSCEOLA, N.Y. Henry Krasniewski stood by a mountain of gigantic white ash logs at the sawmill that he and his brother operate and pointed to a lodging trail leading into the wilderness to the north.

Silver futures jumped 10 cents an ounce in terms of the July contract on the Commodity Exchange here to close at $4.56 8/10 an ounce, amid reports of heavy buying of silver futures by British financial institutions.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y. The Village Board of Trustees here has scheduled an unusual summer session on July 14 to decide the future of the wooded, hilly five-acre site containing the rubble of the once-fashionable Gramatan Hotel.

The performance of the House Democrats in scuttling their own efforts at a coherent and equitable energy policy, including the key gasoline tax and rebate plan, reflects an extraordinary paradox. Few Congressmen have shown the political courage to impose a gas tax or other necessary belt-tightening on their constituents yet, instead of staying away from the issue, most have insisted on a piece of the action.

LISBON The United States Government is playing a very quiet and cautious role here in the Portuguese crisis. Its stake in the future of Portugal, whose bases influence the military strategy of the Atlantic and the Western gateway to the Mediterranean, is very large, but Washington is staying out of the internal struggles for the present.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, Wednesday, June 25- After 470 years of colonial rule, the Portuguese flag was lowered at midnight in this East African territory as the most militant and Marxist black government in Africa took control of Mozambique's nine million people.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 24 There are so many "hot" racing boats here at Block Island Race Week that one is afraid to get too close because of the heat.

A recent report raising doubts about the effectiveness of busing for integration was attacked on grounds of method and motivation yesterday by a panel of seven liberal sociologists and psychologists led by Kenneth B. Clark, the State Regent and black psychologist.

WASHINGTON The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is a cartel that sets the price of oil produced in the Arab states. It should not, however, set the price of oil produced and consumed in America.

ALPENA, Mich. (AP) June 24 Mrs. Vincent Madison, the widow of a Detroit Edison executive, died here on Sunday. She was 62 years old.

NICOSIA, Cyprus Some people have been made to believe that "the clock" can be turned back in Cyprus once the Turkish forces withdraw from the island. These are the people who think that the Cyprus problem arose as a result of the Turkish intervention of July 20, 1974.

NYACK, N.Y., June 24 Edward T. Lovatt, former president and chairman of the Marine Midland Trust Company of Rockland County died last night at Nyack Hospital after a heart attack. He was 77 years old and lived at 23 Tellman Avenue.
The International Business Machines Corporation raised its quarterly dividend payment yesterday to $1.75 a share from $1.50 a share in previous quarters.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 24 Self-reliance and nationalism are the keynotes of the official doctrine being preached by the Communist-led Pathet Lao now that its long struggle for control has been won.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 24 Mrs. Louis Cubelli of the Newtown Country Club, tournament medalist, and Mrs. Lincoln Kinnicutt of the Hartford Golf Club, defending champion, won first-round matches handily today as all favorites advanced in the Connecticut Women's Golf Association championship at the Brooklawn C.C.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that the Justice Department authorized warrantless national security wiretaps on 148 persons last year, a significant increase over the average during the five previous years.

LUANDA, Angola, June 24 A Portuguese army truck, stacked high with mattresses, chairs, pots and pans and bundles of clothes, moved slowly this morning behind another truck filled with people along the fashionable Avenue Luis de Camoes to an unfinished luxury apartment house.

Among the survivors of yesterday's Eastern Airlines crash at Kennedy International Airport was a Norwegian tourist, Egon Luftaas, who said he was traveling with a group of 14 Norwegians. Mr. Luftaas was taken to Jamaica Hospital in serious condition with burns over most of his body.

ALBANY, June 24 The commission that will put a proposed charter change on the New York City ballot this November is not barred by the State Constitution from using government money to publicize its plans, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled today.

Having previously published Max, a national youthoriented newspaper, and The New York American, both now defunct, Allan Morrell is getting back into the newspaper business after a hiatus of four years.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, June 25 At dawn on a Sunday morning 25 years ago today, South Korean and America soldiers began fighting in defense of this nation as the North Korean communists struck across the 38th Parallel.

A highly satisfying program of German lieder was very well sung by Myrna Bismarck Becker, a New York-born soprano who made her local debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) President Ford will hold a television-radio news conference at 5 P.M. tomorrow.
PARIS, June 24 Louis Gabriel-Robinet, for 25 years managing editor of the conservative Paris morning newspaper Le Figaro, died at his home here yesterday. He was 65 years old.
A man who said he always wanted to own a firehouse got one yesterday at a cost of $15,000, during a two-day auction of surplus municipal property that brought the city approximately $1.7-million.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the Labor Department have negotiated a proposed agreement that would allow 13 colleges and universities with unapproved affirmative-action hiring plans to receive more than $20-million in Federal contracts despite a rule requiring that such plans be approved before the contracts are awarded.

LONDON, June 24 The diplomatic stalemate between Britain and Uganda over the fate of Denis Cecil Hills continued today despite discussion here over diplomatic tactics and two messages from Uganda's President Idi Amin.

George W. Gale, founder and president of the Gale Engineering Company of New York City, died yesterday in Cape Cod. Mr. Gale, who lived in Chatham, Mass., and formerly in Short Hills, N.J., was 68 years old.
Louis Gottschalk, historian and an authority on the French Revolution, died Monday at the Billings Hospital of the University of Chicago. He was 76 years old and lived in Chicago.

MOSCOW, June 24 The Soviet Union plans to mark the 25th anniversary of the beginning of the Korean war tomorrow by opening a one-month campaign against the continued presence of American troops in South Korea and in favor of "peaceful, democratic" reunification of the country.

After breaking out of 12 years of golfing obscurity to win the United States Open, Lou Graham became so popular yesterday that it was difficult to get a phone call through to his home. A crowd of about 100 had waited at Metro Nashville Airport late Monday night to welcome Graham home.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) The House, after less than a half hour of debate, passed today a $46-billion increase in the national debt ceiling. The vote was 223 to 196.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, June 25 (Reuters) President Park Chung Hee marked the 25th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean war today with a warning that North Korea was planning to start another war but that it would only bring about its own destruction.

ALBANY, June 24-The controversial proposal that would have permitted savings banks to offer checking accounts in return for financing a mortgage pool for allegedly "red-lined" areas was killed today in the Senate after the state's commercial banks lobbied heavily against the measure.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market rose yesterday in stepped-up trading.

WASHINGTON, June 25 The new United States Ambassador to Israel, Malcolm Toon, said today that an over-all Middle East settlement should include "some rectifications" in the Arab-Israeli borders that existed before the war of June, 1967. Sales volume in the nation's chain stores rebounded from no gain in April to an increase of 8.4 per cent in May, in comparison with the same months last year, according to a compilation of sales prepared by Chain Store Age Magazine. The gain in May was the best achieved so far this year and was higher than for any month since October, 1974 when an increase of 12.6 per cent was recorded.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 (AP) Billy Martin, who won the National Collegiate singles title as a freshman at University of California, Los Angeles, last Saturday, is giving up his amateur status to play professional tennis, the 18-year-old told The Associated Press today.

DUBLIN, June 26 In an antiinflation budget presented today, the Irish Government subsidized food, increased taxes and doubled its estimated deficit for the current year. However, Finance Minister Richard Ryan, who devised the emergency budget, rejected calls for the separation of the Irish pound from the British pound.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The United States has received Egypt's initial response to the latest Israeli ideas for a new interim agreement in Sinai and will probably pass it on to Israel tomorrow.

Good demand for soybean oil by users led to a rise in the July future contract on the Chicago Bcard of Trade. Soybean oil for July delivery closed at 23.65 cents a pound, after being up the 1-cent-apound limit at 23.95 for a while. The strength in oil spilled over into soybean futures, which jumped 4 cents a bushel to close at $5.22 .
OGLALA, S.D., June 26 (UPI) All roads leading to the reservation at Pine Ridge have been blocked and a communications blackout has been imposed on Pine Ridge.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that he was "leaning moderately" toward a Federal-state inspection plan to tighten up a system that has led to allegations of corruption in the handling, grading and weighing of grain in New Orleans and other export ports.

Tomorrow will be a turning point in New Jersey. The vote in the Senate on the income tax should be a milestone on the road to tax reform, better schools and responsible government. But if the Senate says no again, our state will be plunged into fiscal chaos.

The many short stories that have been written on a bridge theme fall into two categories. Some are by famous writers who know something about bridge: Somerset Maugham, Ian Fleming, Ring Lardner, George Kaufman and Roald Dahl. Others are by leading bridge personalities, such as Alphonse Moyse Jr., R.F. Foster, Don Von Elsner, Ron Klinger and Frank Thomas, who are also skillful writers.
WASHINGTON, June 26 Norman M. Klein, architect who was a pioneer of community involvement in highway and mass transit city planning, died today of leukemia at his home here. He was 53 years old.

The audience is different, some of the sounds are strange, and many of the names are new, but jazz buffs coming to town for the Newport Jazz Festival, opening its 22d season and its fourth year in New York today, will find that their kind of music is alive and making a strong comeback in Greenwich Village.

She is attractively feminine, in the obsolete sense of that battered word, and a regular fellow at the same time.
After losing four straight games in Philadelphia, the Pittsburgh Pirates returned to the friendly confines of Three Rivers Stadium last night and ended their skid by beating the Chicago Cubs, 5-2.
The board of the Metropolitan Opera confirmed yesterday the dismissal of Schuyler G. Chapin as general manager and abolished the title.

Three years after a spirit of detente was invoked to begin expanding American-Soviet trade, the amount of advanced technology exchanged between the two superpowers is far less than many had hoped, or feared.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) President Ford plans to go to Ohio next Thursday for two appearances in Cincinnati and for an address at a Republican fund-raising dinner in Cleveland, the White House announced today. The Presidential press secretary, Ron Nessen, said that Mr. Ford would travel to Baltimore on the Fourth of July to participate in holiday ceremonies at Fort McHenry, where Francis Scott Key was inspired to write the national anthem.
NEW DELHI, Friday, June 27 All India was listening with special care today to what an Indian writer here called "the voice of Indira."

A Democratic district leader, who said she had seen the police slaying of a man on a Har lem streetcorner on Wednesday, gave an account to detectives yesterday that differed from the one supplied by the two officers who fired the fatal shots.
Prices sustained fairly sharp breaks in the capital markets yesterday as the Federal Reserve appeared to tighten somewhat its current clamp on short-term money rates.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) A drop of nearly 21 per cent in the volume of imported oil helped the nation's foreign trade account reach a near-re cord surplus in May, the Government reported today.

Weisl Jr., who had criticized the festival organizers for failing to clean up the Central Park site of the festival, which was held Sunday.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 26 Ted Hood, as eminent a racing yachtsman as there is in the United States, won a race today at Block Island Race week.

It then lost points with some of the reporting it chose to transmit.
The Sun Oil Company, the nation's seventh largest petroleum producer, announced a series of top-level management changes yesterday.

ELKINS PARK, Pa., June 27 (AP) Benny Bass, a former world featherweight and junior lightweight boxing champion, died yesterday at the age of 70. He retired from the ring in 1940 after winning most of his 400 fights, 59 by knockouts.

BRUSSELS, June 27 The managing director of the Belgian subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was convicted by a Brussels court today of having bribed a high official of the Belgian state telephone service to get favorable consideration on equipment contracts.

Smokey Robinson was the lead singer of the Miracles, one of the most popular of all soul groups, from 1958 through 1972. And his appearance Thursday night in Carnegie Hall his first here since he resumed his performing career as a solo artist earlier this year proved that he had lost none of his magic.
Prices rose yesterday on the American Stock Exchange for the eighth straight session as volume fell slightly. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-the-counter market.

Isabel Capps Rainey, who developed styli for modern longplaying records and phonograph pick-ups, died Wednesday at the Orleans (Mass.) Convalescent and Retirement Home. She was 75 years old and formerly lived in Westbury, L.I.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 27 (AP) John Rogers, Oklahoma's Secretary of State, who was to face a state Senate impeachment trial in 11 days, announced his resignation today.

"What we want to do is going to take a hundred years," said Alvin L. Schorr general director of the Community Service Society, the city' oldest private social agency. "We want to make New York City more humane."

WASHINGTON, June 27 Secretary of State Kissinger announced changes in the State Department today designed to centralize decision-making and personnel policies and reduce the authority of individual bureaus.

WNET/13 will televise a two-and-a-half hour live special tomorrow afternoon entitled "The Nation of Islam," which will be built around direct coverage of an address from Madison Square Garden by Wallace Muhammad, the new spiritual leader of the Black Muslims. It will be his first address here since he succeeded his father, the late Elijah Muhammad, as leader last February, giving the movement a more moderate tone.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 27 Block Island Race Week ended today with a race around the island in a light but decent easterly breeze for 214 yachts, several of which ran aground while others allegedly committed fouls that brought on 24 protests.

WASHINGTON, June 27 A Congressional committee has begun investigating political pressures that allegedly surrounded the issuance of Federal export licenses in an oil deal involving Governor Carey's brother, Edward M. Carey.

BUENOS AIRES, June 27 President Isabel Martinez de Peron faced her gravest crisis in office today, as economic problems mounted and open opposition was expressed by the labor movement, which has been the main pillar of her support.

Of all the figures who have contributed to the development of jazz in the United States (from Louis Armstrong to Charlie Parker), John Coltrane was, off the bandstand probably the least controversial.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (Reuters) The Commerce Department said today the National Cash Register Company and three other companies have all been fined $1,000 for failure to report that they were requested to participate in the Arab boycott of Israel.

Business credibility might improve if more executives were willing to admit even to themselves that the obligation to pay adequate attention to public needs has not yet become one of the requisites of sound management.
Without Webern's Five Movements for Strings (Op. 5) and Berio's "Circles" the Rug Concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night would have been a bleak affair.

Charging that trustees and the director of the Museum of the American Indian have sold and given away artifacts from the museum's collection of 4.5 million objects in a "surreptitious and wasteful" way, the state's Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, asked for their removal yesterday in State Supreme Court.

NEW DELHI, June 27 Citing danger to India's "security and stability" during the current political crisis, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government has imposed the toughest press censorship in the 28 years since independence. It exceeds the measure taken during the three wars India has fought in that time.

PINE RIDGE, S.D., June 27 More than 100 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents armed with automatic weapons and dressed in battle fatigues combed the prairies and hills of the Oglala Sioux reservation today in search of some 16. Indians they believed took part in the killing of two F.B.I. agents yesterday
A New York diamond cutter and a Maryland mathematician for defense research contractors were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy to commit espionage for the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) Public accountants may be required to disclose suspicious corporate payments to foreign officials, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ray Garrett Jr., said today.
Members of Opus Dei (the work of God) strive to practice Christian virtue in their daily lives as well as within their separate vocations or professions.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 In the easiest match he has had so far, Jimmy Connors routed Phil Dent of Australia, the man who was two points away from upsetting him a year ago, 6-1, 6-2, 6-2, today to lead Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., and Bjorn Borg of Sweden into the quarterfinals of the Wimbledon tennis championships.
A New York diamond cutter and a Maryland mathematician for defense research contractors were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiracy to commit espionage for the Soviet Union.

The wild abandon of the nineteen-sixties is over. It really is Proof is when Ed Austin and Huibert Zuur had their first formal fashion show, they made bras for the mannequins to wear under their seethrough blouses. Despite the fact that women never bared their chests under chiffon in public, designers kept anticipating they would and avoided underpinning as if it were plague.

MOBILE, Ala., June 27 Bart B. Chamberlain Jr., a key figure in the oil deal that led to charges of political pressure involving Governor Carey and his brother, contends that the controversy is the result of an effort by an unnamed party in the oil industry to discredit Edward M. Carey, the chairman of New England Petroleum Company, who was the other principal in the deal.
The world's largest aluminum producer, the Aluminum Company of America, followed yesterday the lead of the Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation, in announcing price increases.
The Gudde Dancers, with works choreographed by Lynda Gudde, are presenting alternating programs at St. Clement's Church, 423 West 46th Street, every evening at 8 through Wednesday.

There were 93,200 fewer jobs in the city this May than there were in May of 1974, indicating that the six-year-old decline in employment here is continuing at an accelerating pace, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.

BONN, June 27 The West German Government, over American objections, today signed a multibillion-dollar nuclear technology agreement with Brazil, which pledged not to use the pact to build atomic bombs or explosive devices.

ALBANY, June 27 The Senate sent sergeants-at-arms out to round up a quorum "by physical force, if necessary," ordered the acting majority leader, William T. Conklin, a Brooklyn Republican-Conservative then wrangled at length today before passing a bill to let parents take their children out of sex education classes.

TRENTON, June 26 Immediately following Senate defeat of the income tax here today, Charles C. Carella, an aide to Governor Byrne, presented Senate president Frank J. Dodd with the Governor's line item vetoes of the state budget, totaling $384-million, effective midnight Monday.
The National Football League seams voted, 22-4, yesterday to impose a player limit of 43 for the 1975 season, in place of last year's 47-man rosters. Approval required at least 20 of the 26 votes.
PITTSBURGH, June 27 (AP) A strike by truck drivers halted delivery of The Pittsburgh Press today and threatened to leave the state's second largest city without a news paper tomorrow morning.
TEL AVIV, June 27 The Israeli Chief of Staff, Lieut Gen. Mordechai Gur, said today that hectic military preparation on the east bank of the Jordan River represented a "new Jordanian concept."
WHITE PLAINS, June 27 The United States and Soviet Union patched up contractual differences today and agreed to stage their track and field meet in Kiev on July 4 and 5.
TRENTON, June 27 The State Senate rejected a state income tax again today, creating a fiscal crisis in New Jersey and dealing a severe political defeat to Governer Byrne.

Tchaikovsky's bittersweet, incredibly lyric, infinitely touching "Eugene Onegin" was the third production of the Bolshoi Opera to be given at the Metropolitan Opera. It is not a work frequently encountered in New York, though the Metropolitan did have it in repertory for a few seasons. But last night's performance by the Bolshoi probably gave New Yorkers a new dimension to the score.

MANILA, June 27 President Ferdinand E. Marcos, having just established diplomatic relations with Peking, will make a state visit to Moscow "before the Russian winter," high Government sources said today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 27 (AP) Cobra, a 32-foot sloop-rigged catamaran owned by Don Karmin of Glen Head, L.I., was declared the winner today of the fifth biennial Newport-Bermuda multi-hull ocean race.
WASHINGTON, June 27 The Senate began its Fourth of July recess today after passing and sending to President Ford a compromise housing bill.

MOGADISHU, Somalia, June 27 (Reuters) A large group of Western, Arab and African reporters gathered here today, at the invitation of the Somali Government, for an inspection tour related to United States reports of a Soviet missile base at the port of Berbera.
Roderick W. Beaton, president of United Press International protested to Prime Minister Indira Gandhi yesterday against the censorship of news dispatches from India.

BRUSSELS, June 27 (UPI) The pound tumbled to another record depreciation level today in the wake of a fresh selling spree on foreign exchanges while the dollar sustained a week-long upward trend and brought its best rates in weeks throughout Europe.

The new joint underwriting association set up by state law to write malpractice insurance began accepting applications from doctors and hospitals yesterday, but refused to commit itself to the premium levels announced by the State Insurance Department this week.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 28 (Saturday) Drummed in by costumed Malayan warriors as natives held multi-colored imitation palms under blazing midmorning sun, Muhammad Ali and Joe Bugner walked through the weigh-in ceremony today for next week's world heavyweight championship fight. Ali weighed 225, Bugner 230.

Farmers were heavy sellers of corn and soybeans yesterday, probably because of recent low prices. Their action showed up in futures trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, where there was eager selling of the two commodities by operators of grain elevators, who sell futures as soon as they acquire commodities from farmers.

ROME, Saturday, June 28 (UPI) The World Food Council agreed early today on proposals for attacking hunger, deflecting an attempt by African and Latin-American nations to dismiss the council's secretariat and have the meeting postponed.
TOMS RIVER, June 27 (AP) Three former Atlantic City inspectors were fined and given suspended jail terms today for taking bribes from a resorthotel owner, Lee Cohn.

VILLAGE FEAST Starting tomorrow with Fritz Lang's "Destiny" and "Metropolis" and ending Sept. 20 with the Laurence Olivier "Richard III" and Shaw's "Pygmalion," the Bleecker Street Cinema (at LaGuardia Place) is presenting a revival program selected from the Janus Film Collection, one of the best existing libraries of international screen classics.

The arrival of summer hasn't discouraged the furriers who are showing their fall collections. Ben Thylan paraded yet another collection at the Plaza this week that made one yearn for a chilly November. The Thylan arrangement is a sort of miniconglomerate of 12 furriers and designers who sell their wares in the Thylan showrooms at 32 East 57th Street. The combination of talent makes for interesting variety.

LOS ANGELES, June 27 Los Angeles County District Attorney Joseph P. Busch Jr., who oversaw the largest district attorney's office in the country, died in his sleep last night at his West Covina home. He was 49 years old.

The Newport Jazz Festival got under way last night, and yesterday George Wein, its tensely ebullient, 49-year-old founder, producer and director, spent the day bustling about midtown Manhattan checking into the activities of his staff and taking care of promotional business.

"Good afternoon, Offtrack Betting," a cheerful female voice from upstate answered, proving that you don't have to live or work in Fun City to be a member of the New York Bets.
WHITE PLAINS, June 27 Robin Campbell contends that chewing gum "keeps me together." Her coach, Brooks Johnson, considers it a sticky subject.

In the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy, West, Point, N.Y., last evening Mary Allerton Cushman was married to Frederic Alan Escherich by the Rev. Robert McCormick.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 27 The United States aid program, for more than a decade the principal prop of the Laotian economy, wound up activities in Laos yesterday. All remaining supplies and property of the Agency for International Development were relinquished to Laotian control.

The United States Justice Department is investigating the sales and rentals of homes and apartments in the northern Bronx, including the Riverdale area, to determine if a pattern of discrimination exists against blacks and Puerto Ricans.

The Chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Eleanor Montgomery Moore, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Alanson Moore of New York, to Richard Justin Sterne, son of Mrs. Russell J. Sterne of Buffalo and the late Mr. Sterne.
There has been considerable grumbling in Wall Street since a plan to distribute one million shares of the Data General Corporation at 30 3/4 was unsuccessful.
ROCHESTER, June 27Pele displayed his soccer brilliance to 14,562 fans at Holleder Stadium tonight as he helped the New York Cosmos defeat the Rochester Lancers, 3-0.

The City Council, without debate, overwhelmingly approved an increase in the city's basic real-estate tax of 83.4 cents yesterday, raising it to $8.187 for each $100 of assessed valuation, the highest in the city's history.

SAN DIEGO, June 27 (AP) The F.B.I. and the San Diego police denied today having solicited two informants to kill an antiwar activist, Peter Bohmer, but conceded that they had used the men in question for undercover work.
Alone among American cities, New York revels in abuse. It has a positive liking for being told of its shortcomings, and even goes about boasting that it is far worse than outsiders suspect.

Many Indian residents of the United States have been stirred into debate and speculation over Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's means and motives in the current political crisis in India.
LONDON, June 27 Western European newspapers are virtually unanimous in condemning Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, accusing her of acting autocratically in arresting political opponents.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, June 27 (AP) The Honduran military Government has cracked down on a protest march by peasants demanding agrarian reform, and tension is reported spreading in the provinces.
When 470 years of Portuguese colonial rule ended in Mozambique this week, the curtain went up on a new country of nine million people and on a new era for southern Africa.

An armed robber fled with almost $900 from a West 42d Street clothing store last night, but he was apprehended minutes later after a chase through the crowded mezzanine of the nearby Eighth Avenue IND subway station, the police reported.

ALBANY, June 27 The political fight within the State Charter Revision Commission for New York City intensified today as a group of commission members began a court action to defend their plans for publicizing the charter proposals.

NEW ORLEANS, June 27 A Company involved in a Federal investigation of alleged corruption in the grain export trade here made payments to key campaign aides of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards between his election and his inauguration in 1972.

LONDON, June 27 For the first time in weeks, officials here are beginning to believe that the major segments of the British economy will be able to agree on stricter policies to control the country's crippling 25 per cent inflation rate, the worst in Europe.

YONKERS, June 27 Tarport Hap snoozed and Nero chumped his oats today, caring little that a union dispute at all 145 Offtrack Betting Corporation offices in New York City had prevented heavy advance wagering on the $200,000 Cane Pace.
The Supreme Court's decision Thursday concerning the rights of mental patients has left a number of fundamental questions unanswered in the minds of leading medical and legal officials.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 27 (UPI) South Africa, the world's largest gold producer, devalued the rand today by 4.76 per cent against the dollar, its biggest currency adjustment in four years.

A 22-year-old Brooklyn man, whom his neighbors first regarded as the hero of a fatal fire in the Bushwick section Thursday morning, has been arrested on suspicion that he set the blaze, which killed a 17month-old baby and critically injured the baby's parents, fire marshals reported yesterday.

BOSTON, June 27 Both leaders and rank-and-file members of the National Women's Political Caucus served notice today on aspirants for the 1976 Presidential nominations that their support would not easily be won.

HILO, Hawaii A Hawaiian company is growing a special variety of papaya here that flourishes in soil that looks like a gravel pile and that sprouts from seeds to mature trees in one year. It sounds easy. It isn't.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 27 Lawyers representing migrant farmworkers asked Judge Herbert Horn of State Superior Court here today to order New Jersey to resume inspections of farm labor camps.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia took a major step in shoring up the principle of constitutional government when it decided there were limits on Federal authority to install "national security" wiretaps.

Seatrain Lines, Inc., said yesterday that it had reached final agreement for a $40-million loan for its shipyards from the Chase Manhattan Bank. The loan is 90 per cent guaranteed by the Commerce Department, the company said.

ROME, Saturday, June 28 There have been doubts among the developing countries over the extent of the United States commitment to the proposed international fund for agricultural development. A working group is to meet next week to consider the organization of such a fund, to which Saudi Arabia, Iran and others have announced that they will make contributions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 27 The United States informed he Security Council today that it was ready to see the United Nations Command in South Korea terminated on Jan. 1, provided that China and North Korea agreed to alternative arrangements for maintaining the 1953 armistice.
TRENTON, June 27 The State Senate rejected a state income tax again today, creating a fiscal crisis in New Jersey and dealing a severe political defeat to Governer Byrne.

NEW DELHI, June 27 The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has described internal threats to explain its declaration of a state of emergency yesterday with such as "a deep and widespread conspiracy," "a threat to law and order" and "adopting Nazi methods."

LONDON, June 27 The finback whale, biggest of the whales still hunted legally, was given almost total protection by the International Whaling Commission today. Catch quotas on other species of whales were also drastically reduced.

MEXICO CITY, June 27 Women, who make up more than one-third of the world's labor force, work harder and longer than men, receive less pay perform the most monotonous tasks and have the least chance for advancement, in rich and poor countries alike, according to studies presented at a United Nations World Conference on Women here.

Warning that the city would be "less safe" starting on Mon-' day Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said that 5,034 police officers would be laid off next week because of legislative inaction in the city's fiscal crisis.

ROME, June 27 A report from New York that Guido Carli, Governor of the Bank of Italy, and three executives of the Bank of Rome had been indicted in connection with actions involving the financier Michele Sindona was denied today by sources at the bank.
WASHINGTON, June 27 President Ford asked Congress today to amend the Clean Air Act of 1970 to give the automobile industry the five-year freeze on auto emission controls that it has requested.

Dave Kingman played left field for the Mets last night, his third starting assignment in a row. He hit a two-run homer in a four-run first inning, made the catch of the game in the third and saved the game in the eighth when he backed to the wall and hauled down a deep drive.

Detectives questioned a number of suspects yesterday in their search for the man who beat 18-year-Old Michele Godbout on the head with a golf club Monday afternoon as she was riding her bicycle in Central Park. Miss Godbout died Thursday morning in St. Luke's Hospital.
Kaufman and Broad, Inc., one of the largest builders of housing, continued to operate in the red in the quarter and six months ended May 31, reflecting the curtailed demand for housing.

TAMPA, Fla., June 27 Three Senators testified as character witnesses today in behalf of former Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, at the trial of Mr. Gurney and three co-defendants in United States District Court.

ALBANY, June 27 The Democratic-controlled Assembly, as part of a last-ditch strategy to force the hand of the Republican Senate, tonight voted to authorize New York City to raise $388-milion in new taxes on banks, corporations, and the sale of stocks and bonds.

The pilot of the last airliner to land at Kennedy International Airport before Tuesday's crash was quoted yesterday as saying that he had made his approach at higher than normal speeds to cope with violent shifts in air currents reported in the area.

KEYSTONE, S.D. (AP) The bomb that exploded at the visitors center of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial early today resulted in some damage but no injuries, Harvey Wickware, Rushmore superintendent, said.

The State Board of Regents has granted a charter to a consortium of cultural and higher learning institutions that are combining their facilities to widen educational opportunities and spur the development of downtown Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 27 Former President Richard M. Nixon gave about 11 hours of grand jury testimony on a range of subjects under questioning by lawyers from the special Watergate prosecution force in an unusual proceeding last Monday and Tuesday in California.
Malcolm R. Lovell, a former chief of mission to Britain for CARE, died yesterday of a heart attack in Columbia, S.C. He was 84 years old.

Dr. Elizabeth L. Hazen, who in the mid-nineteen-fifties was a co-inventor of Nystatin, the first antibiotic successful in combating human fungal diseases, died Tuesday in Seattle. She was 89 years old.
PARIS, June 27 (AP) Four young men posing as flower deliverers robbed two American women today of jewels and cash with an estimated value of up to $4.5-million, according to police sources.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 27--Russell J. Little and Joseph M. Remiro, two members of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army, were sentenced to life imprisonment today for the murder of Dr. Marcus Foster, Oakland school superintendent, on Nov. 6, 1973.

When Early Bird, the first commercial communications satellite, was launched 10 years ago on this date, the expectations were that the United States as an affluent nation with one of the most advanced television systems in the world would be the primary user of the new form of transoceanic transmission.

The Beame administration has been told it may if it wants dismiss as many as 1,700 workers already hired under the Federal public-service job program and replace them with civil servants laid off in the budget crisis.

The city was temporarily barred in State Supreme Court yesterday from dismissing 2,934 sanitationmen hours after some trash collectors staged a work slowdown and 140 men who refused orders to go to work were suspended.
The head of a coordinating body of Jewish community relations agencies yesterday rejected fears that the American Jewish community was struggling to achieve its goals "in a sea of hostility."

Dr. Mabel Gutman Silverberg, a dermatologist here for almost a half-century died Thursday in Presbyterian Hospital of a, heart attack, Dr. Silverberg, who lived at 39 Claremont Avenue, was 76 years old.

PARIS, Saturday, June 28 (AP) Two French counterespionage agents and a suspected terrorist were killed and another agent was wounded in a gun battle in a central Paris apartment last night, the In erior Ministry said today.

LONDON Marks Spencer is about as traditionally British as bed and breakfast or fish and chips. So when Britain joined the Common Market two years ago, a lot of people asked whether Britain's best known chain store and one of her better known tourist attractions would risk following the politicians into Europe.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland This has always been an ugly town and six years of terror and counterterror haven't improved its face. Belfast is pockmarked with bombed-out, burnedout sections, traffic obstacles, antigrenade nets and barriers to bomb blasts. Even in the prevailing relative tranquility British regulars constantly patrol in an effort to frustrate sectarian murder gangs.

WASHINGTON, June 27 A struggle is under way within The Washington Star between the paper's new publisher, who is fighting to save if and its controlling company directors, who apparently want to close it.

WASHINGTON, June 27 The United States Railway Association now believes it will be 1979 before Conrail, the new railroad that it is forming to succeed the bankrupt railroads in the Northeast, will become profitable.

Daisies come to bloom, whiten the roadsides and dapple the old pastures. Some people call them oxeye daisies, which is a redundancy, since the word "daisy" is no more than "day's eye" in the old English. Botanically the name is Chrysanthemum leucanthemum, which perpetuates another old English common name, Whiteflower or Whiteweed. One old back-country name in New England is Farmer's Curse.

MEXICO CITY, June 30 Hortensia Bussi de Allende, the widow of Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile, called on the United Nations today to sponsor a committee of women to investigate what she termed "crimes of the fascist junta" in Chile, especially crimes against women.

PARIS, June 30 A dispute that has been growing in the French newspaper business neared a crisis late today with the announcement that the controlling stock of the widely read morning daily Le Figaro would be sold to a publisher against the will of a part of the news staff.
The First National City Bank said yesterday that the oil coma panies so-called capital gap has "not only persisted but widened" despite sharply increased earnings in 1973 and 1974.

LONDON, July 1 In a surprise statement before the House of Commons this afternoon, Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey warned labor and management that unless they devised a voluntary plan limiting wage increases to 10 per cent, the Government, would move toward statutory controls on incomes, prices and dividends.

New Yorkers seemed to feel sorrow rather than anger when their garbege was not picked up yesterday, but above all they seemed to feel resignation. If there was one predominant mood, it was captured almost precisely by the wife of an apartment house superintendent in Astoria, Queens.

Would you buy a tennis racquet for $139? And that's for the frame alone. Stringing it would cost an extra $10 to $23, depending whether nylon or gut was used. Compare that with the $40 to $60 an average quality racquet costs.
MOSCOW, July 1 A new law was made public today under which the Soviet Government will extract a tax of 30 per cent from all money sent from abroad to Soviet citizens.

The use of electric power by individuals and commercial businesses is on the upswing again this year, despite record high power bills, widespread unemployment and the recession. But for big industrial users of electrical power, consumption continues to be down sharply.

POINT MUGU, Calif., July 1 (UPI) Rear Adm. John M. Thomas, commander of the Pacific Missile Test Center, said today that there was no impropriety in his investment with other Navy officers in a bank at Pensacola, Fla.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Former President Richard M. Nixon says he installed the extensive White House taping system at the urging of his predecessor, Lyndon B. Johnson, who, he said, had a similar system.
LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, June 28 For the highly ideological new rulers of Mozambique, the advent of full independence is only the beginning of a major struggle to im
PARIS Voices on the telephone anywhere in the world and especially in Paris are traditionally believed to come out of the sound box and through the vocal chords of human beings.

Chuck Foreman, the National Football League's touchdown leader (15) last season and also Minnesota's leading rusher (777 yards) and receiver (53 catches) has signed a three-year contract extending his obligation to the Vikings through 1978.

The unanimous decision by the United States Supreme Court on the rights of confined mental patients can lead to greater awareness and better treatment for tens of thousands of unfortunate people who have been neglected by state and society. This possible turnaround in attitudes toward those who are forgotten behind high institutional walls could be more significant than the comparatively limited extension of their legal rights.
Stocks started the second half of 1975 in a holding pattern.
Silver, cocoa and sugar prices dropped in futures trading in London and in New York as the British pound, weak on Monday, rose.

The world's weather is Changing, as many people have observed. "We're getting longer springs, shorter growing seasons and quicker return of cold weather in the fall," Earl S. Finckle, a meteorologist said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 1 Because of the effects of inflation, there will be an 8 per cent drop in real spending for basic scientific research in the United States this year as compared with spending in 1974, according to an estimate just published by the National Science Foundation.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The Treasury sold today almost exactly the 500,000 ounces of gold it offered at auction at a price only slightly below that of the world market. The price of gold closed today in London at $166.50.
MOSCOW, July 1 A new law was made public today under which the Soviet Government will extract a tax of 30 per cent from all money sent from abroad to Soviet citizens.

The legislative battle over school aid now being waged in Albany could end with a solution forcing hundreds of school districts in the state to choose between slashing programs or raising taxes above the level voters expected when they approved local budgets.

The Continental Grain Company, the nation's largest commodity exporter, has won a landmark arbitration decision against a Turkish State agency that could have a profound impact on international commodity dealings.

The annual Big Band Ball presented by the Newport Jazz Festival at Roseland Ballroom is, in theory, an-opportunity for jazz bands to go back to their original function as dance bands and for the audience to get out on the floor and dance to jazz. In practice, there is usually more standing around than dancing as the listeners crowd around the bandstand to get a close-up look at the musicians.

TAMPA, Fla., July 1 Saying that he has "a very poor memory for details," former Senator Edward J. Gurney testified in his own defense today that he had no recollection of having hired Larry E. Williams, a fund-raiser in 1971.

Tons of garbage piled up on the city's streets yesterday as 10,000 sanitationmen, protesting the layoffs of 2,934 of their coworkers, began a walkout that Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh called "the best organized wildcat strike I've ever seen."

Since 1971, when John F. Kennedy High School opened, its English program has been one of the most experimental in the city. The school has used elective ungraded classes, where students enrolled in a given course within certain limits and experience regardless of their abilities.

Noon to 2 P.M., Equitable Life Plaza, Avenue of the Americas and 51st Street: Bobby Hackett, Vic Dickenson, John Bunch, Johnny Mince, Milt Hinton and Jackie Williams (free).

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 1 (UPI) The former general manager of the nation's largest dairy cooperative testified today that its board of directors was aware that contributions were being made illegally from corporate funds before the 1972 election.

KINSHASA, Zaire, July 1 (AP) President Idi Amin of Uganda announced today that he had decided to pardon the Briton who had been sentenced to death by firing squad for calling the President a village tyrant.
BUENOS AIRES, July 1 The political crisis in Argentina eased somewhat today as the Government and Peronist labor leaders agreed to continue negotiations over wage disputes.

TRENTON, July 1 The Board of Higher Education today ordered a 50 per cent increase in tuition at the state's public colleges as the impasse continued here between the State Senate and Assembly over how to finance $384-million in budget cuts ordered by Governor Byrne to balance the state budget.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 1 Top Lady Almahurst, an unbeaten pacer, swept both heats today and captured the $15,995 Debutante Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Historic Track.

MEXICO CITY, July 1 Representative Bella Abzug told a session of the International Women's Year Tribune today that her own country had a "third world of women," and prominent among them were the women apparel workers of New York City.

MEXICO CITY, July 1 Representative Bella Abzug told a session of the International Women's Year Tribune today that her own country had a "third world of women," and prominent among them were the women apparel workers of New York City.
WASHINGTON, July 1--Four major oil companies raised refinery gasoline prices by as much as 3 cents a gallon today, the start of the high season for summer vacations and motoring.

CHICAGO, July 1 James R. Thompson, the young United States Attorney who prosecuted some of Chicago's top Democarts, announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor of Illinois next spring.

WASHINGTON, July 1 President Ford has directed the Department of Justice to abide by a Federal court ruling that bars warrantless wiretaps of domestic organizations, even if foreign affairs or national security matters are involved, the White House said today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 1 Thailand and China established formal diplomatic relations today further cementing the ties between Peking and Southeast Asia that have developed since the recent Communist victories in Indochina.

MADRID Voltaire once observed with more truth than generosity that history is nothing but a pack of tricks we play on the dead. Therefore I suppose it is not astonishing to come across an article by a prominent United States general claiming that Marshal Tito won only paper victories during World War II and, but for the British and the Americans, could easily have been wiped out by Croatian military forces.
"Treemonisha," the only extant stage work of the ragtime composer Scott Joplin, will be brought to Broadway next fall.

FUN AND GAMES Oliver's (753-9180) is a pub of rising popularity, operated by a young Briton named Michael Wharton and wedged into the business area at 141 East 57th Street (five doors east of Lexington Avenue). Something new has just been added up front by the small oval window: piano music for the cocktail crowd and diners. Larry Biedes, at the keyboard, is something of a pub original.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Donald E. Wilkinson, a Wisconsin state farm official, reportedly is in line to take over a key agency in the Agriculture Department charged with carrying out the Government's troubled grain inspection program.

The Social Security Administration yesterday lifted a blackout on cost reports filed by Providers of Medicare. But it continued to withhold information, for policy reasons, on why many overpayment claims dating to 1967 have remained unresolved, and why charges of fraud were not pursued.

Carlos Monzon, the world Boxing Association middleweight champion, says his manager is negotiating with the World Boxing Council champion, Rodrigo Valdes, for a bout that would put the title under one roof.

WASHINGTON, July 1 Ruth L. Farkas, the American Ambassador to Luxembourg, told the Watergate grand jury last spring that she won her diplomatic post in a direct and explicit exchange for a $300,000 contribution to the Nixon re-election campaign of 1972, according to a source close to the Farkas family in New York.

Isaiah E. Robinson was elected president of the Board of Education yesterday and immediately called upon teachers and others to shun the example of the sanitationmen and, instead, use "creativity and ima-' gination" to minimize the impact of budget cuts on the schools.

Chessie System, Inc., the first railroad to issue its secondquarter operating results, announced yesterday that earnings in the period were $24-million, or $1.30 a share, down from $25.1-million, or $1.41 a share, in the year ago period. First half net was $40.1-million, compared with $38.6-million in 1974. .

Nevertheless few American women win fame, power, or distinction. Why? Perhaps because public policies of equality are undercut by personal experiences with inequality.

Jack M. Stenbuck, general circulation director of the Hearst Newspapers from 1955 until 1966, who was also a writer, died yesterday in Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 75 years old and lived in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles.

ENGLEWOOD, July 1 After a year of paring costs through fiscal and management reforms that led to a reduction in the real estate tax rate here, this "mini-cosmopolis" may have to wipe out the savings to the taxpayer and increase substantially the tax rate to offset threatened cuts in stale educational aid.

PINE RIDGE, S.D., July 1 The Federal authorities were holding an unidentified Indian as a material witness today in the slaying of two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in a gun battle on this Sioux reservation last Thursday.

The armed forces will have their first black officer of four-star rank upon Senate confirmation of Lieut, Gen. Daniel James Jr. of the Air Force as a full general. There are several reasons one can think of as to why the Hammond Organ Company has chosen to sponsor a Jazz on the Hammond program for the last two Newport Jazz Festivals. Perhaps the company just loves jazz. Perhaps it wishes in a general way to spread its name around among jazz buffs. Or perhaps Hammond is fearful of the competition from newer types of electronic keyboard instruments.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 1 Brazil, striving dynamically to achieve big-power status before the end of the century, is both modeling her efforts after the United States and taking her distance from it.

American Ballet Theater seems to be giving us nothing but galas during its 30th anniversary year last night at the New York State Theater, at the start of its annual six weeks' season, it came up with another, and yet another is just around the corner, later in the month. BEAUMONT, Tex., July 1 (AP) Mobil Oil Corporation said today that it would begin an immediate review "of employe qualifications following a Federal court order to stop any potentially discriminatory practices against women.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES England, July 1 (AP) Massachusetts Institute of Technology took its seventh boat onto the River Thames today and, like the six others the heavyweight eight had used in the last four days, it leaked.

WASHINGTON, July 1 Federal, Energy Administration officials are said to have obtained two documents that discuss reports of the involvement of Governor Carey, when he was a member of the House of Representatives, in a controversial oil deal involving his brother Edward M. Carey.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, July 2 A new Cabinet was installed in Lebanon yesterday, and a few hours later a cease-fire was announced in the persistent street fighting between armed groups of Christians and Moslems.

NEW ORLEANS, July 1 A local executive of Cook Industries, Inc., arranged for "complete secrecy" in unloading a cargo of corn that was rejected by Mexican buyers in 1970 because it had an unacceptable amount of broken kernels.
JERUSALEM, July 1 (AP) Israeli newspapers said today that American technicians might be asked to serve in any new Sinai buffer zone between Israeli and Egyptian armies.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The Federal Government was asked today to ban the use of food packages made from polyvinyl chloride on the ground that a cancer-causing residue from the widely used plastic has been found in such products as vegetable oils, mouth washes, meats and medicines.
LEWES, Del., July 1 (AP) Howard I. Chapelle, a marine writer and historian, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 74 years old.

TRENTON, July 1 (UPI) State Senator Anthony Imperiale, Independent of Essex, heading home from a long Senate session, stopped to administer exygen to two passengers after a car accident early this morning, the police said.

TRENTON, July 1 The Board of Higher Education today ordered a 50 per cent increase in tuition at the state's public colleges as the impasse continued here between the State Senate and Assembly over how to finance $384-million in budget cuts ordered by Governor Byrne to balance the state budget.
PARIS, July 1 Publication of the morning newspaper Le Figaro was suspended today in the wake of a 24-hour strike by journalists resisting the sale of controlling stock to a new owner.

A proposal by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller for a state takeover of the city Sanitation Department for the duration of a health emergency ended the nine-day sanitation strike in February, 1968, which had piled nearly 100,000 tons of refuse along the city's streets.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 1 Christopher Pollak of the Cedar Point Yacht Club in Westport, until recently a Navy lieutenant, won the annual men's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today. He captured the Commodore Hipkins Trophy in taking the regatta by 2 points.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., July 1 Kathy Kuykendall of Miami and Jeanne Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., each scored two victories today and reached the semifinals of the $1O,000 Ms. America circuit tennis tournament at Grossinger's Hotel.
A mobile health van will be stationed at some uptown thoroughfares on Mondays throughout this month and August in connection with the sixth annual Harlem Regional High Blood Pressure Program.

Despite its pretty images, a flower garden of white winged darts and a dozing, playful woman as comfortable as a house cat, Kei Takei's "After Lunch" ran to tedious length on Monday evening. Miss Takei's preoccupation with time has never been more directly explored than it was in this dance piece given at New York University's School of the Arts Theater.
SAN DIEGO, June 30 (AP) Harry Morris, who was on active duty in the Navy longer than any other enlisted man in history, died Sunday at 87.

CLEVELAND, June 30 (UPI) Maj. Harry D. Jones of the Ohio National Guard testified today that National Guard troops were "firing all over the place" When they shot and killed four students and wounded nine others during an antiwar demonstration at Kent State University on May 4, 1970.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The newly appointed chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission called tonight for greater emphasis on education as a means to expand job potential of minorities and said that there was a need to re-educate educators.

The White House yesterday approved American Airlines, Inc., transferring its mainland to Hawaii routes to the South Seas, including Australia and New Zealand, to Pan American World Airways. At the same time, the White House agreed to Pan American's transferring its United States to Bermuda routes and its nonstop New York to San Domingo and New York to Barbados routes to American Airlines.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1 The first statewide strike of Pennsylvania employes began today.

With just about perfect weather to encourage them, opera buffs began marking their spots in Central Park's Sheep Meadow yesterday morning in anticipation of last night's opening concert of "Madama Butterfly." Puccini's opera, with Renata Scotto as the stalwart Butterfly, is the first in the series of eight free concerts the Metropolitan Opera is offering in city parks throughout the five boroughs.

ALBANY, July 1 "Do you think I can wear a size 15 shirt?" Mayor Beame asked at 2:15 this morning as he headed for the third-floor guest room at the Governor's Mansion and began considering such cares of the morrow as borrowed clothing, wildcat walkouts by city workers and the strange ways of bargaining by state government leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 1 Manufacturers achieved a nearrecord reduction in their inventories in May as a Further prelude to a revival of production in the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.
Last week Fireman Thomas K. Newbert was elbow-deep in foam used to smother fires as he and Fireman Richard Wieser rescued a Norwegian sailor from the burning wreckage of Eastern Airlines Flight 66.

Phil Woosnam, commissioner of the North American Soccer League, upheld last night the New York Cosmos' protest of a game they lost in Boston against the Minutemen on June 20, during which Pele was mobbed by spectators. The game will be replayed on Sunday, Aug, 3.

James Havender, a retired lawyer and one of the country's oldest active lifeguards, died Saturday at Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis, Mass. He was 83 years old and made his summer home in East Brewster, Mass.
