WASHINGTON, July 1 The selling of Gerald R. Ford as a plausible President is well advanced. Under the management of the shrewd politicians and businessmen who comprise his "kitchen Cabinet," Mr. Ford is being marketed as another Harry Truman, another honest, decent, friendly Middle Westerner who talks simply and acts on readily understandable human instincts.

STOCKHOLM, July 1 (AP) Anders Garderud, Sweden's Long-distance running star, set a world record in the 3,000-meter steeplechase with a time of 8 minutes 9.69 seconds today at an international meet.

WASHINGTON, July 1 President Ford urged black leaders today to support his policy of fiscal restraint as a key to fulfillment of equality for American minorities. WASHINGTON, July 1 Senator Jacob K. Javits, New York Republican-Liberal and his wife paid $2,180 in Federal income taxes last year on gross earnings of $91,526, adjusted to $86,526, according to a voluntary disclosure made by the Senator in the issue of The Congressional Record distributed today.

OBERKIRSCH, West Germany, July 1 (AP) Hans Furler, a founder of the European Common Market and former president of the European Parliament, died Sunday. He was 71 years old.

The president of the Auxiliary Police Benevolent Association urged his members not to go out on street patrol yesterday because of the reduction in the police force that took place yesterday.
NEWARK, July 1 A Federal jury found a South Jersey farm foreman not guilty here today of holding migrant workers from Puerto Rico in involuntary servitude last summer.

ALBANY, July 1 A bill to permit citizens to sue to protect the environment was defeated in the Senate today after a sponsor denounced one of the bill's opponents so bluntly and bitterly that his remarks brought whistles and murmurs of astonishment from the other Senators.

Stocks of leading group broadcasters companies owning radio and television stations have almost doubled in price from their lows at the end of 1974.

Dr. Johannes Christian Hoekendijk, who had been professor of missions at Union Theological Seminary since 1965, died last Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, while swimming in Long Island Sound. He was 63 years old.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 In the last two and a half months, Beirut has probably seen at least as much violence between Christians and Moslems as Belfast has seen in six, years of conflict between Roman Catholics and Protestants.

The Government of Portugal has just dismissed its chief delebate to the United Nations, Prof. Jose Veiga Simao. The ambassador's "crime" seems to have been a speech he delivered last week denouncing arbitrary arrests, imprisonment without trial and other violations of elementary human rights.

ALBANY, July 1 The Legislature today approved a bill eliminating the present sevenmember, part-time State Commission of Correction and replacing it with a three-member, full-time salaried board appointed by the Governor, with expanded powers.

The Conference Board has reported that the help-wanted advertising index leveled off in May. The index, at 71, is unchanged from the April level and is 1 point above the March reading, but 44 points below the level of May, 1974.

"Whoever has made a voyage up the Hudson must remember the Kaatskill mountains," Rip Van Winkle recalled in Washington Irving's famous tale. "They are . . . seen away to the west of the river, swelling up to a noble height, and lording it over the surrounding country."

LONDON, July 1 In a surprise statement before the House of Commons this afternoon, Chancellor of the Exchequer Denis Healey warned labor and management that unless they devised a voluntary plan limiting wage increases to 10 per cent, the Government would move toward statutory controls on incomes, prices and dividends.

TRENTON, July 2 A Fort Lee rent-leveling ordiance limiting landlords to 2.5 per cent rent increases was upheld today in Superior Court in Bergen County According to Fort Lee's attorney, Armand Pohan, the 2.5 per cent rate is the lowest in the state.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The Central Intelligence Agency, in a move that has surprised, mystified and angered various segments of Washington's legal community, has hired Arnold Porter, one of the city's leading law firms, to serve as consulting counsel during Senate and House hearings on the agency.

YODER, Kan., A longawaited breakthrough in the development of hybrid wheat seed has occurred this summer, offering America's winter wheat farmers the chance of eventually increasing their yields by at least 20 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 2 Army Secretary Howard M. Callaway said today that despite "enormous progress" in improving race relations in the military, there is still "a lot of racial tension" within the Army.

PRAIA, Cape Verde Islands, July 2 (AP) Citizens of the Cape Verde Islands have voted overwhelmingly in favor of union with the newly independent West African nation of Guinea-Bissau, unofficial figures showed today.

A full cast was put on Gov. George C. Wallace's left leg yesterday and will remain for about three weeks. The "simple fracture of the tibia" the larger bone between ankle and knee probably occurred during the Alabama Governor's physiotherapy exercises, according to his physician, Dr. Hamilton Hutchinson of Montgomery.

The most charitable comment to be made about the recent report by Governor Carey's task force on the financing of education is that the panel's heart is approximately in the right place. It is easy to agree with its view that the state should carry a greater part of the burden in the financing of public schools, particularly in the hard-pressed cities.
The "magnet" high school, a new version of an old idea, may be setting a pattern for the future of secondary education in the city.

John McMaster, who retired several years ago as first financial vice president of Great American Insurance Companies here, died yesterday at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Sharon.
PEKING, July 2 Premier Kukrit Pramoj of Thailand said here tonight that Chinese leaders had denied they supported pro-Communist insurgents in his country.

The Fire Department shut down 26 of its 360 companies yesterday morning because of the city's financial crisis, but most firemen continued to hold out hope that Mayor Beame would somehow raise new money and that at least some of them would be restored.
A state law that restricts the distribution and advertising of nonprescription contraceptives was declared unconstitutional yesterday by a panel of three Federal judges here.
Dick Cavett says there were "glaring errors" in accusations filed against him by-the state's Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, in connection with a suit against the Museum of the American Indian.

Interest rates took another good-sized upward step yesterday as the credit markets became more convinced that the Federal Reserve had recently brought to an end its policy ...

Sales of the nation's largest retail chains in June generally held to the gains of May, continuing the better trend since Easter, according to results reported yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, July 2-An oil tanker chartered to carry American wheat to Egypt in late May is still sitting partly loaded in the port here, while a costly dispute continues over inspectors' rulings that it is not clean enough to take the cargo.

LONDON In July, 1966, Britain was going through an acute stage of her long-running economic melodrama. The Prime Minister, Harold Wilson, made a speech giving assurance that the value of the pound would be maintained. He blamed the crisis atmosphere on "the sell Britain short brigade," on "moaning Minnies and wet editorials."

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 2 (UPI) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. signed an $11.4-billion California budget yesterday and promptly came under fire from state employe and highway patrolmen's organizations for reducing proposed salary increases.
BOSTON, July 2 (AP)-A three car subway train collided with a dangling overhead power cable in a tunnel today, setting the first car afire and forcing the evacuation of 400 passengers on foot.

The leadership of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association voted yesterday against taking any formal job action in the wake of the dismissal of 5,000 city police officers.

Put away the Gucci and the Vuitton and go native. The bag of summer is a woven straw affair that might carry vegetables in its native habitat: North Africa, the Philippines or China. It is best in the natural color of the straw, with pattern left to the weave, rather than added adornment. Embroidered flowers, "souvenir of Acapulco" or coy linings are out they mark you as the wrong kind of tourist.

Frederick P. Lawrence, board chairman of Sayre Electric Affiliates in East Liverpool, Ohio, and president of the Sayre Development Company, a realestate concern in Princeton, N.J., died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 177 Library Place, Princeton. He was 64 years old.

In winning the 1975 United States championship, his second in succession, Walter Browne displayed a steadiness his rivals failed to match. The only other player to go through the event undefeated was Arthur Bisguier, but, while Bisguier could not gain a single point outright, Browne won four games to take the $2,300 first prize.

FARGO, N.D., July 2 (UPI) Flood waters, swollen by a foot or more of rain, turned into an "ocean" in the Red River Valley today, wiping out crops, keeping several hundred persons from their homes and causing hundreds of million dollars in damage.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) First claims for regular state unemployment insurance benefits in the week ending June 21 increased by about 10,000 from the previous week's level, the Government said today.

The Newport Jazz Festival's "Salute to Jazz and the American Song" started out at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening as though it were going to be a triumph. But then it began melting as inexplicably as that cake in "MacArthur Park."

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon told a small, mostly silent assembly of black leaders today that job and social advancements for blacks would be stunted until the economy recovered.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was turning over to the Justice Department for possible prosecution the question whether the Chrysler Corporation turned out cars that violated clean-air laws.

A wildcat strike of highway workers, protesting 570 layoffs, led to a traffic tie-up on the Henry Hudson Parkway yesterday, and a similar scene is anticipated for this morning's rush hour unless drivers take alternative routes.

A 90-year-old Bronx man who was beaten and robbed five times in the last year hopes the attempt on him again yesterday was the last. The police arrested two youths when the man went to a subway station to pay them $200 on their demand.
At today's prices, I.B.M. must seem attractive to some who have always said they would buy the stock if it did not carry such a high price-earnings ratio.

ATHENS, July 2 (AP) The Greek Supreme Court today cleared 104 high officials of the former dictatorship of charges in connection with the military coup of April, 1967. It ruled that they had played no direct role in the armed forces' seizure of power.

MANILA, the Philippines, July 2 (AP) Benigno S. Aquino Jr., once the main political opponent of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, will be tried in a military court on charges of subversion, murder and illegal possession of firearms, the government said today.

JERUSALEM, July 2 A political debate over whether to accede to Egypt's demand for complete Israeli withdrawal from the strategically important Sinai mountain passes has opened deep divisions in the Israeli Government, the ruling Labor party and the smaller parties of right and left.

TRENTON, July 2 Democratic leaders in the Assembly have abandoned their commitment to a state income tax, and were reported this evening to have enough votes to approve an alternative package of nuisance taxes that would cancel most of the $384-million in state budget cuts ordered by Governor Byrne.

CONCRETE, Wash., July 2 Mount Baker, a 10,778-foot long-dormant volcano towering near this tiny town, is coming back to life and may soon provide the first major volcanic activity in the 48 contiguous states in 60 years.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Betty Ford disclosed today that the President has been exchanging photographs in silver frames with visiting heads of state in an effort to eliminate the practice of expensive gift-giving on state visits.

Straw has always been a wonderfully cool material for summer bags and there certainly is enough basketry around to suit every taste and pocketbook. Ethel Winant, a production and casting executive for CBS TV for two decades, is leaving the network July 14 to join the Children's Television Workshop as executive producer of its new history series contemplated for next season on public television.

HOBOKEN, July 2 (UPI) Serious research into windmills did not begin at Stevens Institute of Technology until Prof. Franklin Pollock was nearly blown over by a gust of wind from across the Hudson River.

BONN, July 2 The American withdrawal from Indochina this spring shook and worried West Germany, the most powerful ally of the United States in Europe. But the Germans' preoccupation was that America might turn away from them, not that West Germany should reappraise its transAtlantic ties.

The Federal Aviation Administration acknowledged yesterday that any decision of an airport operator to halt flying at a field would be dictated not by flight conditions in the air but only if something developed on the ground that affected the usability of runways.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Secretary of State Kissinger will meet with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva next week to discuss a possible reconvening of the Middle East peace conference and other issues affecting the United States and the Soviet Union.

"If it wasn't for the dogshow sport, the first public diabetes hospital in America probably still wouldn't be built," said Don Starkweather, who teaches at the hospital in Birmingham. Ala., which was two years old last month.

MILAN, Italy, July 2 (AP) Don Quarrie, the Jamaican sprinter, beat the American star, Steve Williams, twice tonight to highlight an international track and field meet.

CLEVELAND, July 2 Like a stick of dynamite with a delayed fuse, a strategic move made by Frank Robinson in the seventh inning tonight exploded in the Yankees' collective faces in the ninth and led to a 3-2 victory by the Cleveland Indians.
For Sanitation Commissioner Robert Groh, the second full day of a citywide garbage strike brought with it a dizzying range of logistical problems and all too few solutions.

LONDON, July 2-James Robertson Justice, the Scottish actor who was perhaps best known for his role as a peppery surgeon in British comedy films, was found dead in bed today at his home in the village of King's Somborne in southern England. He was 70 years old.

ROSCOE, N.Y. When Paul Updike of Roscoe and I visited the no-kill section of the Willowemoc River last week and assembled our trout rods in the last hour before dusk, it was only the prelude to a long planned fishing trip on the Delaware River.
Tomorrow on the Elipse in Washington the Yippies will celebrate the Fourth of July their way, with a smoke-in, their sixth annual. It will be on and with grass.

LONDON, July 2 Two New York book dealers paid $88,000 today for one of the original printed copies of the Declaration of Independence.

ALBANY, July 2 The State Court of Appeals ruled today that an individual taxpayer had the right to go to court to challenge the constitutionality of a state law in cases where a denial of that right would mean, in effect, that the law in question would not be challenged.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market continued to fall for the second straight day in decreased trading. Profittaking, a belief by some investors that bank prime interest rates may be raised shortly and an increase in gasoline prices appeared to be the depressing factors.

ALBANY, July 2 Governor Carey has vetoed a bill that would have given veterans of the two world wars and of the Korean and Vietnam conflicts an absolute preference in retention of Civil Service positions over their nonveteran colleagues in the event of layoffs or job eliminations, his office announced today.
ATLANTA, July 2 (UPI) Bonnie Lauer of Orchard Lake, Fich., has placed 11 qualifiers for the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

LONDON, July 2 The Government of Prime Minister Harold Wilson moved today on several fronts to build public support, particularly among the trade unions, for its proposed measures to reduce Britain's high inflation rate.
WASHINGTON, July 2 A White House official said today that President Ford had refused to meet with Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn on advice from the National Security Council.

Diane Mandle, an actress, was married yesterday noon to Eric Davis of London, a painter and fashion designer. State Supreme Court Justice Alvin Ruskin performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton Inn in Port Chester, N.Y.
With revisionist ardor and amnesiac delight, Bicentennial officials are wiping the slate clean of Revolutionary War defeats.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The White House and Congressional Democrats began jockeying today for advantage in a political battle over prices for oil and natural gas that is expected to dominate the capital's business in July.

Dr. Jacques M. May, widely known medical geographer, and his wife, the former Donna McLelland, died Monday in an automobile accident in Tunisia He was 79 years old and she was 35. They lived in Chatham, Mass.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 2 Though Dr. James S. Coleman, the sociologist, is vacationing in West Virginia, the University of Chicago professor dominated much of a three-day meeting here on equal education, where speakers and panelists accused him of abandoning the fight for school integration.
Stock prices retreated widely yesterday on reports that the First National City Bank might raise its prime interest rate to 7 per cent.

The subdued rattle of a taxi's diesel engine has been a familiar and cheerful sound in Germany for many years, and yesterday it became a permanent part of the New York scene. Ten diesel-powered taxicabs went into regular around-theclock service as part of the taxi industry's latest effort to conserve fuel and cut air pollution.

WASHINGTON, July 2 President Ford, calling a strong housing industry "crucial to our over-all economic recovery," signed into law today a compromise housing measure intended to spur the construction and sale of 300,000 homes.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 The Brazilian Air Force Ministry said tonight that two Brazilian generals mentioned in a Northrop Corporation memorandum had nothing to do with the $72.3-million purchase of 42 Northrop F-5 fighter planes.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 The Henley Royal Regatta, which has been rowed on the same stretch of the Thames since 1839, begins tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The voting solidarity of the four Justices named by President Nixon to the Supreme Court fell off perceptibly during the term that closed this week, but their power to control decision-making remained strong.

Audrey Gellen Maas, the writer and producer, died yesterday at New York Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. She lived at 444 East 57th Street and was 40 years old.

Supplies of gasoline in the United States rose last week for the first time since Feb. 21 as the nation's refineries increased their output to 85.7 per cent of capacity.

Jess Ward, founder and president of Jess Ward Co., Inc., woolen merchants, died Sunday in Jerusalem, Israel. He was 74 years old and lived at 15 West 81st Street.

SWEDESBORO, N.J., July 2 New Jersey's Secretary of Agriculture today praised as a "landmark event" the acquittal of Marcus Portalatin of charges of enslaving migrant workers and assaulting farm visitors.

Heavy rains in Minnesota and North Dakota apparently helped move soybean futures prices ahead on the Chicago Board of Trade. CONCRETE, Wash., July 2 Mount Baker, a 10,778-foot long-dormant volcano towering near this tiny town, is coming back to life and may soon provide the first major volcanic activity in the 48 contiguous states in 60 years.
New York State lent its powerful support yesterday to n movement aimed at creating a uniform system of registering securities brokers, dealers and salesmen throughout the country.
With revisionist ardor and amnesiac delight, Bicentennial officials are wiping the slate clean of Revolutionary War defeats.
PARIS, July 2 A man arrested a month and a half ago for carrying forged identity papers has been identified as a drug supplier and has been indicted in Marseilles, the police announced today.

JERUSALEM, July 2 A political debate over whether to accede to Egypt's demand for complete Israeli withdrawal from the strategically important Sinai mountain passes has opened deep divisions in the Israeli Government, the ruling Labor party and the smaller parties of right and left.

NEW ORLEANS, July 2 (AP) A Federal jury has awarded $275,000 to plaintiffs seeking more than $10-million in damages from the sniper attack here in 1973 in which eight persons died and 17 were wounded.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Nicos G. Dimitriou, the Cypriote Ambassador to the United States, charged at a news conference today that the Government of Turkey was attempting to alter the ethnic structure of Cyprus by settling thousands of mainland Turks in previously Greek areas.
HARRISBURG, Pa., July 2 (AP) Pennsylvania won court injuctions and arrests mounted today as a strike by an estimated total of 50,000 state employes entered its second day.
ALBANY, July 2-Before Mayor Beame arrived tonight to resume talks on his budget, legislative leaders had met this afternoon to discuss the agenda for the remainder of the session.

McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N.J., July 1 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Daniel James Jr., the first black to be nominated for the rank of four-star general, said today that "institutionalized racism has been eliminated from the armed services."

Rick Wise of the Boston Red Sox, bidding to become only the second pitcher in modern major league history to hurl no-hit games in both leagues, gave up consecutive homers in the ninth inning and settled for a two-hit, 6-3 triumph over the Brewers in Milwaukee's County Stadium last night.

WASHINGTON, July 2 The Central Intelligence Agency, in a move that has surprised, mystified and angered various segments of Washington's legal community, has hired Arnold Porter, one of the city's leading law firms, to serve as consulting counsel during Senate and House hearings on the agency.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 In one of the most incredible comebacks of her long career, Billie Jean King struggled from 0.3 and 15-40 in the third set, took six games running and defeated Chris Evert today, 2-6, 6-2, 6-3, reaching her ninth final at the Wimbledon tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Louis C. Wyman, the Republican claimant to New Hampshire's vacant Senate seat, said today that he could not believe that the woman he helped win an ambassadorial post had charged him with enticing her and her husband into illegally purchasing the job.

Eleven persons have been dismissed from a federally subsidized job program in New Brunswick because of their participation in partisan politics. Edward Hardy, executive director of the country's Comprehensive Employment Administration, said the 11 had been discharged because his office had determined they were in violation of the Hatch Act, which prohibits Federal employes from participating in partisan political activities, He refused to identfy those who were discharged.
WASHINGTON, July 2 Army Secretary Howard M. Callaway said today that despite "enormous progress" in improving race relations in the military, there is still "a lot of racial tension" within the Army.

LYNDHURST, July 2 (UPI) The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission agreed today to work with the Tristate Planning Commission on a study of mass-transit needs in the 19,750-acre Meadowlands district.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 2 (UPI) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. signed an $11.4-billion California budget yesterday and promptly came under fire from state employe and highway patrolmen's organizations for reducing proposed salary increases.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 3 Senator Dick Clark, Democrat of Iowa, said today he had learned that one of the world's largest grain corporations had lent money to a former state Representative so that he could start a business that would be responsible for inspecting the corporation's grain to determine its value and quality.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 (UPI) Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, predicting an imminent new war in the Middle East, said in an interview today that his forces had stepped up attacks on Israel and would launch even more in the future.

TRENTON, July 3 State Treasurer Richard C. Leone said today that the package of increased sales taxes and other nonincome levies under consideration by the Legislature would still leave the state with a budget deficit of as much as $133.2-million.

CAPE CANAVERAL, July 3 The Air Force today signed the 23d consecutive contract with Pan American World Airways to operate the missile range from Florida to the Indian Ocean. DETROIT, July 3 Bradford Mallory, a worker at Chrysler's Hamtramck, Mich., plant, has been laid off for eight months and has only 12 weeks left of unemployment insurance. But he is no longer worried.

Nancy Ellen Lefkowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lefkowitz of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Beth-E1 Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y., to David Charles Finkelstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan G. GOSHEN, N.Y., July 3 Goshen, it seems, started getting ready for the Bicentennial before there was a Declaration of Independence. The first resident, Sarah Wells, married an Englishman in 1718 and when she died (at the age of 102), she had 12 children, 98 grandchildren, 212 great-grandchildren and 13 great-great-grandchildren, nearly all of whom lived to take their heritage seriously.

Six young men were arrested by Queens detectives yesterday following a series of crimes, involving a homicide, two other shootings and several robberies over a period of three days.

The romantic side of contemporary jazz was brought to the Newport Jazz Festival on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall by the Chuck Mangione Quartet. Mr. Mangione, dividing his attention between electric piano and flugelhorn, led his group through a program that glowed with mellow moods and sounds even when the tempos became bright and lively.
ROCHESTER, Minn., July 3 (AP) Dr. Louis A. Buie, a Mayo Clinic pioneer and founder of the clinic's proctology section, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.
The operator of a Bronx nursing home and a former Fordham Hospital social worker were convicted late Wednesday night of having swindled two aged patients out of their life savings.

NEW DELHI, July 3?It rained in Madras today. Jubilant crowds danced in the streets in the south Indian city as 3 inches of rain were recorded since last night. Reservoirs on which the population of three million depends for drinking water have begun filling up.
HAMILTON, Ohio, July 3 (AP) A panel of three judges today convicted James U. Ruppert of aggravated murder in the Easter slaying of 11 members of his family.

LISBON, July 3 (UPI) Portugal's military rulers said today that they would nationalize the country's radio stations in a move aimed at ending a power struggle over control of a Roman Catholic station.

BRUSSELS, July 3 (UPI) The dollar sustained its weeklong upswing on European money markets today but gold and the British pound fell.

The Aluminum Company of America, the Reynolds Metals Company and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation issued statements indicating they would comply with the request sent to them by Albert Rees, director of the council.

This paradox seems to illustrate best the divergent paths taken by the tennis-playing sisters in the last year.

Frank Carrington, co-founder and producer of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., died yesterday at his home in Millburn. He lived in a converted barn on Brookside Drive near the theater he operated.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 Jimmy Connors crushed Roscoe Tanner, 6-4, 6-1, 6-4, today on center court in 80 minutes. In the last few weeks, New Yorkers got unsavory indications of that crisis as the thousands of layoffs proclaimed by Mayor Beame touched off a garbage strike, work slowdowns and dire predictions of civil chaos.
JERUSALEM, July 6--Israel postponed today for at least a week a decision on the disputed elements of a new agreement with Egypt on disengagement in Sinai.
NEW DELHI, July 6 The Indian Government today stepped up its campaign of economic measures, which its critics say are designed to deflect attention from the political crisis.
BOSTON, July 6 Republican mayors made unsuccessful attempts today to head off criticism of the Ford Administration's policies by the largely Democratic mayors of the nation's big cities.
NEW ORLEANS, July 6 Farm pesticides are once again threatening to destroy Louisiana's state bird, the brown pelican.

The truth about the tragedy on the Kent State campus five years ago is finally beginning to emerge for the first time, after a series of coverups condoned by exGovernor James A. Rhodes of Ohio and continued by former United States Attorneys General John N. Mitchell and Richard G. Kleindienst.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 The Phillies gave away wrist bands today. Then the Mets gave away the ball game as they "failed to come up with big plays" and lost, 8-6, for their third defeat in a row at the hands of the Philadelphia Slugging Company.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 6 Rhodesia's black leaders gave every impression today of having resolved their bitter factional differences and of having agreed on an uncompromising stand in dealing with the white minority Government of Rhodesia.

WASHINGTON, July 6 Against the advice of both the Defense Department and his Budget Office, President Ford has asked Congress to allow the Navy to construct a nuclear powered cruiser that would cost $1.2-billion, making her one of the most expensive ships ever built by the Navy.

TRENTON, July 6 A coalition of women's groups, determined to add an Equal Rights Amendment to the New Jersey Constitution this year, has already encountered so much opposition from other women and from some State Senators that the success of the drive appear doubtful at this time.

There is fairly general agreement in Washington that the regulatory agencies require urgent attention. Economists in the White House and lawyers in the Justice Department have long thought that current modes of regulation in the transportation industries especially have decreased competition and kept prices unnaturally high.
BOMBAY, India, July 6 Following Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's command, the Bombay government and the local Congress party are cracking down on gangsters, smugglers, boarders even rats.

BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP) Dr. Lillie M. Jackson, president emeritus of both the Baltimore and Maryland units of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died yesterday at her home here. She was 86 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) Richard M. Nixon saw his Presidency not as a one-man show, but as one in which he counted on "free-wheeling, candid and often blunt or critical advice" from others, according to an affidavit filed last week in Federal Court.
Mrs. Pat Menafra patted the Ruffian button pinned to her handbag and said she thought the whole issue went "way beyond" a horse race.

But once in a while they enjoy a social evening without blood, and did so last Thursday at the Old Oaks Country Club, Purchase, N.Y.

NEW ORLEANS, July 6 Melvin L. Hibbets, a vice president of a division of Cook Industries, Inc., has been suspended pending completion of an investigation by the company of its New Orleans operations. Mr. Hibbets is vice president for operations of the company's grain division.

State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that because of ineffective local evaluation methods, there was no way to judge how much of $200-million in special state aid for poor school children here had "achieved its obiectives."

The jazz that went up the Hudson River on a Staten Island ferry yesterday, the last day of the Newport Jazz Festival, was partly New Orleans, as it should be since the tradition of jazz on a riverboat stems from New Orleans. But it was also French, and in this respect, a new tradition may be in the making.
ST. JOHN'S, Antigua; July 5 (AP) Morgan Beatty, prominent broadcast and print news correspondent for more than 50 years, died Friday night at the age of 72.

KATONAH, N.Y., July 5 The Caramoor Festival's production of Francesco Cavalli's opera "L'Ormindo" began here tonight shortly after 8:30, and until around 10:45 it struck this listener as a mildly pleasant, stylistically inept bore.

BEIRUT, Lebanon July 6 (Reuters) The United States Embassy has received a letter and two cassette tapes concerning a missing United States Army colonel, Ernest R. Morgan, an embassy spokesman said tonight.

A declining prime rate, starting down from the record high of 12 per cent last September, had the blessing of the Federal Reserve, which set the stage by nudging money-market rates lower.

The Albany agreement on a new municipal tax package, inappropriately linked to a state school aid program, reflects little credit on the principal negotiators. The $330-million tax package that is expected to be approved by the Legislature today does not solve New York's immediate budget problems and it raises serious questions about the city's fiscal future.

The broad, brave smile of the grownup in braces is stretching from coast to coast. Patients well past puberty are flocking to the orthodontists in search of the better bite, the straighter tooth, the healthier, happier, sexier mouth.

One of our food passions in life is an intricately and bulkily made creation called pozole de Jalisco, a soup or stew, depending on your point of view. If Horace Greeley were alive, his advice today probably would be not "Go West, young man," but "Go into banking, young man."

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique The new rulers of Mozambique have promised to wage ideological war not only on conservative and capitalist ideas but also on the superstitions, inertia and negative aspects of traditional African tribal life.

WASHINGTON, July 6 The closing ceremony of the 197475 Supreme Court term was somehow appropiate. Before a rearly empty courtroom for 23 minutes the Justices announced eight decisions, only one or two of much interest, and then quietly adjourned.

Patricia Diane Seelig, a student at Columbia University's School of General Studies, was married yesterday at noon to Marvin Anchin, a teacher in the Lynbrook, L.I., public schools. The vacancy in the chairmanship of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has been filled at least temporarily by President Ford. Yesterday, he named Garth Marston of Seattle as acting chairman of the board.

A coalition of community groups yesterday denounced a Beame administration proposal to convert a city-financed apartment development being built near Times Square from an upper-middle-income complex to one in which poor and "moderate-income" families would live with Federal subsidies.
ALGIERS, July 7 Algerian oil will continue to cost $11.75 a barrel (f.o.b. Algerian ports) throughout the third quarter of 1975, A.P.S., the official Algerian news agency, has reported.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel returned to Washington this afternoon and promptly met with Secretary of State Kissinger to report on Israel's decision to postpone action on a new agreement with Egypt until she receives further clarification of both Egyptian and American views.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation said yesterday it had petitioned the Federal Trade Commission seeking to have the agency modify its order calling for Kennecott divestiture of the Peabody Coal Company. Kennecott acquired Peabody in March, 1968, for $285-million plus "production payments of $300-million."

Grocery sugar prices, which have dropped 67 per cent from their peak last November, are on their way up again. The Amstar Corporation, the country's largest sugar refiner, and the Sucrest Corporation, a leading refining company, announced yesterday price rises of $2 per hundred pounds on grocery sugar and $3 per hundredweight on specialty sugars. JERUSALEM Not long ago Mayor Teddy Kollek enthusiastically showed visitors the new structures on the way up in this ancient city Now he seems to point with as much pride to the projects he has helped to prevent. And he talks of the city's need to "learn from its mistakes."

He was 67 years old.

"Basically a nice guy" and "the best tennis player in the world" were the words Arthur Ashe used yesterday in Pittsburgh to describe Jimmy Connors, the man he defeated on Saturday in the men's singles final at Wimbledon. He denied the contest was a "grudge match" because Connors is suing Ashe for $5-million for libel and a charge of restraint of trade.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange fell yesterday along a broad front in slow trading.

John R. McGean, a retired aircraft executive and sportsman, died of cancer yesterday in Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 59 years old.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 7 (UPI) Karl E. Hassel, a radio pioneer and co-founder of the Zenith Radio Corporation, died today of a heart attack at Evan. ston Hospital. He was 79 years old.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 7 The Government's Democratic Action party and opposition forces have hardened their positions during congressional debate on a bill to nationalize the country's foreign-owned petroleum industry.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) A new internal report by the Labor Department's chief investigator says that 16.5 per cent of Federal public-service jobs checked were improperly filled.

CAMDEN, July 7 Judge Louis L. Goldman of State Superior Court today again refused to bar a black congregation from holding religious services in a church in the Borough of Woodlynne. Borough officials contended the congregation was violating local zoning laws.

The Weeden Corporation, parent of Weeden Co., the third-market brokerage firm, said yesterday it earned $2,03million, or $1.22 a share, in the third fiscal quarter ended June 30 contrasted with a loss of $1.15-million a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided at its midMay meeting to permit the nation's money supply to grow more rapidly in May and June to accommodate the tax debates then being mailed out by the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Intelligence sources said today that members of Congress, two Vice Presidents and other politicians had flown chartered flights on a Washington-based airline, unaware that the line was owned and operated by the Central Intelligence Agency.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The chief executive officer of the American Medical Association wrote a letter early this year to state and county officials of the association minimizing questions that had been raised in the association's own magazine about the safety of a widely used diabetes drug.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Senator Bartlett said here today that he would recom- mend aid to assist Somalia in resettling drought-stricken refugees.

The rather nervous master of ceremonies for James Brown's show Sunday night at Madison Square Garden kept referring to Mr. Brown as "this young man." Whatever else he may be, Mr. Brown does not suggest the image of lissome youth. He is solid and stolid onstage, his generous middle girded by an unusually high-waisted, broadbelted pair of pants. And his whole performance has an almost middle-aged quality to it, these days.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market dropped sharply yesterday in slower trading.

TEL AVIV, July 7 (UPI) The Israel Electric Corporation asked three American companies to submit bids for building the country's first nuclear power station.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 A small group of New York teachers received wide support here from teachers in other states in opposing the Albert Shankerbacked leadership of their state organization at the National Education Association's annual meeting.

A British scientist, here under the auspices of the chemical industry, yesterday described as "utter nonsense" the argument that fluorocarbons such as those used in some spray cans present a serious threat to the ozone layer.

Wilson B. Fotmar, a retired designer and manufacturer of women's wear for the couturier retail trade, died Wednesday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his Manhattan home. He was 63 years old.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7-Damage and casualties were surprisingly light for a large-scale operation when Israel attacked Palestinian camps and villages in southern Lebanon by land, sea and air early today.
The market for minicomputers is still booming, although not so spectacularly as in the recent past, according to a study just completed by the publisher of modern Data magazine.

BALTIMORE, July 7 The former West Virginia State Treasurer, John H. Kelly, pleaded guilty here today before United States District Judge Joseph H. Young to charges of fraud, extortion and misuse of bank funds.

The Health Department has sited 12 food businesses for failing to correct violations on second inspection. They have been warned that they face closing orders if the violations persist upon a third and final inspection.

The Harris Poll reported yesterday that a 43-to-38 per cent plurality of Americans felt that Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, "would inspire confidence in the White House," according to The Associated Press.

The union that represents about 1,600 New York Public Library employes is taking a poll of its members to find out whether they would favor a four or a four-and-a-half-day work week to avert layoffs.

The National Basketball Association suffered a second major blow yesterday when David Thompson decided to play for the Denver Nuggets of the rival American Basketball Association rather than the Atlanta Hawks of the N.B.A.

CONCORD, N.H., July 8 (AP) The Federal Government sued the state of New Hampshire today over Gov. Meldrim Thomson's refusal to provide information on the racial and ethnic backgrounds of state workers.

UNIONDALE, L.I., July 8 Playing with the decisive accuracy that carried her to the Wimbledon championship last week, Billie Jean King led the New York Sets to a runway 26-13 victory over the San Diego Friars in World Team Tennis tonight before 2,048 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

ALBANY, July 8 The State Legislature, finally arriving at what Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal called "the end of a long and tortuous road," voted today to authorize New York City to raise $330-million in new taxes and also to give the state's school districts more than $200-million in additional aid.

ATLANTA, July 8--Dave Kingman, who has been alternating strike-outs and homers with increasing ferocity on ifie Mets' current trip, hit one of the latter for three runs and a 4-3 New York victory over the Atlanta Braves tonight.

If everyone could agree beforehand that the results were essentially meaningless, wouldn't it be fascinating to apply a decibel meter to concert and recital audiences throughout one whole season? The urge to measure the immeasurable, to try to take accurate soundings of unfathomable depths, does exert its pull in our quantifying age. Here, just for fun, is one constant listener's guess as to what such a decibel count might show.

BONN, July 8 Toni Schm cker, managing director of Volkswagenwerk, A.G., said today at a stormy meeting of shareholders in Wolfsburg, West Germany, that recent actions to steer the automobile manufacturer back to financial health were taking effect. He said that, although he hoped it could report a profit for 1976, he expected the company to have another loss this year.

The sturgeon long thought to be almost extinct in waters around New York City is apparently thriving in the Hudson River in such numbers that it would appear to offer a potentially large source of protein-rich food in sturgeon steaks and the possibility that New York may once again become a major exporter of caviar.

Some twelve weeks after the Communist entry into Phnom Penh and the forced exodus on foot of millions of urban Cambodians to distant countrysides, a veil of silence still cloaks the full horror of what has happened with the worst yet to come in predicted deaths from hunger and disease.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 8 The Town of Oyster Bay said today that it would join the Town of Babylon in Suffolk County in a suit to prevent the State Department of Parks and Recreation from doubling the $1 toll on the Jones Beach State Park complex.

The Offtrack Betting Corporation's campaign to remove the 5 per cent surtax on payoffs moved forward yesterday when the City Council approved the necessary home-rule message to enable the State Legislature to consider a repeal measure.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) The Soviet Union, suffering from drought, is preparing to purchase large quantities of grain from the United States and Canada, according to reports in two London newspapers today.
The Museum of Modern Art has invited Volvo of Sweden and Volkswagen of West Germany to design and build taxicabs suitable for use in New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 8 One day last week President Ford flew into Cincinnati through a dense smog to dedicate the National Environmental Research Center. Although a pollution alert was in effect, Mr. Ford delivered a speech that thickened the air with additional noxious materials.

BOSTON, July 8 Mayor William McNichols of Denver had just sunk his spoon into a bowl of oatmeal this morning when he spotted Mayor Beame leaving the hotel dining room. He leaped up and offered a combination handshake and pat on the back.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 Nearly a million citizens in six states will receive over $20million in refunds this week as a result of legal action begun over 20 years ago charging that drug companies had overcharged consumers.

The sturgeon long thought to be almost extinct in waters around New York City is apparently thriving in the Hudson River in such numbers that it would appear to offer a potentially large source of protein-rich food in sturgeon steaks and the possibility that New York may once again become a major exporter of caviar.

With summer comes the selling of the new television season. Now begins the flood tide of promotional spots: "Welcome to the bright new world of ABC," "Catch the brightest stars on CBS," "Superseason on NBC you're gonna like it a lot."

ALBANY, July 8--The State Legislature, finally arriving at what Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal called "the end of a long and tortuous road," voted today to authorize New York City to raise $330-million in new taxes and also to give the state's school districts more than $200-million in additional aid.

Billy Martin, a member of six pennant-winning Yankee teams in the nineteen-fifties, expressed his displeasure last night at not having been invited to the Yankees' oldtimers game that will recall that decade of glory. That was before the game.
Amid reports that the Soviet Union is about to buy grains in the United States, prices for wheat, corn and soybeans jumped by their daily permissible limits yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The Ladies Professional Golf Association introduced yesterday its new chief executive, Ray Volpe, and with him a preview of what women's professional golf will be like in the near future not the quality of the golf, but the intensity of the hard sell.

PIONEER'S DAY One of the historic names in jazz, Eubie Blake, will appear in today's 90-minute free concert at 4:30 P.M. at McGrawHill Park, Rockefeller Center. In this third program of "Jazz for City Evening," the ragtime pianist will reprise highlights of a career that began in the honky-tonk bars of Baltimore, and yielded his first hit, in 1899, "The Charleston Rag."

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Ford Administration declined today to make a specific recommendation for tax reductions designed to increase the money available for business investment in new plants and equipment, although it has said for months that increasing such "capital formation" was one of the most urgent economic problems facing the nation.
Construction has begun on a $1.9-million expansion of the Pierpont Morgan Library on the east side of Madison Avenue at 36th Street.

WASHINGTON In June, 1974, Representative Michael J. Harrington was permitted to read the transcript of a secret briefing by the Director of Central Intelligence, William E. Colby, on American covert intervention in Chile.

WEST BERLIN, July 8 The Hungarian movie "Adoption," which was directed by Marta Mezaros, and which tells the story of an unmarried woman who adopts a baby, won first prize, the Golden Bear award, at the close of the 25th Berlin Film Festival today.
PANAMA, July 8 (Reuters) Secretary of State Kissinger has told Panama that he will not give up the search for a solution to their differences over the Panama Canal, it was announced here today.

LONDON, July 8 (Reuters)--Signs of growing Soviet activity in Western currency, Eurodollar and gold markets provide evidence that the nation may be seeking substantial dollar balances for North American grain purchases, London bankers report.

A three-judge panel of they United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled here yesterday by 2 to 1, that a lower court erred in refusing to hear a case brought against the New York Stock Exchange after the financial collapse of Weis Securities, Inc., a former brokerage house.
The price of fresh squid has declined recently, making it a relatively cheap source of quality protein. Prices currently range from 60 cents to $1 a pound.
SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, July 9 (AP) Three controversial "wartime security" bills were passed by the South Korean National Assembly before dawn today.

CLIFTON, N.J. July 8 Chet Sanok, who won his fifth state amateur crown last month here on his home course, Upper Montclair, captured his first Ike golf tournament today. He defeated Jay Blumenfeld of East Orange and George Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff.
Two men, including a reputed Mafia member, were arrested On gambling charges here, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday.

The Bee Gees concert Monday night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park-- they'll be there again tonight--was a feast for people who like lush, romantically inflected poprock. The Wollman Rink wasn't full, but the crowd was respectable, given the two shows and the threat of rain, and the surrounding rocks and hills were covered with embracing couples.

GREENBURGH, N.Y., July 8 Disciplinary charges of disorderly conduct, harassment, dereliction of duty and misconduct have been filed against 41 Greenburgh Town policemen who participated in a demonstration that tied up traffic at a major intersection for two hours on June 25.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The laternal Revenue Service, in what appears to be a reversal of established policy, has ruled that it will no longer permit tax deductions for contributions to the Bach Mai Hospital Emergency Relief Fund.

More than two years after a ruling that all New York City school teachers were entitled to leaves of absence to bring up their new babies, teaching fathers apparently are passing up the chance to be at home with their children.

A legal battle over the ownership of 11 murals painted by the late Howard Chandler Christy was settled out of court yesterday when the Hotel Des Artistes filed a notice that it was dropping its suit against the Cafe Des Artistes and its former operator, Romeo Sterlini.

BERGEN-BELSEN, West Germany, July 8--His face pale, his voice grave, Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel stood solemnly before a small stone monument here today and read a prayer to the memory of the tens of thousands of Jews who perished in this vast concentration camp 30 years ago.
A Federal grand jury in Newark is investigating allegations of widespread corruption among present and former leaders of the National Maritime Union.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 John E. Ryor, a mathematics teacher from Michigan who was elected president of the 1.7 million-member National Education Association yester day at its annual convention here, shrugs off the fact that he is from the same state as the President of the United States. "We're of a different political persuasion," he says, and besides he's a Neanderthal when it comes to aid to education."

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI)--The head of the Food and Drug Administration testified today that two powerful substitutes for penicillin were related to 13 additional deaths but that adequate warning language was being required on labeling and in advertising.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) China is expected to have a good harvest this year, Congress was told today, one "as good as last year," when 255 million tons of foodgrains were produced.

MIAMI, July 8 The Roman Catholic archdiocese of Miami said today that its chancellor, Msgr. Noel Fogarty, had neither written nor signed a letter criticizing a young dissident Cuban priest who left the area in a dispute over the policy of the archdiocese toward Hispanic priests.

TRENTON, July 8 State transportation officials today announced plans for a sharply reduced rail and bus subsidy program by the state that could eliminate service for tens of thousands of commuters and result in higher fares for thousands of others.
The Museum of Modern Art has invited Volvo of Sweden and Volkswagen of West Germany to design and build taxicabs suitable for use in New York City.
A desire named streetcars is growing a desire for the return of one of America's oldest forms of urban public transpor- tation.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, who is chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, said today that former President Richard M. Nixon would be asked if he had any evidence regarding Central Intelligence Agency plots to assassinate Premier Castro of Cuba. Such plots allegedly began in the last year of the Eisenhower Administration, when Mr. Nixon was Vice President.

DETROIT, July 5 In John Joseph Riccardo's early days as a top executive of the Chrysler Corporation, he was called "the flame thrower" in recognition of the tough, aggressive way in which he approached his job and demanded performance from those under him.

STRASBOURG, France, July 8 Sir Michael Stewart, head of the British Labor party's first delegation to the European Parliament here, said today that his country was now determined to make "a success" of the European Economic Community and its efforts to move toward union.
BUENOS AIRES, July 8 Argentine labor leaders today called off a general strike after the Government had agreed to wage demands ranging in many cases to 100 percent above previous salary levels.

WASHINGTON, July 8--Representative Michael J. Harrington today defended as appropriate and responsible his disclosure to follow Congressmen last year of details of sworn secret testimony on the Central Intelligence Agency's political activities in Chile.
WASHINGTON, July 8 The Government has received its first complaint under the sweeping unfair trade practices section of the new trade law enacted by Congress late last year.
WASHINGTON, July 8 President Ford announced formally today that he would seek the Republican nomination for the Presidency in 1976 "in order to finish the job I have begun."

A Federal Labor Department official yesterday questioned whether the city had the estimated total of 1,500 to 2,000 vacancies in the Federal public employment program. Mayor Beame had said would be used to rehire some dismissed city workers.

WASHINGTON, July 8--The United States Postal Service is investigating the American Medical Association to determine whether its journal should lose a special mailing rate because of the activities of its political arm.

MORONI, Comoro Islands, July 8 (Reuters)--Ahmed Abdallah today became President of the Comoro Islands, which uniliaterally declared independence from France Sunday. He was designated by the Chamber of Deputies.

When he changes from his brown habit into blue jeans and leaves the shadowed peace of the Church of St. Francis of Assisi for the thronged sidewalks of West 31st Street, the Rev. John McVean is covering 700 years in a single step.

WASHINGTON, July 8 A House subcommittee voted today to reject portions of the school sex discrimination rules that have been written by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The panel also voted to amend the law under which the rules were written to exempt revenue-producing college sports from having to comply and to allow physical education classes to segregate on the basis of sex.

The Health and Hospitals Corporation has begun implementing city budget cuts that Dr. John L.S. Holloman Jr., its president, estimated yesterday would require 14 affiliated hospitals to lay off 1,000 professionals and others.
PARIS, Ky., July 8 (AP) A full brother or sister to Ruffian will be foaled next year, but the Claiborne Farm master, Seth Hancock, says it just won't be the same.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Federal Election Commission was urged today to bar political parties from accepting halls, security guards and transportation for national conventions that are paid for by private business interests.

The big question at a press Fancheon, held by the Manufacturers Hanover Bank yesterday was: Is the recession over? Gabriel Hauge, chair man of the bank, answered: "Yes, if you mean the end of the down."
PARIS, July 8 (AP) Guy Drut of France beat Charles Foster of the United States by more than six feet today as he won the 110-meter hurdles, the opening event of a track meet at Jean-Bouin Stadium.

Hoards of auto racing enthusiasts will be converging on Watkins Glen, N.Y., this weekend for the World Championship of Manufacturers. And, if they are typical fans, they'll probably be almost 90 per cent in the 18-to-34-year-old set, practically half of whom are making more than $15,000 a year and more than three-quarters of whom have attended college.

CHICAGO, July 8 (UPI) Not enough of the white blue-collar voters that the Rev. Francis X. Lawlor calls "my people" turned out today to save him from defeat in a Congressional election likely to be his "last hurrah" as a maverick priest in politics.

A federally contracted study of marijuana smoking in Jamaica, where the consumption by heavy users is said to be 10 to 25 times that of their American counterparts, has failed to confirm any serious adverse effects.
Some purchasers of municipal bonds, alarmed by the plight of the nation's cities, are turning to hospital bonds for tax-exempt income.

Two young men wearing white jackets and holding stethoscopes set up a specialized "practice" on Fifth Avenue and 53d Street yesterday with a card table, a little black bag and a pail for contributions.

WASHINGTON, July 8 A key Republican Congressman, Clarence J. Brown of Ohio, suggested today that President Ford might cut in half his fee of $2 a barrel on imported crude oil if he and Congressional Democrats could agree on a formula for gradual decontrol of domestic crude oil prices.
A worn-down black shoe with wooden taps on the heel and toe that belonged to John Bubbles when he danced with Judy Garland at the Palace...
Robert McQuinn, an artist and stage designer, died June 24 in Pineville, Pa., at the age of 92.

Don Sutton and Mike Marshall, named to the National League All-Star pitching squad earlier in the day by their manager Walter Alston, combined on a four-hitter to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 3-0 victory over the Pirates in Three Rivers Stadium last

With the departure June 30 of Frank C. Herringer as urban mass transportation administrator to take over as head of the Bay Area Rapid Transit District in San Francisco, the future of the trolley and other urban transit developments becomes the concern of a new administrator.

A 32-year-old Brooklyn fireman, back on duty only a few hours after a three-week vacation, collapsed while fighting a two-alarm fire in the BedfordStuyvesant section early yesterday and died three hours later.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 (UPI) A settlement on general damages was announced today in billion-dollar lawsuits based on the crash of a Turkish airlines DC-10 in France a year ago, the worst air crash in history.
PARIS, July 8 The Court of Appeals in the famed winegrowing district of Bordeaux today reduced the penalties imposed on the principal defendants in a wine-adulterating trial last December.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Ford Administration is mounting a large-scale lobbying effort among members of Congress in the hope that a vote next week will overturn the embargo imposed by Congress last winter on military assistance to Turkey.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Central Intelligence Agency made a major build-up of its domestic intelligence operation during the Administration of President Nixon, according to documents released by the C.I.A. for the first time tonight.
Floyd Barger, editor and senior vice president of The Daily News, will retire on Aug. 1.

SCARBOROUGH, England, July 8 Prime Minister Harold Wilson's efforts to control Britain's soaring inflation made progess today when mineworkers voted against demanding an immediate 60 per cent wage increase in next winter's round of negotiations.
A Federal grand jury in Newark is investigating allegations of widespread corruption among present and former leaders of the National Maritime Union.
LONDON, July 8 Eton, an ancient symbol of privilege and upper-class exclusiveness, has fallen victim to inflation and decided to take in paying guests from abroad who want to learn English.
While New York City has taken a lot of criticism over its money troubles, it has never defaulted on its obligations or filed for bankruptcy under the Federal bankruptcy law.

Martin Bear, a nine-year-old who lives in San Francisco, spent a few months recently with a relative in New York who describes him as an "exuberant political novice." While here, Martin sent a number of letters to officeholders in Washington. Those letters and excerpted replies appear below.
PARIS, July 8 The Court of Appeals in the famed winegrowing district of Bordeaux today reduced the penalties imposed on the principal defendants in a wine-adulterating trial last December.
LONDON, July 8 Eton, an ancient symbol of privilege and upper-class exclusiveness, has fallen victim to inflation and decided to take in paying guests from abroad who want to learn English.
The small, exquisite trees that Kyuzo Murata nurtures, patiently transforming nature into art, evoking timelessness through simplicity, are just like children to him.
BUENOS AIRES, July 8 Argentine labor leaders today called off a general strike after the Government had agreed to wage demands ranging in many cases to 100 percent above previous salary levels.

"There's no question about it," the chairman of the Municipal Labor Committee told a Times reporter last month, "we have the ability, in a sense, to elect our own boss." Victor Gotbaum was talking about the Mayor of New York but the electoral power of the municipal unions extends to other city officials as well in the Council, in the Board of Estimate and in the State Legislature.
WASHINGTON, July 8 President Ford announced formally today that he would seek the Republican nomination for the Presidency in 1976 "in order to finish the job I have begun."

Hamilton M. Warren, a retired vice president of sales and advertising of the National Carbon Company, a former division of the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 77 years old.

TRENTON, July 8 Layoff notices now being delivered to thousands of state employes will result in a chain reaction of "bumpings" of less senior employes in jobs governed by Civil Service regulations, state officials said today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Central Intelligence Agency disclosed tonight portions of an internal report on its domestic spying operations in the late nineteen-sixties and the early nineteen-seventies. The report was provided for President Ford last Dec. 24.
ALBANY, July 8 A bill that removes dozens of legal prohibitions against the employment of ex-convicts received final passage in the Assembly tonight and was sent to the Governor for his signature.
A woman's size isn't important at the Farmer's Daughter. The Lexington Avenue boutique has one-size garments that can be worn equally well by a 6 or a 16.
Some bridge writings, like some wines, travel well. Others do not. The general rule is that books on play and defense are exportable, while books on bidding are not.
WASHINGTON, July 8 The Central Intelligence Agency secretly paid Ashland Oil, Inc., nearly $99,000 in five recent years more than $50,000 of it in cash for undisclosed purposes.

DUMONT, July 8--As a result of difficulties encountered in trying to find foster homes for them, patients at Greystone Psychiatric Hospital in Morris Plains who have been deemed sufficiently well to be released are being held there.

There were 1,203 merger announcements in the first six months of 1975, a decline of 28 per cent from the 1,669 announcements made in the corresponding period of 1974, W.T. Grimm Co., merger consultants in Chicago, announced yesterday.

PRAGUE, July 8(AP) The United States track and field team, winning eight of the 16 final events, defeated favored Poland and Czechoslovakia today, three days after its crushing loss to the Soviet Union.
A student learning to read comes upon the sentence, "The boy jumped on the horse and rode off." But instead of saying "horse," the student substitutes "pony." Should the teacher correct him?
Aerosol cans are a convenience but they come to the consumer usually but not always at a higher cost, a research project of the New York Public Interest Research Group found.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 8 Three union officials were indicted today, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office announced.

An easing trend in money-market rates produced a fairly buoyant showing in Treasury securities yesterday. The corporate bond sector, taking its cue from the Government market, overcame its nervousness... of recent sessions to close slightly higher. Significant declines occurred in the yield of Treasury bills.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market closed narrowly mixed yesterday in slow trading although volume rose on the counter markets.
DETROIT, July 8 The Chrysler Corporation announced today its new management team.
A desire named streetcars is growing a desire for the return of one of America's oldest forms of urban public transportation.

NEW DELHI, July 8 The obscure country politician whose lawsuit against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi touched off India's political crisis filed an appeal in the Supreme Court here today, seeking additional judgments against her.

"People have always thought of me as an intellectual comedian, and I'm not. I'm a one-liner comic like Bob Hope and Henny Youngman. I do the wife jokes. I make faces." That is Woody Allen, straight, on Woody Allen, as reported by Eric Lax in "On Being Funny," a sort of stab-at-abiography cum home movie of the comedian in action.

By the standard of recent decades, President Ford's announcement of his candidacy is extraordinarily early. But in the absence of his formal permission, the legal and financial reporting requirements of the new Campaign Finance Act make it difficult for the President's friends to conduct the low-keyed preliminary campaign usually organized in behalf of an incumbent.
Food prices rose in New York City to a record level last week, as an advance of 0.9 per cent the week before was followed by an increase of 1.0 per cent.

MADRID A revolution has already occurred in Spain and almost everyone in the country knows it except for Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the handful of conservatives with whom, by preference, he surrounds himself at the sunset of his life. "When he dies," a prominent Spaniard confided to me, "the nineteenth century will finally be over."

ALBANY, July 8 Never mind the passage today of the raucously negotiated package on the New York City fiscal crisis. There is a whole faction of political ob servers who feel that the 1975 legislative session really is going to end this week because the Bleecker Bar, a nocturnal haunt of legislators, just closed for vacation and the Metropolitan dry-cleaning store will shut this Friday for a rest.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 Brazil has fiery debates in Congress on human rights, newspaper denunciations of political corruption and even incipient student strikes, but a political song or a racy play is still taboo.

SCARBOROUGH, England, July 8 Prime Minister Harold Wilson's efforts to control Britain's soaring inflation made progess today when mineworkers voted against demanding an immediate 60 per cent wage increase in next winter's round of negotiations.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., reported yesterday its highest revenues and net income for the quarter and nine months ended May 31 in the last 10 years. At the same time, Frank E. Rosenfelt, president, said that indications were that fiscal 1975 would be the best year in M-G-M's history.
The death of Pavel Virsky, leading Soviet choreographer, was reported yesterday in Moscow by Tass, the Soviet press agency. He was 70 years old.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 8 Lucia Burbadge Donnelly, editor of The Westport News, was found dead in bed at her home yesterday. The police say she died of natural causes. She was 64 years old and lived at 2 Scherer Court.

BOSTON, July 8 (UPI) The Boston School Committee has asked Judge W. Arthur Garrity of the United States District Court to postpone for a year the school building alterations required as a step toward desegregation.

TRENTON, July 8 (AP) The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that John J. Kenny, a former Hudson County Freeholder, was protected from prosecution by the state because he had been granted immunity by the Federal Government to testify in a political corruption case. The court, in a 7-0 decision, dismissed state convictions against Mr. Kenny for extortion and misconduct in office.

Natalia Makarova has made it clear to the world at large that she considers that American ballet has done her wrong; has, in effect and in fact, failed to give her the opportunities she needed to develop as an artist. Is this true? It might be.

A Federal Labor Department official yesterday questioned whether the city had the estimated total of 1,500 to 2,000 vacancies in the Federal public employment program. Mayor Beame had said would be used to rehire some dismissed city workers.

PARIS, July 8, (Reuters) A convicted robber escaped today during his trial in a Paris criminal court when his wife, disguised in lawyers' robes, handed him a revolver and then brandished a hand grenade, the police said.

A reporter on assignment for the weekly National Enquirer who had an extraordinary interest in Secretary of State Kissinger's trash was questioned for two-and-a-half hours by Secret Servicemen and Washington policemen Monday night after he picked up five bags of the Kissinger garbage.

BERGEN-BELSEN, West Germany, July 8 His face pale, his voice grave, Premier Yitzhak Rabin of Israel stood solemnly before a small stone monument here today and read a prayer to the memory of the tens of thousands of Jews who perished in this vast concentration camp 30 years ago.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 8 (Reuters) Laos warned Thailand today that her people would punish any encroachment on her independencc and sovereignty.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 9--La Forza del Destino, the black, 52-foot sloop that has been called the pirate ship on account of her blackness and has been called a comic opera on account of being named after Verdi's epic, was first to finish a slow ocean race from Marblehead here today at noontime.

WASHINGTON, July 9--The Agriculture Department has asked its general counsel's office whether a private inspection agency under investigation in New Orleans can legally be put out of business, according to official sources here.

Ground that other bridge writers fear to tread is favored territory for Robert Ewen, a former New Yorker who now makes his home in Miami. To his two previous books, original and effective treatments of opening leads and doubling, he has now added a third, Pre-emptive Bidding. This excellent 162page monograph is published by Prentice-Hall at $7.95 in hardcover and $3.95 in paperback.

In San Francisco, where private carters pick up all the trash, S.M. Tatarian, the director of the Public Works Department, which is charged with keeping the city's streets clean, says: "I shudder to think of what would happen if my department was responsible for collecting garbage."
LOS ANGELES, July 9-- "Gentlemen, Mr. Ray Bolger," Marvin Hamlisch, the composer, said, and musicians in the pit of Lindy's Opera House burst into applause.

KINSHASA, Zaire, July 9 (Reuters)--Britain's Foreign Secretary, James Callaghan, has received a categorical assurance from President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire that the British lecturer, Denis Hills, imprisoned in Uganda, would accompany him home to London tomorrow, the Zaire press agency AZAP said tonight.

"A great writer," Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn wrote in his novel "The First Circle," "is, so to speak, a second government of his country." It was as the exiled voice of the "second government" of his native Russia that the Nobel Prize-winning novelist and political dissident spoke in New York yesterday, calling upon the American people to understand the "worldwide danger" that Soviet power poses to their own freedom and security.

BOSTON, July 9--The Democratic mayors of the nation's biggest, oldest cities were defeated today in a major policy battle with a well-organized minority of Republican mayors, who were aided by divisions among the Democrats.
J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., reported yesterday that income for the quarter ended June 30 rose to nearly $45-million before securities transactions and almost $44-million afterward.
CAIRO, July 9 (UPI)--Foreign ministers or their representatives from 12 African and 12 Arab countries met today to prepare a draft declaration on principles and guidelines for closer ties.

BUENOS AIRES, July 9-- President Isabel Martinez de Peron enjoyed a brief respite today from the political crisis that has shaken the Government, as Argentina observed the 159th anniversary of her independence.

A novel medical program in which Gimbel's workers with high blood pressure were treated at the department store has achieved such favorable results that it is viewed as holding promise as a practical way of treating larger groups of patients all over the world.
AARHUS, Denmark, July 9 (AP)--The world recordholder, Dwight Stones of the United States, cleared 7 feet 2 inches to capture the men's high jump today at an international track and field meet.

Governor Carey has a rare opportunity to make civilizing inroads into the traumatized and overburdened state prison system. His bill to create a new State Commission of Corrections has passed the Legislature; now he must give life and direction to the new group.

Because of the expiration of the civil and criminal statutes of limitations, the Federal Government is unable to collect millions of dollars of overpayments of Medicare funds to nursing homes or to prosecute operators for an unknown number of frauds.

MASERU, Lesotho, July 9 (AP)--Eighteen supporters of the opposition Basutoland Congress party were found guilty of treason in the Lesotho High Court today. The charges involved a reported conspiracy to overthrow the Government of Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan a year and a half ago.

MBA Communications, which grew out of the entrepreneurial thinking in 1966 of four students at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, has been acquired by Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born international publishing baron.

Because of a combination of actions in Albany and local decisions not to reduce levels of school spending, residents of suburban areas face substantial school-tax rises this year-- 20 per cent and more in some areas.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 9-- The 51st convention of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod moved to the brink of open schism today by passing a resolution that could remove from office eight district presidents accused of breaking church law.

TRENTON, July 9--Reductions in Medicaid costs totaling $15.3-million would be implemented later this summer by cutting back physician fees and requiring New Jersey's 600,000 recipients to pay more, according to a plan proposed today by Ann Klein, the Institutions and Agency Commissioner.
Roosevelt Hospital disclosed plans yesterday to lay off 10 per cent of its 2,400 employes during July and August "because of a very bad financial situation."

CANBERRA, Australia, July 9 (UPI)--Prime Minister Gough Whitlam said at an emergency session of Parliament today that his Labor Government had sought a $4-billion loan from unofficial Arab sources partly to nationalize and develop Australia's vast energy resources.

CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, July 9--With a four-underpar 68 that held off the challenges of Jack Nicklaus and Hale Irwin, Peter Oosterhuis of Britain claimed the firstround lead in the British Open golf tournament today. Nicklaus and Irwin shot 69's and were in a six-way tie for second with Andries Oosthuizen of South Africa, Jack Newton and Bob Shearer of Australia and David Huish of nearby North Berwick.

WASHINGTON, July 9--The Federal Election Commission, rejecting more rigorous limits on political conventions, tonight handed down regulations that will permit the Republican and Democratic parties to continue to accept many of the free services that have been provided for their conventions in the past.

An alleged member of the Joseph Colombo Mafia family was being sought yesterday by Federal authorities and the police as the leader of four armed men who held up the Times Square Post Office at 340 West 42d Street in May and fled with 11 mail sacks containing about $300,000 worth of valuables.

WASHINGTON, July 9--Representative F. Edward Hebert had hoped to steer through the House yesterday a bill to authorize production of crude oil from the naval petroleum reserves, retain the Navy's jurisdiction and restore some of the prestige Mr. Hebert lost in January when he was ousted as chairman of the Armed Services Committee.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 9 (UPI)--Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said today he believed the Soviet Union was in the market to buy a large amount of wheat but did not know of any specific purchase from American traders. The W.T. Grant Company announced yesterday that its sales in the four weeks ended July 3 dropped 14.5 per cent to $120.2-million from $140.7million in the same 1974 months.
