Hard on the heels of the 10day Newport Jazz Festival, which ended last Sunday, another jazz festival started on Tuesday. This one is at the Seafood Playhouse, 209 West 48th Street, where two jazz groups will perform twice a night, Tuesday through Sunday, this week and next. Different groups will appear each evening.

Scopes, a young Dayton teacher accused of the crime of expounding in School Darwin's theory of evolution.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) --An Agriculture Department report today charged the head of American Beef Packers, Inc., with sending more than $1.1million in certified checks to close associates when the meat packing plant was in dire financial straits and contemplating bankruptcy.

Carey.
Arthur H. Barnes, vice president of the Institute for Mediation and Conflict Resolution, was named president and chief operating officer of the New York Urban Coalition yesterday.

ALGIERS--Rabia Ferhat, an energetic 33-year-old, has four children, is a school teacher and runs the local branch of the Algerian National Women's Union in the little market town of Hamadia. On March 30 she was elected president of the Hamadia Popular Communal Assembly, roughly equivalent to a New England town council, the first time a woman has been elected to this position in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, July 9--The National Institute of Mental Health issued today the Federal Government's first policy position on the issue of behavior modification, stating that the technique is worthwhile in treating some ailments, but must be used with caution, heeding the legal rights of subjects.

After a halftime lecture by Coach Gordon Bradley, the New York Cosmos scored three goals last night to defeat the Boston Minutemen, 3-1, and take first place in the North American Soccer League's Northern Division.

Madison Square Garden, in an effort to recapture the past, is bringing back televised Friday night boxing for a seven-week summer tryout. The Garden will act as promoter and matchmaker, but none of the five programs already scheduled will emanate from the Garden, once the mecca of boxing.

ALBANY, July 9--Republican legislators sued today to overturn the election of three Regents who were chosen last March in a raucous evening legislative session that the Republicans denounced as a "rump" meeting.

BUENOS AIRES July 9-- President Isabel Martinez de Person enjoyed a brief respite today from the political crisis that has shaken the Government, as Argentina observed the 159th anniversary of her independence.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 9 (AP) --A dozen armed Nigerian troops seized the grounds of a United States Embassy annex early today in a bid to force the Americans out, then withdrew after 22 hours.

WASHINGTON, July 9--President Ford's new election campaign organization will make no effort to win delegate support for Vice President Rockefeller for the second spot on the 1976 Republican ticket, the President's campaign chairman said today.

Supplies of gasoline in the United States fell sharply last week despite an increase in output by the nation's refiners. Consumer demand appeared to be outdistancing attempts to prevent spot shortages of motor fuel this summer.

HONG KONG, July 9 (AP)-- The new Communist Government of South Vietnam has reaffirmed its determination to uphold religious freedom. Hanoi's official Vietnam News Agency reported today.

The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper enterprise, reported yesterday a decline of 37.2 per cent in profits for the second quarter this year and 19.2 per cent for the first six months although sales showed only modest declines.

A wreath of 1,200 white carnations was placed on the grave of Ruffian yesterday at Belmont Park. She was buried at the track Monday.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 9 --A fleet of 222 boats competed in the 30th annual New York Yacht Club junior regetta here today. Over 500 sailors aged 13 through 17 raced in Fireballs and Blue Jays.

The board of directors of Union Theological Seminary yesterday elected as the seminary's president Donald W. Shriver Jr., a professor at Emory University. The board said Dr. Shriver was "uniquely equipped" to meet morale, fiscal and other difficulties that have beset the institution.

Stiff new rules that limit political activity of judges and their appointees were approved yesterday by the policy-making body of the state court system.

The General Electric Company, the nation's largest manufacturer of electrical products and power generation systems, reported yesterday that its earnings in the second quarter were 13 per cent below the corresponding quarter of 1974.

Jacinto Vasquez, who rode Ruffian in all but two of her races, summed up yesterday the matter of the filly's tragic end in a conclusion manner. "It's about time we stopped talking about it," he said. "It was just a freak accident, and nothing else, not even pigeons had anything to do with it."

ALBANY, July 10 The Assembly late today passed a series of comprehensive bills designed to end widespread abuses in the nursing home industry, including neglect and mistreatment of the elderly and mismanagement and misappropriation of millions of dollars in Medicaid funds.

Burns, told him that all the signs pointed to an economic recovery soon on the other side of the Atlantic.

Willie Stargell of Pittsburgh hit his 15th home run of the season last night in Three Rivers Stadium, a tworun blow in the eighth in ning that gave the Pirates a 4-1 victory over the faltering Los Angeles Dodgers.

Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that its 21member board of governors had voted unanimously that a merger of the Amex and the New York Stock Exchange was not in the public interest.

ARLINGTON, Wash., July 10 O.C. Helton, 39 years old, of nearby Darrington, has won a court battle that may enable him to finish the log cabin that he is building with the technique taught to him by his grandfather.

WASHINGTON, July 10 The Senate, failing for the sixth time to shut off debate on the disputed New Hampshire Senate election, decided today to shift its attention to other legislation, such as a series of energy bills the Democrats want to pass before Congress starts a one-month recess Aug. 1.

BRIDGETON, July 10 (UPI) Funeral services were scheduled for tomorrow at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church for Joseph H. Garwood, managing editor of The Bridgeton Evening News, whose body was found in Delaware Bay six days after his fishing boat capsized in a sudden squall. He was 58 years old.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) The dollar and the British pound rose sharply today against the joint European currency float on the first day it was exparaded to include the French franc.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) John R. Bartels Jr., who was dismissed as head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, testified today that he believed his two main accusers made charges against him to conceal their own shortcomings.

Victor Borella, the chief labor consultant to Vice President Rockefeller and a longtime aide of the former New York Governor, died of heart failure Wednesday night at Mary Hitchcock Hospital in Hanover, N.H. He was 68 years old and lived in semi-retirement on a farm near Enfield, N.H.

WASHINGTON, July 10 The House Rules Committee moved today to abolish the strife-ridden House Select Committee on Intelligence and to replace it with a larger, newly constituted panel that would retain the same authority.

ALBANY, July 10 The Legislature today voted final approval of a statewide ban on pay toilets, a public facility assailed by feminists as a humiliation and denounced by male legislators as an inconvenience.
The Yankees didn't have as much success with lightning last night as Ben Franklin and Dr. Frankenstein (young and old) had in days gone by.

TAPHANK, L.I, July 10 Ronald J. Parr, the developer of the controversial, $22-million Suffolk Meadows quarter-horse race track, has concluded an agreement with his associates under which they will discontinue their association with the track and drop litigation against him in exchange for more than $1-million in compensation.

Patricia Louise Barker, daughter of Lieut. Col. Herbert R. Barker, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Barker of El Paso, Tex., was married yesterday at noon to peter Powers Goodman of Las Cruces, N.M., son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren H. Goodman of Ossining, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, July 10 A Senate subcommittee has turned down the private appeals of William P. Rogers, former Secretary of State and Attorney General, for a delay in furnishing the Senators with information that he has reportedly described as having the potential to ruin the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

Two of the nation's largest banking concerns Citicorp and the Chemical New York Corporation yesterday reported sharp gains in their second quarter and first half earnings. Both made substantial charges to earnings by additions to their loan loss reserves.

Fran ois Rossi the reputed kingpin of the "Latin-American connection" in heroin, was held in record bail yesterday $5million following the opening of his sealed indictment on a charge of smuggling into this country more than $1.5-billion worth of heroin during an eightyear period.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 10-The MarbleheadHalifax yachting event, one of the slower ocean races within recent memory, continued today with more fog than ever and not much wind. By midafternoon only half the fleet of 102 starters had completed the 360-mile passage, which began last Sunday, but all six class winners and the over-all victor had been determined.

TRENTON, July 10 Two unions representing more than 75 per cent of the state's employes today attacked the layoffs being announced by the Byrne administration to balance the state budget, and said they were prepared to call strikes.

Stans, who was finance chairman of the Nixon campaign, and Kenneth W. Parkinson, who was a lawyer for the Committee for the Re-Election of the President.

Faced with drastic cuts in state aid and services, the New Jersey Legislature appears finally to be headed for action on new taxes to help balance Gov. Brendan T. Byrne's tight austerity budget but not on the tax reforms that the Governor has been demanding.
BRUSSELS, July 10 (AP) Achille van Acker, former So cialist Premier of Belgium, died at his home in Bruges today. He was 77 years old.

More than 225 Roosevelt Hospital workers marched yesterday in the third day of protests over budget cuts that hospital officials have said will result in a loss of 215 jobs.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has started negotiations for another major grain purchase from the United States, and it could total 10 million metric tons, a senior agriculture department official said today.

KESHENA, Wis., July 10 The Alexian Brothers, a small Roman Catholic religious order, told the Menominee Indian tribe here today that it was canceling its agreement to give the Indians a huge monastery near their reservation.

Starting next Tuesday, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be closed to the public two days a week. The additional shutdown, which adds Tuesdays and Tuesday evenings to the regular Monday closings, is a result of the city's fiscal plight, which has caused a 20 per cent reduction in the museum's security force, the Metropolitan says.

GROTON, Conn., July 10 The largest strike to hit Connecticut in 15 years has idled 10,000 skilled shipbuilders and threatened 7,000 or more other workers with layoffs. WASHINGTON, July 10 President Ford summoned the chairmen of the Federal regulatory agencies to the White House today and, in the name of "maximum freedom for private enterprise," asked them to dispense with as much regulation as possible.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a decline of 14.2 per cent in second-quarter net income as sales dipped by 5.6 per cent. The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday earnings declines of more than 20 per cent in both the second quarter and first half despite higher sales in both periods.

A former Navy pilot made an emergency landing on a West Side pier yesterday after a cylinder exploded in his single-engine Stinson 108 airplane. The pilot, H. Lewis Merton, 56 years old, his daughter, Holly, 16, their cat, Mozart, and their dogs, Little Pete and Rembrandt, were uninjured.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10 King Hussein of Jordan said today that he was buying sophisticated American weapons for his armed forces to defend Syria against any flanking attack by Israel through Jordanian territory.

WASHINGTON, July 14 President Ford announced today a plan to remove gradually all price controls on domestic oil over a 30-month period. He said it was a "reasonable compromise" that would stimulate production of oil in this country.

Forrest David Mathews must be a very brave man. At the relatively tender age of 39, he is about to end his career as president of the University of Alabama to wrestle with the jungle of very thorny problems that beset the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
NEW DELHI, July 14 They Supreme Court of India today set Aug. 11 for the start of the appeal in the electoral corruption case against Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

I was at the Squibb building fire in New York last Friday. Luckily I was on a lower floor and despite an appalling absence of a fire alarm or of any clear signs indicating how to evacuate the building escaped safely. (Not without a moment of near panic on smoke-filled fire stairs when someone yelled that the exits were locked. I did what you are supposed not to do, dove into an elevator.)

Philip Morris, Inc., the nation's second largest cigarette company after Reynolds Industries, reported yesterday record earnings and revenues for the quarter and six months ended June 30. The rise reflected increases in the company's tobacco and Miller Brewing operations.
The second-quarter, surge in earnings reported by the nation's banks continued yesterday, with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Charter New York Corporation announcing strong gains.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 (UPI) Public disclosure last year of the police department's socalled Alpha file a list of alleged dangerous black juveniles has led to virtual abandonment of the program, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Selective Service System, sharply reduced in size, is busy planning its new method of registering men for the stand-by draft. The new method is a one-day affair each year for men who turned 18 years old the previous year.

MOSCOW, July 14 Top officials of the Soviet Soyuz space program confidently asserted today that they were ready to loft a two-man crew into orbit tomorrow on a historic space rendezvous with an American Apollo spaceship.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -Nine states charged today that President Ford had abused his power in imposing a $2-a-barrel fee on imported oil.

The Koppers Company, Inc., a Pittsburgh-based manufacturer of tar and asphalt products, coke, machine parts, forest products and plastics, said yesterday that it planned to acquire Sprout, Waldron Co. of Muncy, Pa., for 214,176 shares of Koppers common stock worth about $14.8-million.

There it is, bravely rippling in a breeze or hanging with simple dignity in the summer heat a big red banner proclaiming WOMANBOOKS. And it's a good thing the banner is there because a surprising number of wouldbe customers of this new feminist shop, at 255 West 92d Street, arrive in the neighborhood, look around a bit, and then from a telephone booth call and say, "Where are you?"

WASHINGTON, July 14 Clarence M. Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, acknowledged today that during the post-World War II period, F.B.I. agents had committed break-ins and burglaries to secure "information relative to the security of the nation."

HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 15 (Agence France-Presse) More than 125,000 people have left Saigon for a new life on the land in a provincial center, Vietnamese Communist press and broadcast media reported today.

A Philadelphia law firm being investigated for alleged criminal wrongdoing in connection with the National Maritime Union was ordered yesterday to turn over extensive records to a Federal grand jury in Newark.
What do Frenchmen, who number 40,000 here, do when they are away from home and it is le Quatorze Juillet Bastille Day their Day of Independence?

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14 (UPI) Carol Mann carded par today for the last four holes of a round that had begun yesterday and won the $65,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Columbus Open with a seven under-par 209.

ITHACA, N.Y. Visit exotic Cornell University, Canoe Cayuga's waters. Hike Cascadilla Gorge. See the famous college cow with the porthole in its stomach. Hear moog synthesizers, pileated woodpeckers, learned professors. Eat cafeteria food. Sleep in dormitory beds. Or sit up all night debating things cosmic. . .

WASHINGTON, July 14 Congressional Democrats reacted sharply, and negatively today to President Ford's proposal to lift price controls on oil and moved ahead with plans to act this week on legislation that puts Congress on a collision course with the President over energy policy.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) A group of former convicts has persuaded the District of Columbia police department to let them establish a security agency in the nation's capital.
MILWAUKEE, July 14 Following are excerpts from a speech by Secretary of State Kissinger, as prepared for delivery tonight before the Institute of World Affairs here:
What do Frenchmen, who number 40,000 here, do when they are away from home and it is le Quatorze Juillet Bastille Day their Day of Independence?
Dr. Judith Graham Pool, professor of medicine at the Stanford University School of Medicine, died Sunday at Stanford University Hospital after an illness of several months. She was 56 years old.
CHICAGO, July 14 (UPI) The King Korn Trading Stamp Company filed today a voluntary petition in Federal District Court for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
Despite reports of the turnaround in the economy, steel production continued its decline in the week ended July 12, according to figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
WASHINGTON, July 14 Total business inventories were reduced by a record total of $3-billion in May, twice as much as in April, the Commerce Department reported today.
TRENTON, July 14 (UPI) Citing the "sharp impact of inflation," 250 auto insurers writing policies in New Jersey asked today for a 34.1 per cent increase in their rates.

Grain and soybean prices swung over a wide range yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade before closing lower Wheat futures lost from 6 to 19 cents, corn was off 3 to 5 and soybeans were down 11 to 13 cents from Friday's closing prices.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 14 The American astronauts, spacecraft and rockets were ready tonight for the scheduled launching tomorrow of the first international manned space mission, the planned rendezvous flight between Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft.

WASHINGTON, July 14 President Ford announced today a plan to remove gradually all price controls on domestic oil over a 30-month period. He said it was a "reasonable compromise" that would stimulate production of oil in this country.

WASHINGTON, July l4 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will limit its investigation of covert activities by the Central Intelligence Agency to a "half-dozen or so representative cases," including the intervention in Chile, the committee chairman said today.
In the night skies of midsummer, it may be hard to find familiar groups at first sight.

Sporadic but heavy rains struck the sodden metropolitan area again yesterday, sending rivers and streams over their banks, flooding highways and some homes in outlying sections and causing millions of dollars of crop damage in New Jersey.

The owners of two privately owned facilities housing nearly 275 elderly people have filed petitions for bankruptcy in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, contending tha they could not continue to operate under the present rate of reimbursement.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 14 Eugene R. Kelley, the Suffolk Police Commissioner, filed a $20-million lawsuit today against the county's District Attorney and the chief assistant prosecutor, charging them with "libel and slander" for announcing that he was being investigated for "corruption, misconduct in office and other, more serious crimes."
The Jets open training camp today, which is obviously why Joe Namath will be at the Four Seasons restaurant.
HELENA, Mont., July 14 A man found guilty of falsifying forms of the Montana Workmen's Compensation Division was given the maximum sen tence of 14 years in prison today.
TEL AVIV, July 14 Israelis resentful of American pressure for an Israeli pullback in occupied Sinai stoned the United States Embassy here tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama raised $1.3-million more for his undeclared Presidential campaign in the last four months, increasing his fundraising lead over the wide field of 1976 candidates.

"Massage parlors," peep shows, so-called adult bookstores and hotels in the Times Square area suspected of catering to prostitutes will be visited starting next September by a special team of city inspectors searching for violations that might close them, under a grant announced yesterday by Governor Carey.

The French have picked up more fashion ideas from us than simply blue jeans. One is the whole concept of resort clothes. That is, sun clothes to be sold in the middle of the winter and worn by women who live in warm climates or are fortunate enough to travel there when snow is on the ground.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 14 Mrs. Alexander Munro Innis Arden won the medal by two strokes today in the annual Women's Tri-County golf championship at the Scarsdale County Club. She carded a 42-39 81 in the round played in intermittent heavy rain.
TEL AVIV, July 14 Israelis resentful of American pressure for an Israeli pullback in occupied Sinai stoned the United States Embassy here tonight.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 14 Dozens of recent Cambodian refugees, some of whom escaped from the country as late as last Tuesday, are telling of a nation in a state of total revolutionary upheaval that is rapidly returning to its undeveloped past of a century ago.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 14 Danny (Lightning) Buggs, who has succeeded Henry Carr and Rocky Thompson as the new speed king of the football Giants, does not intend to waste his time or talent running up and down in front of the bench this season.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it had turned down a petition for a ban on aerosol sprays, which critics contend may be destroying portions of they earth's atmosphere.
WASHINGTON, July 14 A House subcommittee agreed today not to delete three school sex discrimination rules from the regulations that are scheduled to become law next week.
The RCA Corporation reported yesterday sizable declines in earnings for both the second quarter and first half despite slightly higher sales in both periods.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, West Germany On July 2, 1900, a strange cigar-shaped object, designed by a local eccentric named Count Ferdinand Zeppelin, emerged from a floating wooden shed on Lake Constance near here and sailed into the air, silhouetted by the Thurgau Alps rising from the far shore.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 14 (AP) Members of the ruling Labor party voted 55 to 33 in Parliament today to approve the dismissal by Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam of his Deputy Prime Minister and Environment Minister, James F. Cairns Mr. Whitlam ousted Mr. Cairns on July 2 because of charges of improprieties in the raising of foreign loans.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 Secretary of State Kissinger warned the third world majority of the United Nations today that its "arbitrary tactics" in the General Assembly were alienating the support of the American people for the world organization.

Zutty Singleton, one of the most celebrated jazz drummers to come out of New Orleans, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He had suffered a stroke several years ago. He was 77 years old and lived at the Woodward Hotel, Broadway and 55th Street.

HONG KONG, July 14 Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's nominal head of state, has told diplomats in North Korea where he is staying that he plans to return to Phnom Penh soon, knowledgeable sources said today.

JACKSON, Miss., July 14 (AP) Dr. Laurence C. Jones, who founded the Piney Woods School near Braxton in 1909 and dedicated his life to helping educate young blacks, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 92 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The European security conference, now heading toward a conclusion in Helsinki, Finland, is designed to document the intention of the 35-participating countries to live in peace and a spirit of cooperation.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 14 The United States is hoping to reach agreement with the major oil-producing countries by next month on the holding of an international conference on energy and raw materials.
FALLBROOK, Calif. Harry Parker isn't quite sure what presents the greatest threat to his avocado grove a root disease that has killed off some of his neighbors' trees or people blight.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The Justice Department has broadened its response to requests from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence for classified F.B.I. documents, following an assertion by Senator Frank Church, the committee's chairman, that the department's sluggishness had "severely hampered" the committee's work.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif. (AP)? Consumers have been warned by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission that high pressure airless paint spray guns may be hazardous under certain conditions.

RENO, July 14 (UPI) Former United States Representative Walter S. Baring, who served a record 20 years as Nevada's lone Congressman, waging war against the New Frontier and Great Society programs, died yesterday at Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital of cardiac pulmonary complications. He was 63 years old.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 14 The 16-ton Apollo spacecraft scheduled to rendezvous Thursday with a 7.5-ton Soviet Soyuz is virtually identical with the 14 previous Apollos that astronauts flew around the earth and the moon starting in 1968.

Some of the major provisions of the state's Fair Campaign Code were declared unconstitutional here yesterday by a special Federal court that assailed the restrictions on election campaigning as "repugnant to the right of freedom of speech."
LOS ANGELES, July 14 Things are not so good for the two baseball teams here right now but then, they are not so bad, either.

CLEVELAND, July 14 (UPI) Capt. John Martin, the commander of a group of Ohio National Guardsmen who fired into a group of student antiwar demonstrators at Kent State University on May 4, 1970, testified today that he "saw no reason to fire" during the demonstration.

TRENTON, July 14 Two dozen representatives of commuter groups and transportation unions, faced with the possibility of drastic cutbacks in bus and railroad subsidies beginning midnight Sunday, denounced the state's cutback plan at a public hearing today in the State House complex.

GENEVA, July 14 After nearly two years of negotiations, the 35 countries attending the European security conference decided today that they could set July 30 as the target date for a meeting to sign a charter on East-West relations.

KESHENA, Wis., July 14 (UPI) Two suspected arson fires caused $100,000 damage in neighboring Shawano County today and appeared to be connected with violence that started last week, Menominee County Sheriff Kenneth Fish said.
Despite mixed economic news, stock prices struggled ahead yesterday in moderate trading.

WOLF ISLAND, St. Lawrence River, Canada Although my companions had warned me that the smallmouth bass of the St. Lawrence River would probably not take a surface lure at this time of year, I stuck with a flyrod popping bug to the point of absurdity. Meanwhile, they hauled in enough bass for a noon fish fry put on by our skipper, James Brabant of Clayton, N.Y., on the north end of Wolf Island.
PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP) One youth was shot to death and four others beaten today in apparent racial fighting in the city's Beltzhoover section, the police said.
Television coverage of the Soviet-American space missions is scheduled to begin today with live views of the Soyuz launching from the Soviet Union, set for 8:20 A.M,, Eastern daylight time.
Forego of the Lazy F Ranch, the horse of the year for 1974, was assigned high weight of 134 pounds yesterday for Saturday's $100,000 added Suburban at Belmont Park.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 14 Defense attorneys for Joan Little made clear as her trial opened today that they were putting the Southern system of justice on trial as much as they were defending a young black woman accused of first-degree murder.

CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -Phil Dent of Australia moved into the second round of the $50,000 Chicago international tennis tournament tonight by defeating Dick Dell, 5-7, 6-2, 6-1. Dick Stockton breezed past Syd Ball of Australia, 6-1, 6-1.

St. Elizabeth's Memorial Episcopal Chapel in Tuxedo, N.Y., was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Madeline Hellum Mihok, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Hellum of Tuxedo, to L. Gordon Hamersley Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Alfred J. Miller.

Investigators who have already found widespread abuses in the nursing-home industry are beginning to find evidence of apparent fraud in some storefront offices, often called "Medicaid mills,"where groups of doctors treat patients whose bills are paid for by the Government.
WASHINGTON, July 14(AP) A Ford Administration proposal to grant regular trade terms to Rumania was approved 24 to 3 today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

TRENTON, July 14 Governor Byrne's chief counsel, Lewis B. Kaden, said today that he did not pay a special New Jersey commuters tax last year even though he lives in New York and works in New Jersey, and conceded that this had raised a number of questions concerning his residence and its effect on his state tax liability here.

HAMILTON, Ohio, July 14 (UPI) James Ruppert, convicted of killing 11 of his relatives the largest mass murder of members of one family in United States history was sentenced today to 11 consecutive terms of life in prison.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 14 (UPI) Ethiopia's military rulers have announced the formation of a political party "guided by the aims of Ethiopian socialism" to govern the country.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 14 Apollo-Soyuz, the first international space flight, will inaugurate a new etiquette among astronauts: Speak in the listener's tongue.
TRENTON, July 14 (UPI) The State Senate passed a "sunshine" bill today requiring governing bodies at all levels to open their meetings to the public.
VIENNA Occasionally, at the end of a concert, Karl B hm will turn and announce the Austrian national anthem.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) An Agriculture Department spokesman told Congress today the Administration saw no need for a revival of the Government's sugar-control program.

HARRISBURG, July 14 (AP) A Commonwealth Court judge refused today to order striking unemployment office personnel, back to work, ruling that their walkout was causing inconvenience and annoyance but not grave danger to the public.

MOSCOW, July 14 Top officials of the Soviet Soyuz space program confidently asserted today that they were ready to loft a two-man crew into-orbit tomorrow on a historic space rendezvous with an American Apollo spaceship.

The political influence of Anthony M. Scotto, the union boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, was demonstrated when a bill introduced at his behest was passed as the final measure of the 1975 State Legislature in Albany.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Declaring that they were "firmly convinced of the innocence" of their executed parents, the sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg filed suit today in an attempt to make public all the Government's files on the celebrated espionage case.

President Ford, who said he felt "about 40," celebrated his 62d birthday yesterday. He began the day with a 35-minute physical examination in his White House study and went on to a surprise party in the East Room.

What do theaters in New York, London, Stratford, Ontario, Washington, Spoleto, Chichester, Stratford, Conn., and Niagara-on-theLake, Ontario, all have in common, apart from higher prices than last year? The answer is a plague of illmeaning, selfish and incompetent amateur photographers.

President Ford, who recently has been making his first official visits to far-off places, became yesterday the first Chief Executive in 38 years to visit the marble headquarters of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington.

Investigators who have already found widespread abuses in the nursing-home industry are beginning to find evidence of apparent fraud in some storefront offices, often called "Medicaid mills," where groups of doctors treat patients whose bills are paid for by the Government.
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 14 (UPI) Pro-Communist Vietnamese students have been trying to persuade refugees here to return to South Vietnam.

Compared with most consumer magazines, which are off in advertising, the socalled city magazines the independent city magazines are doing great. Generally speaking they are up in advertising pages and revenues as well as in circulation.

The third annual World Open tournament, July 2-6 at the Roosevelt Hotel, established a new record of 815 entrants for Swiss system events, thus indicating that the shock of Bobby Fischer's refusal to defend his title and its consequence the decline in player turnouts is at an end.
Investors, given the gains and opportunities that have developed in the stock mar ket, are not exactly falling over themselves to buy Treasury bills these days.
WASHINGTON, July 14 Common Cause, the public interest lobbying group, announced today the resignation of Mitchell Rogovin as general counsel and as chairman of its litigation committee.

The political influence of Anthony M. Scotto, the union boss of the Brooklyn waterfront, was demonstrated when a bill introduced at his behest was passed as the final measure of the 1975 State Legislature in Albany.
NEW DELHI, July 14 (UPI) The Indian Government barred a correspondent of The Financial Times of London from entering the country today as an "undesirable."
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 14 Squalls and postponements marked the first racing today in the Larchmont Junior Regatta.

Some of the major provisions of the state's Fair Campaign Code were declared unconstitutional here yesterday by a special Federal court that assailed the restrictions on election campaigning as "repugnant to the right of freedom of speech."

The owners of two privately owned facilities housing nearly 275 elderly people have filed petitions for bankruptcy in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, contending that they could not continue to operate under the present rate of reimbursement.
CRATER LAKE, Ore., July 14 (UPI) A water-treatment plant on loan from the army tomorrow will begin flushing out a contaminated water system that forced the closing of Crater Lake National Park.

Continuing a widespread upward trend on Wall Street, record profits for the June quarter were reported here yesterday by the parent companies of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis Inc., and E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., both major brokerage houses.
The Soyuz spacecraft that is to be launched today is a modernized version of a standard orbital vehicle that has been the mainstay of the Soviet Union's manned space program since 1967.

MILWAUKEE, July 14 Secretary of State Kissinger warned the third world majority of the United Nations tonight that its "arbitrary tactics" in the General Assembly were alienating the support of the American people for the world organization.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's leading manufacturer of nuclear power plants for the production of electricity, reported yesterday a 75 per cent increase in earnings in the second quarter Compared with the like period a year ago.

LUANDA, Angola, July 14 (UPI) Troops of one Angolan faction drove a rival group from the capital of Angola today as the Portuguese Foreign Minister arrived here in an attempt to prevent full-scale civil war.
The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation is dunning nine unions in an effort to collect more than $4.6-million in services already rendered to their members for about the last year.

Mayor Beame submitted a resolution to the City Council yesterday calling for repeal of the law that limits the oneway fare on the Staten Island ferry to a nickel. The Mayor also was reported seeking funds from state mass-transit operating subsidies as part of a plan to restore full service on the ferry.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July, 14 (Reuters) An American expedition has failed in the first attempt in 13 years to climb K-2, the world's second highest, mountain, according to a message received today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The director of the United States disarmament agency is pressing Congress to make it a crime to divulge or publish secret information on how this country monitors Soviet military developments.

The extensive concept of a new West Side Highway, 39 months in preparation by a select planning group, has become pockmarked by legal, financial and environmental pitfalls that threaten to cancel or delay it interminably.

Henri Richard, a veteran of 20 National Hockey League campaigns with the Montreal Canadiens, announced his retirement yesterday. The 39-year-old center, who performed on a record total of 11 Stanley Cup championship teams, missed most of last season because of a broken ankle.

ELIZABETH, July 14 The Hispanic American Committee of Elizabeth said it had canceled a demonstration scheduled for today against the administration of Mayor Thomas G. Dunn because of an appeal by a local newspaper for moderation through July 21, the end of a previously set coolingoff period.

The days of heavy rain are causing more sneezing in New York, not because of colds or hay fever, but because of molds, according to an allergy expert at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 14 (AP) The Laotian Government ordered armed Pathet Lao guards out of a United States warehouse today after an informal meeting at the Foreign Ministry between American and Laotian officials, a United States spokesman said.

MOSCOW, July 14 With a flourish of publicity previously unknown in this country before a space mission, the Soviet Union discarded, temporarily at least, its policy of prelaunching secrecy. In the past, the public and the world have never been told when this country would launch a space vehicle, manned or unmanned.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission proposed today regulations designed to improve service on interstate buses.

More than 100,000 city employes stayed at their jobs until 5 P.M. yesterday after their union leadership agreed not to defy Mayor Beame's order canceling the 9 A.M.-to-4 P.M, summer work schedules. The issue will be submitted to binding arbitration, under an agreement reached yesterday.
Judge Thomas W. Swan, who retired in 1953 as Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit here, died at his home in New Haven. He was 98 years old.
FALLBROOK, Calif. Harry Parker isn't quite sure what presents the greatest threat to his avocado grove a root disease that has killed off some of his neighbors' trees or people blight.

In their liftoff into the space of a 12 -game lead in the National League West, the Cincinnati Reds are surprising even themselves. After the four-game sweep of the New York Mets last weekend, Pete Rose shook his head.

The Reynolds Metals Company reported yesterday declines of 66.2 per cent and 52.5 per cent in earnings for the second quarter and first half respectively. Sales in both periods fell by more than 17 per cent.

DURHAM, N.C., July 14 (AP) Filbert Bayi of Tanzania won't compete for PanAfrica this weekend during the United States-Pan AfricaWest Germany track meet, the meet coordinator, Leroy Walker, said today.

CHICAGO, July 14 The Federal Housing Administration's program of low-cost mortgages for low-income and moderateincome families was denounced at a Congressional hearing today by critics who charged that it provided lucrative financial windfalls for private mortgage, concerns while contributing to the creation of urban slums.

The $86,000 payment earmarked for the Italian Communist party by the Exxon Corporation's Italian affiliate was to have gone to the party through a Communist newspaper or front organization, according to authoritative sources.

Reversing an early trend, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed higher yesterday in slightly decreased trading. Prices also closed higher in the over-the-counter market as volume also fell slightly.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 14 Dozens of recent Cambodian refugees, some of whom escaped from the country as late as last Tuesday, are telling of a nation in a state of total revolutionary upheaval that is rapidly returning to its undeveloped past of a century ago.

JACKSON, Miss, July 14 (UPI) Frank Hains, 49 years old, arts editor of The Jackson Daily News, was found dead in his apartment early today, the victim of a crushing blow to the head. He had been bound and gagged. Mr. Hains wrote an entertainment column, "On Stage." Before coming to Jackson, he worked a number of years in radio and at newspapers in Vicksburg.

TEL AVIV, July 14 (Reuters) -Secretary of State Kissinger has assured Premier Yitzhak Rabin of $1.8-billion in aid if Israel reaches an interim agreement with Egypt, an Israeli newspaper reported today.
A possible trade involving Dave Bing, Norm Van Lier and Kevin Porter was the most interesting report yesterday as a number of outstanding players turned out
MILWAUKEE, July 14 The American League, which hasn't done too well with its All-Star bats in the last 15 years, will try to win tomorrow night's game with philosophy.

TRENTON, July 14 Governor Byrne's chief counsel, Lewis B. Kaden, said today that he did not pay a special New Jersey commuters tax last year even though he lives in New York and works in New Jersey, and conceded that this had raised a number of questions concerning his residence and its effect on his state tax liability here.

GENEVA, July 14 After nearly two years of negotiations, the 35 countries attending the European security conference decided today that they could set July 30 as the target date for a meeting to sign a charter on East-West relations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (UPI) As part of a campaign to establish security, military authorities have promised amnesty to soldiers of the defeated South Vietnamese Army who turn themselves in now, even though the deadline has long passed, but have warned that anyone who opposes the new Government will be "severely punished."

Tennessee Williams's "The Red Devil Battery Sign" opened June 18 at the Shubert Theater in Boston and closed 10 days later. Thirty-five years ago, Mr. Williams's "Battle of Angels" also opened and closed, prematurely, in Boston.

Kialoa, the new 79-foot ketch from Los Angeles, finished the trans Atlantic yacht race yesterday at the Nab Tower off England's Isle of Wight. Kialoa took 15 days to complete the passage from Newport, R.I., and apparently was far ahead of the eight competitors remaining in the race.
ALBANY, July 14 Governor Carey today vetoed a bill that would have increased fees paid by shipping companies to pilots in New York Harbor.

Mayor Beame hurriedly submitted resolutions to the City Council last night seeking approval of 4 per cent nuisance taxes" on personal services such as haircuts, laundering, dry cleaning and shoeshines as well as on admissions to entertainment and sporting events.

CAMDEN, July 14 In an apparently unprecedented ruling, Judge Leon A. Wingate, Jr. of Camden County Court told a jury today that fetuses that are "a victim of a criminal blow or wound upon their mother" and later born may be found to be murder victims if they die from the wounds.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 14, (Reuters) North Korea rejected today a South Korean proposal for a reopening of the stalled dialogue between the two Governments about reunification, a South Korean spokesman said.

BARNWELL, S.C., July 14 (AP) A Federal court jury was chosen today for a $1.5-million civil suit brought on behalf of two welfare mothers, one who claims she was sterilized to obtain treatement under the Medicaid program and another who says she was threatened with the operation.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Central Intelligence Agency has told Sen. William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, that prospects are good for a successful Apollo-Soyuz space mission, even though Soviet space technology is inferior to that of the United States.

LISBON, July 14 Leaders of the Popular Democratic party, the second largest electoral force in Portugal, predicted today that a military government, with some civilian economic experts, would be established here by Wednesday night.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 16 The Islamic countries are working with more determination than ever to recover Moslem religious and political rights in Jerusalem as part of a Palestinian state.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 16 When Skip Parmenter's wife checked into the hospital for minor surgery last December, he assumed the operation was covered under his insurance policy with the Philadelphia Bell of the World Football League.
TRENTON, July 16 Governor Byrne presented to the Democratic Assembly majority today lists of budget restorations and nuisance taxes that he would sign if voted by the State Legislature.

BROCKTON, Mass., July 16 (AP) District Court Judge George Hurd ruled today that a man cannot commit the crime of prostitution and found Fred Doane of Brockton not guilty of such a charge.

The City Commission on Human Rights will hold a factfinding hearing next Monday morning to ascertain whether the head of Composition Roofers Local 8 violated antidiscrimination regulations by replacing black and Puerto Rican workers with whites on some union jobs.
Mayor Beame yesterday named Peter F. Tufo, a lawyer and former aide to Mayor Lindsay, as chairman of the city's Board of Correction.

WASHINGTON, July 16 The Defense Department has concluded that the Navy, which was under instructions to come up with a "low-cost fighter," has understated by at least $1.6-billion the long-term cost of its program to build a new carrier plane.
VANCOUVER, British Columbia, July 16 (UPI) Members of two pulp unions went on strike today against 22 mills throughout the province, shutting down a major part of British Columbia's leading industry.

WASHINGTON, July 16 Secretary of State Kissinger acknowledged today that he had advised President Ford not to see Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn because it would have been "disadvantageous", to this country,'s foreign policy presumably its pursuit of detente with the Soviet Union.
The only thing that undermines a negotiating process more than a sense of panic is a sense of complacency. The diplomatic exchanges now going on between Israel and Egypt are threatened by both.

Rod Gilbert, the star right wing of the New York Rangers, signed a multiyear contract with the National Hockey League club yesterday. Emile Francis, the general manager, made the announcement but, as usual, did not disclose the terms of Gilbert's 14th contract.

ALBANY, July 16 Governor Carey said today that the state's budget gap, which he originally estimated at $600million, might be reduced to $300-million by the end of the fiscal year, next April 1, if the economy had a "meteoric and mercurial recovery."
MOSCOW, July 16 (Reuters) The Government-controlled press filled newspapers today with what by Soviet standards were screaming headlines about the Apollo-Soyuz mission.

NEW ORLEANS, July 16 The Porto, the oil tanker that has been the subject of a twomonth dispute here over whether its tanks were clean enough to carry grain, is finally on its way to Egypt with a cargo of American wheat.

CAIRO, July 16 King Khalid of Saudi Arabia arrived in Cairo today for a five-day visit to demonstrate his support for President Anwar el-Sadat at a critical moment in the search for a peace settlement between the Arabs and Israel.
Profit taking sent prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market down yesterday after several sessions of increases.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Kroger Company, the nation's thirdlargest supermarket chain, of advertising products not in stock and charging more than advertised prices.
A new $1,109,969 contract amendment has brought the cost of the Yankee Stadium reconstruction and surrounding projects to $57,088,000.

Anthony Perkins, so often cast as a psychopath, off the coach himself and working as a psychiatrist may seem quite a switch, but that is precisely what is happening at the Plymouth Theater, where Mr. Perkins has taken over the role of the psychiatrist, Martin Dysart, in Peter Shaffer's play "Equus." In another major cast change, the role of the young, disturbed boy is now played by Thomas Hulce.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 16 David Forbes made public for the first time today his version of the blow that floored and injured Henry Boucha in a hockey game and led to a charge of aggravated assault against the Boston Bruin player.
MOSCOW, July 16 The Soyuz 19 spacecraft, on the second day of its historic space flight, successfully maneuvered today into the orbit in which it will await its Apollo partner.

One would assume that the subject would be covered with the utmost care by the press acrd in our universities. Such, unfortunately, is not the case.

WASHINGTON, July 16 Secretary of State Kissinger said today that Egypt's threat not to renew the mandate of the United Nations peace-keeping force in Sinai was "extremely unfortunate" and complicated American efforts to bring about a new Egyptian-Israeli agreement.

UNIONDALE, L.I., July 16 The New York Sets rushed to a commanding lead in the early events and coasted to a 27-17 World Team Tennis victory over the Hawaii Leis tonight before 4,870 in the Nassau Coliseum.
WASHINGTON, July 16 The Soviet Union has agreed to buy 3.2 million metric tons of wheat, or about 117 million bushels, from two major United States corporations.
The Yonkers City Council, after a six-hour meeting that ended early yesterday, adopted a $133.5-million budget for 1975-76 that will increase property taxes by 13.9 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 16 The United States Postal Service and four union bargaining units were locked in virtually roundthe-clock negotiations today, trying to avoid disruptions in mail service next Monday, when the present two-year contract expires.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) White House aides made plans today for a Presidential trip to Europe, probably starting about July 26.

American Airlines, the No. 3 of the domestic trunklines, reported yesterday its net income in June had dropped to $4-million, or 14 gents a share, from $10.5-million, or 37 cents a share, in June of last year.

Richard Conlon, general manager until he retired recently of Gallagher's Steak House, a Times Square gathering place for sporting and theatrical personalities, died yesterday in his home in the Parc Vendome, 340 West 57th Street. He was 60 years old.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has placed a $100-million note issue with the Government of Saudi Arabia, the giant telecommunications company said yesterday.
TOKYO, July 17 Crown Prince Akihito and Princess Michiko of Japan were attacked by two young radicals today on Okinawa, but were unhurt. A policeman suffered minor burns.
State and county mosquitocontrol officials said yesterday that they had become increasingly concerned that the recent drenching rains might help spawn vast swarms of mosquitoes by late next week.
Charles Bertine Collins, a senior partner in the law firm of Carpenter, Bennett Morrissey of Newark, died Wednesday at his home, 20 Woodhill Drive, Maplewood, N.J. He was 70 years old.

ARLINGTON, Tex., July 17 Sparky Lyle made his debut as a "long" relief pitcher tonight much faster than the Yankees would have preferred as the New Yorkers absorbed a 7-2 drubbing from Ferguson Jenkins and the Texas Rangers.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 17 The president of Brown University, Donald F. Hornig, announced his resignation today.

For the ninth consecutive day, the moist tropical air mass stalled over the metropolitan area produced more brief, sporadic downpours and thunder showers yesterday over waterlogged portions of New York City and New Jersey.

Sit-ins, begun earlier this week, continued early today at the Health and Hospitals Corporation offices at 93 Worth Street and at Morrisania Hospital, 168th Street and Gerard Avenue in the Bronx, to protest proposed budget cuts in hospitals services.

Although he gives the impression that even his undershirt is stuffed, Bowie Kuhn deserved to continue as the Commissioner of Baseball more than Charles O. Finley deserved to be hailed as his assassin. In the end, that is why Bowie Kuhn rose from the dead yesterday.

The directors of the Municipal Assistance Corporation told Mayor Beame yesterday that the city must immediately undertake a series of dramatic measures even beyond a wage freeze for city employes to reopen the money-lending market to the city and the corporation.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 17 The jury in the case of the State of Minnesota versus David S. Forbes deliberated almost seven hours today, then retired to a hotel late tonight after reaching an impasse in determining the fate of the Boston Bruins' hockey player. It will reconvene here tomorrow morning.

HOUSTON, July 17 Astronauts of the United States and the Soviet Union united spaceships today and then joined hands in the first international meeting away from earth, a symbolic gesture of the two nations' expressed desire to cooperate in the exploration of space.
Herbert Kaufman, a partner in the law firm of Kaufman Siegel, 10 East 40th Street, died Wednesday evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 975 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 17 Hoping to end the disputes that have stalled its investigation of the Federal intelligence agencies, the House of Representatives took the unusual step today of abolishing its Select Committee on Intelligence and replacing it with a new, larger panel with the same authority.

Charles J. Hynes, a special state prosecutor, announced they indictment and arrest of two nursing-home employes yesterday, one for the alleged abuse of a patient, the other charged with the theft of $46,700 from a nursing home.

MILWAUKEE, July 17 Bowie Kuhn survived the palace revolt and won reelection as commissioner of baseball today when the New York Yankees and Texas Rangers quite the rebels after a night of nonstop counterattacks.

For Muhammad Ali every bout calls for a brand new production number, and the world heavyweight champion was in town yesterday to announce formally his title defense against Joe Frazier on Oct. 1. Ali billed the fight, which could earn him $8-million and Frazier $5-million, as a "killer, of a chiller in a thriller in Manila with the gorilla."
WASHINGTON, July 17 Senator Abraham Ribicoff asked the Internal Revenue Service today to make an immediate investigation of possible tax violations by the American Medical Association.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The nation's total output of goods and services was essentially flat in the second quarter, providing further evidence that the recession has hit bottom, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Senate refused today to go along with House efforts to allow separate physical education classes and professional honorary societies for men and women in federally aided schools at all levels.

A week ago Mayor Beame was assuring his fellow polit ical leaders that the city's "crisis" had lifted, at least for a while. TAMPA, Fla., July 17 (UPI) Government prosecutors rested their bribery-conspiracy case against former Senator Edward J. Gurney of Florida today without calling rebuttal witnesses.
The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday sharply lower net income for the second quarter and first half as sales in both periods fell by more than 14 per cent.
LISBON, July 17 Portugal's rulers cast about today for an effective government following the collapse of the Lisbon coalition early this morning.

A newly released Federal census report shows that the New York State communities with both the highest and the lowest per-capita incomes are suburbs of New York City. Calculations from the census data, compiled for Federal revenue-sharing allocations, indicate an average income of $4,248 for state residents during the 1972 calendar year.
The second of New York's three major annual tourna ments begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 Syria has been in close consultation with Egypt since Cairo's threat not to extend the mandate of the United Nations Emergency Force in Sinai beyond July 24, Arab diplomats said here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17 North Vietnam has applied for membership in the United Nations, two days after South Vietnam requested admission.

The State Board of Elections announced yesterday that it had not found any criminal violations in an upstate Assemblyman's use of a Governor Carey campaign fund to finance underhanded tactics against former Gov. Malcolm Wilson in the 1974 gubernatorial contest.

OPEN HOUSE The time: 2 to 6 P.M. today. The place: The House That Jazz Built, at 1312 Stebbins Avenue (near Jackson Avenue) in the Bronx. The hostess: Maxine Sullivan, who needs no introduction as a durably 'popular balladeer.

Beatrice Hertz Imberman, an English teacher at Stuyvesant High School in the nineteenforties, died yesterday, apparently of a stroke, at Long Island Jewish Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 41 Auerbach Lane, Lawrence, L.I.

Virginia Friedland of Miami Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Maj. Gen. Donald Shelton Dawson, Air Force Reserve, retired, senior partner in the Washington law firm of Dawson, Riddell, Taylor, Davis Holroyd. Judge Edwin S. Malmed of the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Mann of Bryn Mawr, Pa., friends of the couple.
NEW SQUARE, N.Y., July 17 To step into this village, which has only one access road, is to step into the East European villages of the last century.

Milliners, who have been starving through more than a decade of hatlessness, can take heart at the sight of brimmed straws sailing around New York. But they should be cautious about embarking on the expensive confections they sold in the nineteen-fifties.

WASHINGTON, July 17 Ambassador Simcha Dinitz of Israel today gave Secretary of State Kissinger the latest Israeli proposals for breaking the deadlocked talks with Egypt on a new Sinai agreement. Americans and Israelis said later that "progress" had been made toward an accord.

Succumbing to a bombardment of false propaganda, the Interior Committee of the House of Representatives has defeated by four votes a modest bill calling for land-use planning. Three, Democrats, Representatives Melcher of Montana, Howe of Utah and Taylor of North Carolina, turned against the measure after, having previously given it their support.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The State Department has informed Congress that the Administration deliberately chose not to approach the Soviet Union on possible naval-arms limitations in the Indian Ocean before deciding to proceed with con struction of a naval base on the island of Diego Garcia.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, which led last month's "Fear City" campaign, has resumed distributing leaflets warning that the city is unsafe because of the dismissal of 3,000 police officers.
The city's Department of Buildings, with 45 of its 270 inspectors and 15 other employes charged with graft, is planning to seek authoriaztion to give builders the option to hire their own inspectors.
The Humanitas Prizes, created last year to improve the moral tone of network television, were won today by David Seltzer and Joel Olianski.

Mayor Beame said late yesterday that 1,434 sanitationmen would be dismissed this afternoon, and that 750 others would have to be laid off at the end of the month because the unusual $1.6-million fund pledged by their union to pay their wages was running out.

WASHINGTON, July 17 Postmaster General Benjamin F. Bailar disclosed late today that 85 postcards and 25 letters intercepted more than three years ago by the Central Intelligence Agency had just been found on a shelf at an agency office.
Col. Sol P. Fink, U.S.A., retired, a veteran of four wars and a former New York stockbroker, died yesterday in Lawrence (Mass.) General Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in North Andover, Mass.

Paul M. Lund, a vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in charge of public relations and employe information since June, 1971, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Ridgewood, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The staff of the Rockefeller commission concluded that the chief of the Central Intelligence Agency's testing of LSD destroyed the drug program's records in 1973 to hide the details of possibly illegal actions, commission sources said today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Commissioner, Donald Alexander, said today 111 American corporations are under investigation for alleged illegal domestic and foreign political contributions.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange were pushed lower yesterday, largely by the weight of uncertainty over the future course of credit rates.
The city's Department of Buildings, with 45 of its 270 inspectors and 15 other employes charged with graft, is planning to seek authorization to give builders the option to hire their own inspectors.

OTTAWA, July 17 The Soviet Union has purchased two million metric tons of high grade wheat from Canada for delivery in the fall, the Canadian Wheat Board announced today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 17 Four British soldiers were killed today by a bomb hidden in a milk can near the border with the Irish Republic.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 17 Thailand said today that China had agreed to buy 200,000 tons of Thai rice in what was clearly a move to cement economic relations between the two countries.
RALEIGH, N.C., July 17 Two more jurors were selected in the murder trial of Joan Little today, bringing the total to six.

Improved weather found anglers moving in boats and along the beaches in much greater number yesterday. Similarly, fish again began showing greater interest in shopping. Blues, weaks, porgies and sea bass were reported in worthwhile quantities frequenting their favorite haunts.

Periodically, samples are taken of what passes for water off our beaches to decide where bathers can swim uncontaminated. On the same theory, this column proposes to sample the top 10 pop singles periodically, in order to ascertain if there's anything out there on the airwaves worth listening to. The water has reportedly improved; maybe the music has, as well.

WASHINGTON, July 17 Senator Jacob K. Javits today reprimanded Dr. F. David Mathews, President Ford's nominee for Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, for the statements of Dr. Mathews earlier this week on school busing.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 17 Security Council members began private consultations today seeking a formula that would persuade Egypt to agree to extend the mandate of the United Nations peace force in Sinai. After an hour-long meeting, they agreed to meet tomorrow.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., July 17 Judy Rankin, an established golf professional who began her career by winning pee-wee tournaments at the age of 8, led the opening round of the United States Women's Open Championship today, but the star of the afternoon was an 18year-old amateur who trailed by only one stroke.
A United Air Lines DC-8 jet carrying 142 Asian exchange students on a charter flight from Bangkok to the United States was ordered by Philippines authorities to land in Manila late Wednesday.

TRENTON, July 17 The State Assembly appeared today to be undecided on how to go about restoring tomorrow the budget cuts made by Governor Byrne. Assemblymen have filed 13 tax bills and one supplemental appropriation bill for possible votes.
NEW ORLEANS, July 17 (AP) Blacks who lost their jobs in the current recession because they had low seniority have not been discriminated against a Federal appeals court has ruled.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Contract talks between the railroads and the railway clerks union broke down today and the union called for a strike July 28.

Seaboard Coast Line Industries, Inc., parent of the railroad of similar name, as well as of the Louisville Nashville Railroad and several other Southeast carriers, reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in the second quarter fell to $6.3-million, or 44 cents a share, after a tax credit of $1.7-million. F. Edwin Church, an artist and a founder of the North Shore Wildlife Sanctuary, died Tuesday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 98 years old and had lived here and in Locust Valley for the last 45 years.

TRENTON, July 17 Bondissue funds totaling $137.5-million will become available for water-pollution control and water-supply projects in New Jersey as a result of legislation signed into law today by Governor Byrne.

Dr. Fred S. Ikle, the director of the United States Disarmament Agency, is a Government official who wants to muzzle the press. So what else is new? Only that unlike most of his peers, Dr. Ikle just may have a point; in any case his concern precisely illustrates the difficulties that can arise in an open society with a free press and those that would result from legislation limiting that freedom.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The House passed today by a vote of 393 to 18 a $7.5-billion measure to fund the Treasury, White House and other agencies and cutting requests for funds for former President Richard M. Nixon's staff by $81,848.
BRUSSELS, July 17 Leaders of the nine European Common Market countries decided today to seek American and Japanese help in dealing with what they described as the internal tional, monetary disorder.

The Sucrest Corporation, a leading sugar refiner, increased its industrial sugar prices yesterday by 61 cents per hundred pounds, continuing a trend of higher prices in both grocery and industrial sugar in the last 10 days.
SUTTON, Mass., July 17 (AP) Rod Curl, on the comeback trail, shot a five-underpar 66 today and took a onestroke lead in the first round of the $200,000 Pleasant Valley Golf Classic.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 17 (UPI) The Communist-dominated Laotian Government took its first major step against the foreign press today, banning a Thai newspaper and setting up stiffer entrance requirements for newsmen.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. Thomas V. Jones, the Northrop Corporation's embattled chief executive officer, said today that he intended to stay "in charge" of the scandal-ridden company "indefinitely" despite a stinging rebuke by the company's executive committee that led to his resignation as chairman yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The Senate Judiciary Committee turned aside attempts today to amend and weaken a bill to extend the Voting Rights Act for 10 years and appeared ready to approve the measure tomorrow.
The state yesterday obtained a temporary restraining order against a strike threatened for next Monday by 115,000 members of the Civil Service Employes Association.

Top officials of the city's Health Department said yesterday that while there still was a fraud in Medicaid they were recouping more mispayments than in the past and that they were doing the best they could with a staff limited by the fiscal crisis.

MOSCOW, July l7 A headyset Russian woman in a beige dress watched the Apollo-Soyuz docking on a color television set in a Gorky Street shop today, blocking with her bulk many of the other would-be viewers, who grumbled and pushed closer.

Judge Jacob Fuchsberg ruled in the New York State Court of Appeals yesterday that the New York Stock Exchange had a right to sue a subsidiary of the Continental Insurance Company for $47.5-million in damages arising from the collapse of the Allied Crude Vegetable Oil Refining Corporation in the salad-oil swindle of 1963.

Henry Glass Munson, a retired Navy captain who had headed the School of Electrical Engineering at the submarine base in Groton, Conn., died of pneumonia Wednesday in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 18 Dodds Lane in Princeton, N.J.

The United Steelworkers of America joined in the petition to the International Trade Commission.
The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday a drop of slightly more than 30 per cent in second-quarter earnings although sales ran 7.7 per cent higher than in the like 1974 period.

Jay B. Leonard is a tall, outgoing man who wears aviator glasses and works as the research specialist covering foods and beverages for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith. When he talks about a food-processing company, he's apt to whip out a package for frozen pizza covered with salami slices.

WASHINGTON, July 17 The income tax checkoff begun two years ago is expected to produce more than $100-million in Federal funds to help to finance the 1976 Presidential election, the chairman of the Federal Election Commission said today.
Herbert Kaufman, a partner in the law firm of Kaufman Siegel, 10 East 40th Street, died Wednesday evening, apparently of a heart attack. He was 74 years old and lived at 975 Park Avenue.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the nation's largest independent telephone system and a major manufacturer of electronic equipment, reported yesterday a decline in earnings of 6.8 per cent in the second quarter and 10.1 per cent for the first half from the records achieved in the 1974 periods.

STOCKTON, July 17 (AP) Rodgers and Hart are long gone from here but the wishing well that inspired their hit song still stands on the grounds of a small hotel-restaurant in this tiny Hunterdon County community.

Hugh Morrow, Vice President Rockefeller's press secretary, yesterday denied a widely published report that Dr. William Ronan was resigning as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to take a high Federal post in Washington.

A 40-year-old Bronx woman was freed from state prison yesterday shortly after four police officers were indicted on charges of illegally obtaining the evidence that led to her arrest on a narcotics violation nearly four years ago.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 17 (UPI) Five timber companies and two executives were found guilty yesterday of violating Federal antitrust laws in bidding on timber in the Willamette National Forest.
TOKYO, July 17 Crown Prince Akihito and Princess Michiko of Japan were attacked by two young radicals today on Okinawa, but were unhurt. A policeman suffered minor burns.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) Richard M. Nixon was ordered today to give testimony before lawyers seeking access to White House papers and tapes accumulated while he was President.

A week ago Mayor Beame was assuring his fellow political leaders that the city's "crisis" had lifted, at least for a while. But within the last 48 hours he has found himself in something approaching a state of siege, faced with demands for drastic steps to bring the city, for the second time in a month, back from the brink of possible default.

DETROIT, July 17 (UPI) The Fruehauf Corporation, one of the world's largest builders of truck trailers and containers, and its two chief officers were found guilty today of conspiring to cheat the Government of $12.3-million in taxes.

The Boston Globe's exclusive rights to syndicated newspaper features have been limited to a six-county area under an agreement approved by a Federal judge Wednesday ending eights years of litigation, United Press International reported.

A former employe of the Central Intelligence Agency said yesterday he believed that a scientist who plunged to his death from a Manhattan hotel window 22 years ago had knowingly participated in a C.I.A. experiment with ISD shortly before.

UAL, Inc., the corporate parent of United Airlines and Western International Hotels, reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income plunged to $5.5-million, or 22 cents a share, from $35-million, or $1.40 a share, a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 17 President Ford, having first avoided a proposed meeting with Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, is now trying to arrange one. But the exiled Soviet author is reportedly insisting on a written invitation to the White House.
The Parking Violations Bureau here has disclosed that the biggest scofflaw in the city is the Federal Government, which is running up unpaid bills estimated at $6-million a year.

Mayor Beame said late yesterday that 1,434 sanitation- men would be dismissed this afternoon, and that 750 others would have to be laid off at the end of the month because the unusual $1.6-million fund pledged by their union to pay their wages was running out.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that business loans at leading New York City banks declined for the second consecutive week, indicating that economic activity remained sluggish despite widespread anticipation of a national recovery.
WASHINGTON, July 17 Cleveland, where Republicans nominated Alfred M. Landon for President in 1936, is now a leading bidder for the G.O.P. converition next year, party sources said today.
PARIS The title of the world chess champion has been usurped to the accompaniment of guilty silence on all sides.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) Acting on complaints of "seriously frightened" listeners, the Fedral Communications Commission sharply admonished today Radio Station WPRO in Providence, R.I. for broadcasting an updated version of the H.G. Wells classic "War of the Worlds."

The Polaroid Corporation lived up to anlysts' forecasts of a turnaround in earnings, as the company reported more than a fivefold gain from a year ago. The company said yesterday that net income in the second quarter rose to $13.4-million, or 41 cents a share, against $2.2-million, or 7 cents a share, in the like 1974 period.

HOUSTON, July 17 Astronauts of the United States and the Soviet Union united spaceships today and then joined hands in the first international meeting away from earth, a symbolic gesture of the two nations' expressed desire to cooperate in the exploration of space.
CAIRO, July 17 Egypt, in the official view, has instilled a new sense of urgency in the search for a Middle East settlement and has closed no doors.

Harald Lander's "Etudes" is a superb example of the good-bad ballet.
