MINEOLA, L.I., July 17 Testimony is expected to be presented to a Nassau County grand jury next week following an investigation into the death of the wife of Dr. Charles Friedgood, a source close to the case said today.
NEW SQUARE, N.Y., July 17 To step into this village, which has only one access road, is to step into the East European villages of the last century.
NEW DELHI, July 16 One rainy August day 26 years ago India's constituent assembly sat in an ornate hall here working over the draft of a federal constitution.

John Stonehouse, fugitive member of the British Parliament, and his secretary, Mrs. Sheila Buckley, left Melbourne, Australia, yesterday under the escort of four Scotland Yard detectives and began the 23-hour flight back to England. There they face criminal charges of theft, fraud and forgery.
Before yesterday morning's meeting at Gracie Mansion, Mayor Beame invited the conferees to have coffee and Danish.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) The United States resettlement program for Asian refugees is being expanded to include Laotians and an additional 7,000 to 9,000 Cambodians and Vietnamese.

Sy Oliver joined the Jimmie Lunceford orchestra in 1933 and, through his arrangements, shaped the distinctive Lunceford sound: crisp, clipped trumpets, smooth, stretched-out saxophones and an easy, propulsive two-beat.
MANILA, July 18 The Philippine Government released early this afternoon a United Air Lines DC-8 charter plane that it grounded for 15 hours for alleged violation of air space.
One pony was found dead and another was ordered shot yesterday at riding stables inside Steeplechase Park in Coney Island that health officials described as filthy and hazardous.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 The New York Sets and the Los Angeles Strings met on a neutral court tonight and the Sets won, 28-20, in World Team Tennis competition. The match drew 3,518 people in Kiel Auditorium.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 18 A mistrial was declared today in the case of Dave Forbes, the Boston Bruins' hockey player, when the jury announced it could not reach a verdict.

DURHAM, N.C., July 18 (AP) Walter Schmidt of West Germany threw the 16pound hammer 249 feet 7 inches today in the United States-Pan African-West Germany track meet. Schmidt's throw is the longest recorded in the Western Hemisphere.
WASHINGTON, July 18 President Ford issued an executive order today that moderates a three-year-old ban on the use of toxic chemicals to kill coyotes and other predators on Federal lands.
BUFFALO, July 18 (AP) The National Gypsum Company said today it would appeal the conviction of the company and two of its executives on charges of conspiring to fix prices.
Robert T. Crane Jr., a former New York lawyer and more recently an associate of the law firm of Truscott Erisman of Philadelphia, died Wednesday at his home in Gladwyne, Pa. His age was 65.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 18 Fifteen of the 24 members of the Organization of American States are prepared to support a resolution lifting the hemisphere grouping's embargo against Cuba, the Foreign Minister of Costa Rica said today.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 18 (AP) Atlantic Richfield has been granted a permit to drill 17 new oil wells in the Santa Barbara Channel, the first new drilling in the waterway since a 1969 oil spill blackened beaches and killed wildlife.

LISBON Portugal's revolution, whose ultimate course remains unclear, was historically both prompted and financed by the right-wing, armysupported dictatorship created by Antonio de Oliveira Salazar. The revolution has so far succeeded only in creating a left-wing military dictatorship.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 A distraught woman tells a radio moderator that every time she hears a car backfire at night she thinks the fighting has started again. "I almost have a nervous breakdown," she says.

TRENTON, July 18 State Transportation Department officials said today that most bus and rail service subsidized by state funds would continue operations through Monday even though the subsidies cut by the Governor have not been fully restored.
LOS ANGELES, July 18 (UPI) Rank-and-file farm workers in California and Arizona today ratified by a 4 to 1 margin a three-year contract with the Western Growers Association.

LISBON, July 18 The aroused people of the little farming town of Rio Maior have driven the Communist party virtually underground, displaying the same reaction to Communist advances that has been noted in Lisbon and other parts of Portugal.

The Apollo and Soyuz spacecraft are scheduled to undock today, redock a second time to test the mechanisms again, and then undock permanently, ending the joint phase of the international space mission.
South Africa, the Davis Cup defender beleaguered in international sports because of her racial policies, was one match away from elimination in the tennis competition yesterday.
Two pop singers appearing in Manhattan clubs both show unusual promise without yet fully realizing that promise.
WASHINGTON, July 18 Not many members of the House of Representatives can claim to have killed a bill on the House floor with a single humorous speech.

Locally, the biggest remaining obstacle to a credible self-help effort is the attitude of municipal employes and their unions. Ignoring fiscal realities, union leaders have stubbornly insisted that their members are entitled not only to job security but to all the extraordinarily generous benefits they have extracted from compliant politicians during more than a decade of municipal mismanagement.
CAIRO, July 18 After the issue of war or peace with Israel, the greatest single problem facing President Anwar elSadat is money.

DAVIS, Calif., July 18 Scientists at the California Primate Research Center here have reported the results of three longterm experiments using monkeys as models in a search for better understanding of human health problems.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 18 Ricky Townsend returned to the New York Giants' training camp tonight, and Pete Athas set up a meeting here tomorrow morning to iron out details on his new contract.

HYANNISPORT, Mass., July 18 An interracial group of children and adults seeking support for a program to get summer vacations for city children of poor families won a sympathetic hearing at the Kennedy compound here.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 18 The Government announced today the discovery of seven bodies, including those of two priests who had been missing since the army clashed last month with 12,000 peasants demanding land.

SAN YSIDRO, Calif., July 18 The bawdy temptations of Tijuana and Mexico's "tourista" border zone were thrown wide open to swarms of vacationing American youths yesterday when a juvenile checkpoint here was closed down after 17 years of operation.

Paul Kolton, chairman of the American Stock Exchange, disclosed in an interview yesterday that the Amex was embarking on-a five-year program to expand its facilities including the possibility of doubledecking its 5 -story trading floor.

PARIS, July 18 For the first time in 27 years, unemployment in France rose instead of falling during the month of June, and now stands at almost 900,000, an estimated 4.5 per cent of the labor force, according to figures made public by the Ministry of Labor.
MOSCOW, July 18 (AP) Svetlana Leonov was sitting tensely in front of the television set, waiting to watch her husband hurtle into space, when the telephone rang.

Brisk selling by farmers of wheat, corn and soybeans to grain elevators and the movement of the commodities into major grain terminals helped depress prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. There was also substantial selling attributed to disappointment over lack of confirmation of further sales of wheat or corn to the Soviet Union.
LISBON, July 18 Portugal's military forces were put on full alert today as the conflict between the Communist Party and its rivals began to move into the streets amid reports of a possible coup.

Garbage pickups will be cut in half in the city's most congested areas and street sweeping on secondary arteries will virtually come to an end as a result of the economy layoff of 1,434 sanitationmen yesterday, Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh said.
TEL AVIV, July 18 The military command said today that Israeli troops had killed three Arab infiltrators from Lebanon, blocking an attempt to seize hostages in the frontier area.

WASHINGTON, July 18 Vincenzo Cazzaniga, a central figure in recent disclosures concerning payments by American oil companies to Italian political parties, said today that "in one way or another" all major industries in Italy, and the American companies in those industries, made political payments.

HOUSTON, July 18 The astronauts of Apollo and Soyuz visited each other's spacecraft twice today, sharing meals and speaking of friendship and further cooperation, and then closed the hatches on the first international meeting in space.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 (Reuters) Brazil's State Railway Board said today that 11 people were killed and 219 injured in last night's train crash in a suburb of this city.

A local sheet-metal workers union was ordered by a Federal judge yesterday to increase the number of nonwhites in the union and its apprentice program from about 4 per cent at present to 29 per cent within six years.

The board of the Association of American Dance Companies whose honorary chairman is Betty Ford, has announced the election of John Gingrich as its president. He will succeed Adam Pinsker, who became president in April, 1970, and has now resigned.

With millions of Americans who never before wielded a hoe now harvesting homegrown foods and canning them for year-round consumption, the nation is experiencing a sudden increase in outbreaks of botulism, a deadly form of food poisoning.

The third quarter-point increase in the prime rate this month by the First National City Bank, the nation's secondlargest bank, took the steam out of yesterday's stock market. The bank raised its prime rate yesterday to 7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Senate Democratic leaders, facing a bitter dispute with Southern legislators, unexpectedly called up the House-passed voting rights bill for action today and immediately filed a petition to shut off any attempt to filibuster it.

Helen Hennessy, women's editor of the Newspaper Enter prise Association, a syndicate serving newspapers throughout the United States and abroad, died of a liver ailment Thursday evening in St. Vincent's Hospital. She waS 59 years old and lived at 77 Seventh Avenue.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) A Senate committee has voted to try one more time to get a strip mine control bill enacted, despite two vetoes of the legislation by President Ford.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., July 18 Nancy Lopez, a plump 18year-old amateur golfer who still is not sure what it's like to choke, and Sandra Post, a veteran of seven years on the professional tour, shared a two-stroke lead today after the second round of the United States Women's Open.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 18 The mystery about the activities of one of Northrop's highly paid European consultants was intensified by a special report filed this week by the company's executive committee with the Securities and Exchange Commission in a Los Angeles Federal court.
Dr. Erik Sjoqvist, the archeologist who discovered the ancient Greek city of Morgantina on a Sicilian mountaintop, died Wednesday in Drottningholm, Sweden. He had marked his 72d birthday Tuesday.
The Tar Beach image is changing in New York, and these days the summer move to the roof has greening more often than tanning as its goal.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 The fourth day of senior racing at Larchmont Race Week drew 119 one-design craft and 60 cruising boats. The winds were light to moderate but the competition was hot enough among the cruising boats to produce three protests.

MOSCOW, July 18 (Reuters) Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, said today that his wife, Yelena, had received permission to go to Italy for treatment of an eye condition she feared could make her blind.
American-based coal companies exported 27.5 per cent more coal from the United States during the first five months of 1975 than during the comparable period last Year.

Mayor Beame proposed yesterday to the city's highest elected officials and its municipal union hierarchy more than $1-billion worth of economy options including a wage freeze, the layoffs of 27,500 additional city workers and a 10 per cent across-the-board salary cut for all city employes as a way to restore the city's credibility nationally and avert insolvency.

WASHINGTON, July 18 The State Department said today that the United States would oppose any revisions in United Nations Security Council resolutions dealing with the Middle East to speed a renewal of the mandate of the United Nations peace-keeping force in Sinai.

Amex International, Ltd., the American Express Company's banking subsidiary in London said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Rothschild International Bank, Ltd., by purchasing all of its issued share capital. The Northwest Energy Company of Salt Lake City raised yesterday its bid for the Apco Oil Corporation to $25 a share for up to 1.5 million shares. It also amended its offer in some other respects.

UNIONDALE, L.I., July 23 The New York Sets defeater the Cleveland Nets, 2521, in World Team Tennis at the Nassau Coliseum tonight before 3,167 fans. Sandy Mayer scored a 6-4 victory over Marty Riessen in the turning point of the match.

We saw the snapping turtle at the beginning of summer. It would appear toward evening, its head sticking out of the water just below the house: a menacing sight, after all we had heard about snapping turtles. They ate baby ducks and were a general menace to wildlife; they could shoot their head out and snap a man's toe in their powerful jaws.

The "reform" faction of the Democratic party; charging that there was "a regular party plot for theft" of New York delegates to the Presidential nominating convention, gave formal notice yesterday of a challenge to the selection rules.

WASHINGTON, July 23-The Senate voted tonight for an amendment that would extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for seven years, instead of the 10-year extension previously approved by the House of Representatives.

MIAMI, July 23 (AP) Representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association voted today to refuse to load American and Canadian grain on ships destined for the Soviet Union. They indicated that the ban would be lifted "if the interests of the American public are adequately protected."

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Internal Revenue Service has withdrawn for reconsideration a ruling it made last month denying tax-deductible status to contributions made to the Bach Mai Emergency Hospital Fund, Inc.
Pressed to pay a municipal debt, New York aucsioned off some of the City Hall furniture. The Mayor was the high bidder.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The Senate leadership has abandoned further efforts until September to break the deadlock over the contested New Hampshire Senate seat.

WHITE PLAINS, July 23 After three months of investigating allegations of misconduct in the Westchester County Sheriff's Department, a county grand jury announced today that no evidence of wrongdoing had been established.

CLEVELAND, July 23 Robert Canterbury, a retired brigadier general of the Ohio National Guard who was the highest ranking officer on the Kent State University campus on May 4, 1970, testified today that he had had no direct responsibility for the weapons used and whether they were loaded at for the tactics of the troops and the methods of dispersing students protesting against the United States invasion of Cambodia.

The White House has responded rather curiously to the charge by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn that President Ford is betraying Eastern Europe by participating in next week's Helsinki summit and signing the so-called European security agreement there. The White House defense is that the document in question "in no way legally settles borders in Eastern Europe." But neither Mr. Solzhenitsyn nor anyone else says that it has.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Senate voted tonight for an amendment that would extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for-seven-years, instead of the 10-year extension previously approved by the House of Representatives.
Those who delight in taking broadbill swordfish on rod and reel never have had an easy time of it, for Xiphias gladius always has been a difficult mark.

The chances of a gasoline shortage in the nation this summer have all but evaporated because of further gains in the production and supplies of the motor fuel in the week ended last Friday, according to weekly industry figures.
Three more of the nation's leading oil companies yesterday reported sharply lower earnings for the three months ended June 30.
CINCINNATI, July 23 Midwestern Governors of both parties called today for the removal of price controls from newly developed natural gas.
Barnard College yesterday named Dr. Leroy C. Breunig, the college's dean of faculty for five years, as its interim president.

POQUONOCK, Conn., July 23 Up and down the Connecticut River Valley this recession summer, the only employment available for thousands of unskilled workers is the hot, sweaty, muddy and low-paying work of tending the shade tobacco fields, an occupation that people here have shunned with determination for decades.
NEW DELHI, July 23 The Government asked the resident correspondent of The New York Times tonight to leave India voluntarily, and it warned that if he refused he would probably be deported.
James A. Healy, a retired stockbroker and collector of Irish art, died Tuesday at his home. He was 84 years old and lived at 350 Central Park West.
ALBANY, July 23 At the end of this Year, 87 solar-heated houses will have been added to the country's housing stock, or about as many as were built in the previous 16 years.

As the world economic slump begins to abate, production and consumption in the world oil trade are for the moment precariously balanced. But there are forces present on both the supply and demand sides that could upset the present equilibrium.

TEL AVIV, July 23 An Israeli leader appealed today to what he described as the "enlightened" members of the United Nations to try to head off any move to suspend Israel from the coming General Assembly session.

A pet wolf named Rocky is being sought by the New Jersey Department of Health to determine whether the animal, which nipped a year-old girl on the cheek last Saturday at a charity softball game, is rabid.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell for the fifth consecutive session yesterday bringing the market index to 92.41, off 1:54. Volume rose to 2.55-million shares from 2.47 million.

Mikhail Botvinnik, world champion off and on from 1948 to 1963, advised that it was a mistake to try to develop an openings repertoire that would be all-inclusive. A few choice openings, certainly not more than three or four, should be studied in depth for each event, but, he thought, to go for greater comprehensiveness would be to invite shallow thinking.
Barnard College yesterday named Dr. Leroy C. Breunig, the college's dean of faculty for five years, as its interim president.
Representatives of 15 major magazines showed up at Doyle Dane Bernbach yesterday morning to hear a pitch for free space from the United Fund of Greater New York.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 After avoiding, it for years, this old city seems finally to have come face to face with the issue of busing, a question that has brought tension and even violence to Boston and other American communities.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Arthur M. Okun, the economist, told Congress today that a much faster economic recovery than the Administration wants would be desirable. He said a faster recovery would present little danger of increased inflation and that it probably cannot be achieved if the Federal Reserve System adheres to its present objectives for monetary Policy.

ATLANTA, July 23 The Atlanta Public Safety Commissioner, A. Reginald Eaves, said today that four city police detectives were continuing their investigation into allegations that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was the victim of a conspiracy rather than of the lone assassin James Earl Ray, Mr. Eaves said he expected a full report by Friday or Monday.
EDISON, N.J., July 23Jack Kiefer didn't realize he had won the New Jersey open golf championship when he dropped his final putt for a bogey 5 on the 72d hole today at the Plainfield Country Club.

CHICAGO, July 23 (Reuters) The Peoples Gas Company said today that its subsidiary, the Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America, had agreed to advance $250-million to the Chevron Oil Company's California Company division for gas development on 38 tracts offshore of Texas and Louisiana.
LONDON Envision the farsightedness and courage of the government of New York City applied to a whole nation: That's the Government of Great Britain.
Dr. Gordon M. Tomkins, a University of California biochemist who pioneered research on hormone activity, died here Tuesday at the age of 49.

No one understands better than Rudolf Nureyev the mystic, fairy-tale quality of the great ballet classics. Not only does his acting and dancing have a bold, emblematic flamboyance he is every inch the Prince but also his productions of such ballets as "The Sleeping Beauty" have a grand simplicity and coherence that enables their legends to leap to life.

Mayor Beame and officials of the Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday set a deadline of midnight next Tuesday for compliance by the city's unions with the fiscal program being advocated to restore the city's credibility and facilitate the sale of the corporation's next billion-dollar bond issue.
It isn't every night that Siegfried's entrance in "Swan Lake" is as eagerly awaited as Odette's, but Tuesday night at the State Theater was that night.

In response to the fiscal distress of museums, the New York State Council on the Arts decided at its monthly meeting yesterday to find additional money for allocation to its museum aid program, which it had earlier trimmed by $2-million. The $2-million cut, made in the visual-arts program, had evoked vociferous expressions of alarm among museum directors, trustees and their supporters.

LONDON, July 23 A small but determined group of militants dealt a blow tonight to the career of one of Prime Minister Harold Wilson's senior ministers and to Mr. Wilson's own efforts to unify his party.

Dr. Edward C. Reifenstein Jr., who was associate medical director of the E.R. Squibb Sons Institute for Medical Research in Princton, N.J., at his retirement in 1973, died yesterday at Chilton Hospital, Pompton Plains, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Kinnelon, N.J.

The Peabody-Thermal Energy Company and a subsidiary of Santa Fe Industries, Inc., said yesterday they had signed a memorandum of intent to sell 86 million tons of coal over a 35-year period to the Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District. The district is a political subdivision of Arizona.

NEW DELHI, July 23 Parliament today completed its ratification of the current state of emergency, under which the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has assumed sweeping powers and arrested thousands of its political opponents.

Pan American World Airways reported yesterday a net loss for June of $4.7-million. The financially pressed company was able to report a net profit of $4-million for the second quarter, or 10 cents a share, but only because of "favorable adjustment" that increased ticket revenue for the period by $28.3-million.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The General Accounting Office recommended today revising the nation's $30.2-billion Federal revenue-sharing program to provide for strict enforcement of antidiscrimination laws and to require local governments to involve their citizens in determining how the funds are to be spent.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 After avoiding it for years, this old city seems finally to have come face to face with the issue of busing, a question that has brought tension and even violence to Boston and other American communities.

At the start of the season the No. 1 man on the California Angels' pitching staff was Nolan Ryan. But that spot has been taken over by Frank Tanana, especially after his 1-0 victory over the Orioles in Baltimore last night.
FORT MONROE, Va. The young Army skin diver climbed out of the murky waters of the moat, cradling a cardboard box as carefully as though it were filled with live ammunition.
Dr. George K. Brazill, a retired dentist, died Tuesday at the Sarah R. Neuman Nursing Home, Mamatoneck, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

Residents of the Crown Heights and Bedford-Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn tossed garbage into the streets in several areas last night in protest at what they said was a lag in collections by sanitationmen.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters) Guillermo Vilas, Arthur Ashe, Ilie Nastase and Roscoe Tanner advanced today in the $100,000 Washington Star International clay-court tennis tournament.

The Taxi and Limousine Commission, under orders from Mayor Beame, yesterday rescinded the permits it had issued to political leaders and other noncommission personnel giving them parking privileges at hundreds of taxi stands around the city.

NEWARK, July 23 (UPI) There will be enough natural gas in New Jersey this winter if temperatures are normal, but customers in the southern part of the state will have to pay higher prices, power company executives said today.

Federal auditors have begun a confidential review of how the city's Addiction Services Agency allocated Government funds here last year following complaints that as much as $500,000 had been improperly withheld from private drug rehabilitation programs.

WASHINGTON, July 23 At the suggestion of the State Department, the Defense Department has delayed plans to remove obsolete nuclear warheads from Italy and Greece.

CHICAGO, July 23 The concrete path in the damp passageway between the visitors' clubhouse and the visitors' dugout in ancient White Sox Park is worn thin from the spike marks of generations of ballplayers.

DALLAS, July 23 The United St ates Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled on a four-year-old appeal in New ed States Court of Appeals court plan for desegregation of Dallas schools was inadequate and said that the dual school structure of the Dallas Independent School District must be dismantled by January.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (Agence FrancePresse) South Vietnam's new leaders today published the first issue of the first newspaper to be distributed throughout the country since the surrender of Saigon on April 30.

JERUSALEM, July 23 Premier Yitzhak Rabin said tonight that a new interim agreement with Egypt could not be concluded without "face-to-face negotiations between Israeli and Egyptian delegations" on the final details of an accord.

A Consolidated Edison employe was arrested yesterday on charges that he accepted a payoff from the owner of three West Side brownstones in order to make a pending bill "disappear."

During the five years that Walter Kidde Co. has been waiting to complete the sale of its subsidiary, United States Lines, to the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, investors have been troubled by the uncertainties.

DETROIT, July 23 (AP) The pace of new car sales in mid-July hit the highest level for a mid-month period since June, 1974, topping last year's depressed totals by 4 per cent, domestic automakers reported today.

President Ford declared New Jersey a disaster area yesterday because of heavy rains, high winds and flooding in the last two weeks that left six dead, damaged 5,400 homes and businesses, washed out bridges and road and destroyed as much as 50 per cena of some of the state's crops.
A midday upturn failed to take hold on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and prices closed lower for the sixth straight day.

WASHINGTON, July 23 A senior United States Army medical researcher said,today that none of the nearly 600 soldiers who were given LSD in Army experiments were told before or after that they had received the drug, and he said that follow-up studies were done on only 10 per cent of the men.
Government and business officials agreed yesterday that the Soviet Union's purchases of American and other foreign grains either have been completed for this year or are in a temporary lull.

While they continued to mull over the Cleon Jones mat ter in private, the New York Mets continued to maul the Cincinnati Reds in public last night, when Jon Matlack pitched them to their second straight victory over the team with the fanciest performance chart in baseball.

City officials acknowledged yesterday that they did not know how many municipal employes had been cut from the payroll as a result of the fiscal crisis, and they refused to say when a firm layoff figure would be forthcoming.

Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York, which pays hospitals in the metropolitan area almost $1-billion a year, was charged at a State Health Department hearing yesterday with wasting subscribers' money by being too generous with hospitals and with endangering quality health care by not being generous enough.

New York team events invariably attract a substantial nucleus of high-ranked players and are probably harder to win than any comparable contests in the United States. The luck factor, which plays an important role in pairs championships, is considerably diminished.

Thanks to Pele and their goalie, Kurt Kuykendall, the New York Cosmos defeated the San Jose Earthquakes, 2-1, at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island last night.

ROME, July 23 As an era that Italians call "the afterFanfani" began today, the governing Christian Democrats put off until tomorrow the start of the process of naming a successor to their ousted party leader.

OTTAWA, July 23-Canada announced today that she would close her Atlantic ports to the Soviet fishing fleet Monday. She charged that Soviet fishermen had exceeded internationally agreed limits on catches in waters off eastern Canada.

CAIRO, July 23 In a lastminute response to an appeal from the United Nations Security Council, Egypt decided today to permit renewal of the mandate of United Nations peace-keeping forces in Sinai for three months. The mandate expires tomorrow.

TEL AVIV, July 23 (AP) An Israeli force crossed into southern Lebanon before dawn today in a search for guerrillas, and the Israeli command said seven Arabs were captured in a frontier village and brought back for questioning.

Arlington Edinboro's remarks surprised onlookers yesterday as he accepted a $25,000 check from the National Basketball Association on behalf of the Holcombe Rucker Community League, the first winner of the Walter Kennedy Community Service Award.

The annual series of summer concerts in Washington Square Park is observing America's forthcoming Bicentennial, and it began with a singularly appropriate program on Tuesday night. The After Dinner Opera Company had been invited to present its special re-craetion of early American opera excerpts.
Mayor Beame said yesterday that Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home entrepreneur, had met with him at City Hall last August to discuss the problem of a vacant nursing home on Staten Island.

A former city policeman who was acquitted on the basis of insanity for hijacking an Eastern Airlines 727 jet in May, 1971, was arrested again yesterday this time for trying to rob a Fifth Avenue bank.
LIMA, Peru, July 23 (AP) The Peruvian Government last night expelled Edith M. Lederer, Associated Press bureau chief here.

LONDON, July 23 Marjorie McFarlane is frightened. Alistair Black, the Under Sheriff of London, is vexed. The young people at 19 Elgin Avenue are adrift and resentful.

A column that recently appeared in the pages of this newspaper as a paid advertisement deserves attention both for the importance of the subject and the prestige of its author, Bayard Rustin. Unfortunately, it deserves rather less admiration.

The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest photographic equipment manufacturer, reported yesterday a 2.9 per cent drop in June-quarter earnings, making the second time in its history that profits declined from the year before. Net income fell 17 per cent in the initial quarter this year.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The statement by King Hussein today opposing anything less than the $350-million airdefense system originally promised to him by the United States postponed a proposed compromise between the Ad ministration and Congess on the sale.
WASHINGTON, July 23, (AP) Another 1.3 million Americans were added to the nation's list of poor last year, raising the total of poor Americans to 24.3 million, the Census Bureau said today.

The City Planning Commission yesterday approved designating Staten Island's South Richmond area as a "special zoning district" in an effort to insure that future development of the area does not outpace construction of necessary sewers, educational, transportation and health facilities.

Robert J. Schmertz, an owner of the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association, died last evening in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 48 years old and lived at 820 Fifth Avenue and in Lakewood, N.J.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 23 (UPI) Frost in Southern Brazil has ruined an estimated 50 per cent of next year's coffee harvest and is threatening six million head of cattle, Parana state officials reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 23 President Richard M. Nixon authorised the Central Intelligence Agency to make a lastditch, all-out effort in September, 1970, to keep Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming President of Chile, authoritative Government sources said today.

Prices of wheat, corn and soybeans drifted downward on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The selling pressure came because the Soviet buying had been formally announced and traders accepted the statements by both Cook Industries, one of the exporters involved, and the Department of Agriculture that Soviet buying was over, at least, for the present.

OTTAWA, July 23 Canada announced today that she would close her Atlantic ports to the Soviet fishing fleet Monday. She charged that Soviet fishermen had exceeded internationally agreed limits on catches in waters off eastern Canada.

EAST LANSING, Mich. The paradox was shattering. I had traveled 9,000 miles from home and yet I was not a stranger and the-land was not strange. It was as if the jet plane that Congressman Andrew Young and I stepped down from on a November day in 1974 was a Jules Verne time capsule returning us to the Mississippi of two decades earlier.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 23 The irregardless Cafe, a local vegetarian restaurant and countercultural meeting place, expects to be short-handed for some time. One of its owners, Jule Hudson, 23 years old, and one of its waitresses, Cornelia Howell, 21, will be among the jury members hearing the Joan Little murder case.

The commander of the 78th Police Precinct station in Brooklyn has taken 14 plainclothes policemen who used to make a third of the felony arrests in the area and put them back into uniform to bolster his depleted patrol force.

The Taxi and Limousine Commission, under orders from Mayor Beame, yesterday rescinded the permits it had issued to political leaders and other noncommission personnel giving them parking privileges at hundreds of taxi stands around the city.

The three-man executive committee of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation ("Big Mac") is scheduled to visit Washington tomorrow to "report" to top Federal officials on efforts to overcome New York City's acute fiscal crisis. Although the Big Mac executives have denied that they also will be seeking Federal action to help Big Mac surmount its own critical funding problem, the case for such action is persuasive and urgent.

Governor Carey's two-month old executive order covering potential conflicts of interest by top state employes has become so mired in differing interpretations and unexpected problems of application that the seven-member board appointed to administer the order may soon recommend to the Governor that he modify it substantially.

LONDON, July 23 (AP) Members of the House of Commons voted early today to raise their salaries immediately by nearly 28 per cent, and accepted a recommendation that they eventually rise by 144 per cent.

KAMPALA, Uganda, July 23 Angola's feuding guerrilla movements were urged Last night to send their military commanders to Kampala next Monday to attempt to work out a lasting peace with the help of African leaders here for the 12th leaders meeting of the Organization of African Unity.
MARGATE, N.J., July 23 M. Curtis Young, president of South Jersey Airways and Allegheny Commuter Airline, died yesterday of a heart attack while playing golf. He was 54 years old and lived here.

DEAL, N.J., July 23 Judy Cooperstein of Glen Oaks carded a par 74 today and took a commanding eightstroke lead in the 40th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54-hole championship. Play was at the Hollywood Golf Club today.
NEWARK, July 23 (AP) Two hundred strikers demonstrated without incident today outside the offices of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of New Jersey as a threatened blockade failed to materialize.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 23 Emlen Tunnell, who talked the New York Giants into giving him a tryout and became one of professional football's greatest defensive backs, died here early this morning, apparently of a heart attack. He was 50 years old.

The cash in the city's treasury has sunk to precariously low levels over the last few days as the Municipal Assistance Corporation has begun exercising its real power over the city the power of the purse.

MONTPELLIER, France Gen. Antoine (Tony) de Reals changed swiftly from his dress uniform and gold embroidered kepi (for the wedding of an officer's daughter), into a sober, dark suit and said gaily, "In July, everybody in France gets married."
CALI, Colombia, July 23 (AP) An American foursome set the first world record of the aquatic championships tonight, winning the men's 400-meter free-style relay in a time of 3 minutes 24.85 seconds.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 A representative of the League of Women Voters' Delaware River Basin Interleague Council said at a public hearing here today that the controversial Tocks Island dam should not be built because the basin cannot safely divert more water to North Jersey and New York City than it already does.

The nation's leading chain store organizations reported a sales gain in June of 7.9 per cent over the level of June, 1974, Chain Store Age magazine said yesterday. The increase in June compared with a gain of 8.4 per cent in May and no gain in April.

Bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation gained 2 to 3 points yesterday in their first rally since the start of public trading on Wall Street. This means that the bonds gained $20 to $30 per $1,000 face Credit value.

The Urban Development Corporation today will receive a $140-million loan from an obscure state insurance fund, half the money the once-insolvent agency needs to finish its building program and one of the crucial pieces in the complex rescue effort that followed the corporation's default five months ago.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The Federal Government has decided that the American alligator no longer faces extinction and plans to take the reptile off its endangered species list in most of the South.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 23 (AP) King Hussein warned the United States Congress today not to attempt to scale down sales of air-defense arms to Jordan, saying. "Otherwise we shall not hesitate to seek the weapons we need from other sources."
The Kennecott Copper Corporation yesterday reported heavy declines of 65 per cent or more in net income for the second quarter and first half. Sales in both periods fell more than 17 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The House of Representatives rejected today two contrasting proposals on oil prices, one of which would have permitted the price to rise significantly and the other of which would have reduced the average price of domestic crude oil slightly.

BUENOS AIRES, July 23 (Reuters) Argentine legislators tonight purged from office a close associate of the ousted Government strongman, Jose Lopez Rega, forcing the resignation of Raul Lastiri as Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies.
LONDON, July 23-The British Broadcasting Corporation announced on its news programs today that it was withdrawing its correspondent, Mark Tully, from New Delhi.

In a ceremony in the Old Supreme Court Chamber in the United States Capitol, the American Institute for Public Service honored four persons yesterday for "the highest ideals and achievements in the field of public service in the United States."

LISBON, July 23 (AP) A high Government official said today that three top military men are preparing to take full power in Portugal, now governed by a Revolutionary Council of 30 military officers.

WASHINGTON, July 23 President Richard M. Nixon authorised the Central Intelligence Agency to make a lastditch, all-out effort in September, 1970, to keep Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming President of Chile, authoritative Government sources said today.

NAHA, Okinawa, July 23 (UPI) Two men in a motorboat threw firebombs at a Chilean Navy sailing vessel and three other craft today in a 30-minute attack on ships visiting the Expo 75 fair here, the police said.
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, July 24 Twenty three members of the main Opposition party in Sri Lanka have been dismissed as disloyal.
The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday sizable declines in second-quarter and first-half earnings despite higher sales.

The Moreland Act Commission investigating nursing homes voted unanimously yesterday to invite Vice President Rockefeller to testify concerning his staff's activities on behalf of Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home entrepreneur, when Mr. Rockefeller was Governor.

Although they fall short of nationwide licensing and registration requirements, the Administration's new gun proposals constitute a fair start toward necessary controls. HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 24--It has been an agonizing first week for rookies at the Jets' camp, where many of the newcomers know they are merely cannon fodder, "bodies" to be employed so the regulars can get into shape.

There are strong intimations of approaching chaos both political and economic in Argentina. The nation's President, Isabel Martinez de Peron, has been virtually deprived of all power in the last few weeks; the question now seems only when, not whether, she will finally be deprived of her title and position.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) Arthur Ashe, the Wimbledon champion, narrowly escaped defeat today in the $100,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament. He was forced into a third-set tiebreaker against Vijay Amritraj of India, whom he finally defeated, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6.

STONY BROOK, L.I., July 24 There is a footbridge at the State University of New York's center here that starts from one building, leaps across a road and ends in midair. They call it the Bridge to Nowhere.
Willard W. Cummings, a portrait artist who was co-founder and president of the Skowhegan (Me.) School of Painting and Sculpture, died Wednesday evening in a Skowhegan hospital. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 24 The Senate approved a bill extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for seven years and broadening the protection to include Spanish-speaking citizens and other "language minorities."

Albert Shanker has now stooped to aping the "fear city" scare tactics of the police union. In predicting that the austerity budget will leave classrooms too crowded for learning and the schools abandoned to violence, the president of the United Federation of Teachers is trying to persuade parents that their children can be saved from chaos only by surrender to his union's excessive demands.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) President Ford made a series of nominations today for the coming United Nations session.

The United Brands Company, the large banana marketer and meat packer, had 14.1 per cent lower net income in the second quarter of $7.3-million, or 61 cents a share, against $8.5million, or 74 cents a share, in the 1974 quarter, the company reported yesterday.

In a shower of balloons, amid shrieks muffled by spirited band music, and before an audience of millions of television viewers, Jacqueline Rosenzweig, a 34-year-old resident of Jamaica, Queens, who came to this country from Poland 14 years ago, became a millionaire last night as the grand prize winner of the New York State Million Dollar Lottery.

Donald A. MacGrath, a retired Army colonel who served as director of Selective Service for the State of New Jersey from 1953 until his retirement in 1965, died Saturday at a hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

With the first signs of economic recovery, is inflation also accelerating once more? The eight-tenths of one per cent increase in the consumer price index in June 9.6 per cent at an annual rate, seasonally adjusted was disturbing, as were recent price increases by the auto, steel and aluminum industries, which are still operating far below capacity.
DETROIT, July 24 (AP) Indefinite layoffs in the auto industry will drop by 12,000 next week to the lowest level of the year, the domestic auto companies reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Recent actions by the Federal Reserve that helped increase short-term interest rates had "very little significance," Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today.

About 4,000 doctors, nurses, other hospital workers, hospital community board members and patients blocked all lanes of the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday for about 40 minutes during the noon slack traffic period to protest cuts in the municipal hospitals' budgets.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 24 More than a hundred South Korean policemen were dismissed today as part of a threeweek-old campaign against corruption in the nation's police force.

The dispute between parents and educators over what public schools should teach and what texts should be used has spread from West Virginia's Kanawha County, where it exploded in shots and arson last year, to dozens of other communities across the country.

Business loans at leading New York City banks, a key indicator of national economic activity, declined sharply in the week ended Wednesday, according to a report yesterday from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Leaders of six of the world's major religious bodies marked this country's National Day of Prayer yesterday at a ceremony attended by 100 people in the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations, at First Avenue and 44th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 24 The House of Representatives rejected today an effort by the Administration to lift partly the six-month-old arms embargo against Turkey.
Martin J. Hodas, a prominent pornographer with reputed links to organized crime, was convicted yesterday of evading $65,000 in income taxes on his peep-show operations in the Times Square area.

The dispute between parents and educators over what public schools should teach and what texts should be used has spread from West Virginia's Kanawha County, where it exploded in shots and arson last year, to dozens of other communities across the country.

The brothers Heath Jimmy, the saxophonist, and Percy, who, for 22 years, was the bassist in the Modern Jazz Quartet are building a family jazz group that will be rounded out when a third brother, Tootie, a drummer, becomes available. Meanwhile, they are more than making do at the Village Vanguard with Roy Brooks, on drums, and Stanley Cowell, on piano, filling out their current quartet.
RUMSON, N.J., July 24 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks relaxed today as she won her third Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54-hole championship by five strokes.

NEW HAVEN, July 24 In the Bosweil Factory room 331-A of Yale's Sterling Memorial Library the casement windows are flung open to catch the breeze. A sudden gust lifts a batch of handwritten notes which are to be used in a forthcoming installment of the chronicle of James Boswell, the great 18th century biographer.
WASHINGTON, July 23 A year ago, he was living in a modest suburban home, rising early to fix his own breakfast, starting his day by reading the sports pages.

CHICAGO, July 24 The Yankees suffered two damaging defeats at the hands and bats of the Chicago White Sox today and dropped eight games behind the Boston Red Sox in the American League's Eastern Division title race.

Additional Soviet grain purchases in Canada influenced a strong rise in futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. But strength was particularly visible in soybeans, the commodity that the Russians have apparently not yet bought.
ANKARA, July 22 Turkey's Deputy Premier has declared that restrictions on the United States use of bases here might be unavoidable if the embargo on arms sales to Turkey continues.

NEW DELHI, July 24--The Indian Parliament, moving along swiftly now that the opposition members have walked out, barred the courts today from upsetting states of emergency like the current one, which gives Prime Minister Indira Gandhi sweeping powers.

Edwin L. Weisl Jr., the Administrator of Parks. Recreation and Cultural Affairs, said yesterday that City Hall had failed in its promise to fill the 700 summertime jobs it controlled in the Parks Department with members of minority groups and the poor.

Mary Elizabeth McKeveny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Gerard McKeveny of Woodmere, L. I., and Sunset Beach, N. C., was married yesterday evening to Jay J. Nathan, son of Hyman Henry Nathan of New York and the late Eleanor Burnstine Nathan.

A Federal appeals court ruled here yesterday that the city could not go ahead with plans for a low-income housing project near the Trinity Episcopal School on the Upper West Side without obtaining an environmental impact statement on alternative proposals.

Eddie Brannick, a kid from Heli's Kitchen who left New York temporarily when the baseball Giants went West in 1958, left permanently this week. A crowd gathered in St. Ignatius Loyola Church at Park Avenue and 84th Street to see him off.

BELLAGIO, Italy Italy, a country considered for a long time to be the sick man of Europe, has emerged since the local, regional and provincial elections in June as an interesting, disquieting but maybe promising experiment.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 24 Jack Ruhs, a lefthanded golfer who manufactures clubs "for anyone right-handed or left-handed," won today the medal-play portion of the Metropolitan Golf Association's 73d amateur tournament. His score was a four-over-par 146 at Wheatley Hills Golf Club and his margin was one shot.

The complaint in a suit filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York by the Apco Oil Corporation against the Alaska Interstate Company of Houston has charged the Chemical Bank and Kuhn, Loeb Co. with violations of the Federal Securities Act for financing Alaska Interstate in its tender offer for shares of Apco Oil.
ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, July 24 (UPI) Cambodia's Communist Government opened its borders to non-Communist foreigners today and asked for resumption of trade and diplomatic relations with Thailand.

From Barnegat to the popular haunts off Rhode Island, such species as bluefish, weaks, fluke and porgies were being taken in number. There even were giant tuna being found between Montauk and Block Island.
WASHINGTON, July 24 President Ford's campaign manager has suggested that the President may seek "a younger man" than Vice President Rockefeller to run on the Republican ticket next year.

JERUSALEM, July 24 Egypt's latest proposals of terms for a new Sinai accord were described by high Israeli officials today as "serious and well considered." But important differences remain to be overcome on several issues, they added.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 23 Joan Baez's concert at the Nassau Coliseum Saturday night is being billed as her only New York appearance.

HOUSTON, July 24 The three Apollo astronauts returned safely to earth in the Pacific Ocean today, successfully concluding the first international manned space flight and ending an era of American space exploration that began in 1961.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Attorney General Edward H. Levi said today that he would ask the Watergate special prosecutor to keep his office in operation until the appeals from several of its cases were settled.
BUFFALO, July 24 (AP) The National Gypsum Company said today it had filed notice of appeals from the conviction of the company and two of its executives on charges of conspiracy to fix prices.

State Controller Arthur Levitt has ruled out as "inappropriate" the purchase of Municipal As sistance Corporation bonds with any of the $6.3-billion he controls as trustee of the state pension system.

MONTREAL, July 24 (AP) Jack Nicklaus returned from a three-hour weather delay, completed a 65 and tied Tom Weiskopf for the lead today in the uncompleted first round of the $200,000 Canadian open golf tournament.
CALCUTTA, India, July 20 The Indian Government, hoping to win support by improving the economy, is trying to increase tea exports to the oilproducing nations of the Arabian peninsula.

NEW HAVEN, July 24 In the Boswell Factory room 331-A of Yale's Sterling Memorial Library the casement windows are flung open to catch the breeze. A sudden gust lifts a batch of handwritten notes which are to be used in a forthcoming installment of the chronicle of James Boswell, the great 18th century biographer.

LONDON, July 24 The British Government announced plans today to end the controversial policy of interning suspected terrorists without trial in Northern Ireland and to release all internees by Christmas.

RANGOON, Burma, July 21 In her 28th year of independence and 14th of military rule, Burma is stagnating in pervasive poverty. Intellectuals, including many in government, and the foreign community consider Burma a developing country in name only.
Ralph H. Matthiessen, a founder and former president of the General Time Corporation, died Wednesday at his home in Hume, Va., at the age of 85. He formerly lived at Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y.

TRENTON, July 24 (AP) Four of every five phrarmacies in New Jersey are threatening to refuse to fill prescriptions in a protest over reductions in Medicaid payments, the State Pharmaceutical Association said today.
LISBON, July 24 Portugal's Communist-oriented Premier reportedly won the support of army leaders today against demands by the nation's two principal political parties that he be ousted.
Declines ran well ahead of advances again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials closed with its first gain in seven trading days.
Citing "encouraging results," the New York Racing Association said yesterday it hoped to continue its experiment of Sunday racing for the rest of the year and

A third recall of cooked beef rounds produced by the Cardinal Foods Corporation of Brooklyn has been announced by the United States Department of Agriculture following the outbreak of 11 cases of salmonella food poisoning traced to meat consumed in Edison, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 24 President Ford, affirming that he and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama share "a good many similarities" on domestic issues, is nearing the end of his first year in the White House with apparent confidence in the conservative course he has set.

Pennsylvania asked the United States Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin New Jersey from taxing the incomes of Pennsylvanians who work in New Jersey.

Ben Zwerling, publisher of Tariffs and Trade, a newsletter for international executives and a former director of information of the United States Business and Defense Administration, died Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Now that Bond Industries, Inc., is offering to purchase all its outstanding shares at $6 each, many Wall Streeters are wondering whether the New York Stock Exchange acted in the best interest of investors when it delisted the company's shares.

American Stock Exchange prices declined slightly yesterday in moderate trading. The Amex index declined 0.86 to 91.57, with 486,000 shares changing hands, compared with 2,553,000 Wednesday. It was the sixth session of lowerprices.

NEWARK, July 24 (AP)?--Flood victims in the 12 New Jersey counties declared disaster areas can get immediate Federal tax benefits, the Internal Revenue Service announced today.

SYRACUSE, July 24 Haunted by New York City but determined to show something more than a "crisis" aura to his administration, Governor Carey came to this fiscally pacific city today to talk to construction union leaders and medical administrators.
HACKENSACK, July 24 (AP) Judge George B. Gelman ruled in State Superior Court here today that contracts between municipalities and their employes could be subject to public referendums.

Edward A. Choate, retired Broadway producer and general manager, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 67 years old.

Naughton and Philip Shabecoff, New York Times reporters.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) Theodore R. Hanff, a principal figure in the controversial 1948 sale of the Tacony-Palmyra and Burlington-Bristol bridges over the Delaware River, died Tuesday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 72 years old.

Sanitationmen yesterday began removing piles of garbage thrown onto some streets in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn Tuesday night by residents protesting the cutbacks in trash collections necessitated by the city's fiscal crisis.

Robert E. Patricelli, president of a civic group in Hartford, has been nominated as Urban Mass Transportation Administrator by President Ford. The 35-year-old nominee is president of Greater Hartford Process, an arm of the Hartford Chamber of Commerce.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 The Security Council today approved a three-month extension of the United Nations peace force in Sinai. The mandate of the force was scheduled to expire at midnight.

Nicolas Rossolimo, one of the country's 12 grandmasters of chess, and for more than 20 years the proprietor of a chess studio in Greenwich Village, died at St. Vincent's Hospital early yesterday, apparently of injuries suffered in a fall last Monday. Dorothy Day, a former actress and writer, died yesterday at her home, 300 East 74th Street. She was 77 years old.

"First, do no harm" is the ancient cornerstone of medicine, but today physicians are administering to healthy patients, for continuous long-term use, contraceptive drugs and devices that will kill or maim a few of them, and of which the long-range effects are still unknown.

New orders for machine tools in June, were more than 50 per cent lower than the yearearlier Level, according to figures released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. However, for the fourth consecutive month they rose over the previous month.

Texas Instruments Inc., reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings were down 55 per cent from the 1974 period, while sales declined 18 per cent.

HUGO, Okla., July 27 (AP) Isa and Lilly, the 1,500-pound baby elephants who escaped from a circus lot 16 days ago and then eluded searchers for more than two weeks in rugged brush country near here, were located today, a circus official said.

PARIS A few days after the close of the Paris air show, staged at Le Bourget every two years, the French traditionally invite some very special guests, all with very military bearing, to the village of Satory near Versailles for an armaments sales fair.

Carole Steinbock of New York, director of the Center for Social Research in the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, was married yesterday to Robert Goldfeld, associate director of the Vera Institute of Justice. Rabbi Cy Arsa performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Benenson of Mount Vernon, N.Y., friends of the couple.
PARIS, July 27 President Valery Giscard d'Estaing is convinced that "conservative democracy is condemned" and that most people almost everywhere in the world "aspire to liberal reform."
MALMOE, Sweden, July 27 (AP) George Burns 3d, who recently became a pro, beat Graham Marsh of Australia in a sudden-death playoff today to win the $75,000 Scandinavian open golf championship.
WASHINGTON, July 27 Despite 21 hours of political hard-sell by an all-star cast, the Democratic party appeared tonight to have fallen short of its telethon fund-raising goal of over $5-million.

Ronnie Leah Scharfman, a Ph.D. candidate in French at Yale University, and Dr. Joseph Kuhn Youngerman, a clinical instructor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, were married yesterday afternoon at the St. Moritz. Rabbi Benjamin Kreitman of Congregation Shaare Torah of Brooklyn performed the ceremony.

JERUSALEM, July 27 Former Premier Golda Meir said through a spokesman today that any financial award she might receive as a result of her suit against Commentary magazine would be donated to a fund for the settlement of Soviet Jews in Israel.
A good public relations man would advise Henry Kissinger to let the current press criticism of the forthcoming Helsinki supersummit run its course.

Can a Penn Central commuter train due in Grand Central at 8:50 A.M. approach the terminal at 8:58 and still pull into the station "on time" within the five-minute grace period for on-time performance?

CHICAGO, July 27--After submitting to Bill Madlock's two home runs in losing the first game, 4-2, today, the New York Mets had to go 10 innings to square matters with the Chicago Cubs, winning the second game of the double-header, 4-1.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 27 The United States national rowing team won the eightoared title for the second straight year in the 99th national rowing championships today on the Cooper River. Coach Allen Rosenberg's crew fought bow-to-bow with Vesper for the first 1,000 meters and then pulled away at 39 strokes a minute and won by two lengths. The time was 5 minutes, 53.08 seconds.

LENOX, Mass., July 27 This is the season here at Tanglewood for conductors who have taken French leave from the Communist orbit. Mstislav Rostropovich is much in evidence at this summer's Berkshire Music Festival, and another runaway, Klaus Tennstedt, conducted a Beethoven program this afternoon.

Doreen Harriet Seidler, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Ohio State University, was married yesterday in Columbus, Ohio, to Rabbi Chaim Shlomo Feller, co-director of the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation at Ohio State.

HOBOKEN, July 27 Hundreds of residents of this mile-square city this weekend rediscovered the winding Hudson River front, with its incredible panorama of Manhattan, at a fair sponsored by the city's federally financed Community Development Agency.

Carroll Uuderwood Stephens and Bruce Neal Vinik, who graduated this year from Duke University, were married yesterday afternoon in the Edith Memorial Chapel at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School. The Rev. William Head, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh performed the ceremony.
BELLBROOK, Ohio, July 27 (AP) Voters have recalled their mayor and five of six councilmen in a battle over a village earnings tax.
Two New York City nursing homes, the Townview in Manhattan and the Astor Gardens in the Bronx, have lost their eligibility for Medicare and Medicaid funds because of overcrowding.

Crime is of personal concern to most urban Americans, particularly those who live in heavily populated states. It is also an emotional political issue that is often oversimplified by public officials for political purposes.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 27 Thoroughbred race tracks in New Jersey and Pennsylvania have been implicated in a trifecta betting conspiracy.
The American Federation of Teachers and the National Education Association, setting aside their organizational rivalry, have joined in a campaign for dramatic expansion of pre-school education.

MONTREAL, July 27 In one of the tightest finishes of this year's professional golf tour, Tom Weiskopf twice overtook Jack Nicklaus today, then beat his old college friend in a sudden-death playoff to win the Canadian open.

HORSHAM, Pa., July 27 (AP) Carol Mann, humiliated last week when she missed the cut in the Women's United States Open, won the $40,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at Hidden Spring Golf and Country Club today with a 12-under par, 54-hole total of 206.

Mayor Beame issued a virtual ultimatum to the city's municipal labor unions yesterday, asserting that voluntary acceptance of a wage freeze by midnight tomorrow was "much preferable to an imposed one."

In return for $1.85-billion in Federal funds to get Conrail rolling early next year, the United States Railway Association is proposing that Conrail, the Govenment-supported successor to the bankrupt Northeastern railroads, issue $1-billion of 7 per cent income debentures and $850-million of Series A prefererd stock to the Government.

BONN, July 27 President Ford and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany agreed here today that it was "vitally important" that the United States intensify efforts to coordinate economic policy with Western Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) The Fish and Wildlife Service said today that it wanted to classify the grizzly bear as a threatened species.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27 Although the current Newport Music Festival is aimed at the American Bicentennial, that does not mean foreign composers are not represented. Last night's program at the Breakers was called "American Exports," and the idea was to show the influence of our music jazz, specifically on Europeans.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 27 (Reuters) American officials here said today that the United States had begun to suspend operations at four of its Turkish bases yesterday. They were listed as the installations at Golbasi near Ankara, Sinop on the Black Sea coast. Karamursel on the Sea of Marmara and Diyarbakir in the southeast.
KAMPALA, Uganda, July 26 African foreign ministers have begun a campaign here to have South Africa's status as an "independent sovereign state" declared illegal within the world community.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare administered the drug LSD to about 2,500 prisoners, mental patients and paid volunteers from 1954 to 1968 to determine whether it had any medical value, according to Government sources.

Elisabeth Hoffman, a doctoral candidate in clinic psychology at George Washington University, was marriedyesterday afternoon to Dr. Anthony Reading, associate professor of psychiatry at the Johns Hopkins University. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony at the Jamaica Estates, home of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hoffman, parents of the bride.

ATLANTA, July 27 Vernon E. Jordan Jr., executive director of the National Urban League and a member of the Presidential clemency board, broke with the Ford Administration today and urged total amnesty for Vietnam veterans. Mr. Jordan's position was disclosed in remarks he had prepared for delivery tonight in his keynote speech at the 65th annual convention of the league.
CLEVELAND, July 27 (UPI) Cleveland municipal workers accepted today a tentative contract agreement to end a sevenday strike against the city.

HONOLULU, July 27 The Apollo astronauts will be released from Tripler Army Medical Center within 48 hours, but will stay in Hawaii for about 10 days for rest and medical observation, doctors said tonight.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 27 (AP) About $40,000 was paid to win the release of two American students and a Dutch woman who were held in a jungle camp in Zaire by African guerrillas, well-informed sources said yesterday.

Their names mean nothing to the average New Yorker, and little more to City Hall. But until recently, they were a part of the city's backbone work force a policeman, a fireman, a laborer, a librarian, a cafeteria worker and two school aides.

SEATTLE Hundreds of municipal employes here are in a state of open revolt against the city administration. Seattle, to a large extent, has become a microcosm and, to some observers, a preview of a bitter new adversary relationship that is developing between public employes and elected officials in cities across the country.
ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 27 Mario Andretti led from start to finish to post his second Formula 5000 victory of the season at Road America today before a crowd of 33,400.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Five members of the Senate have already raised more than $100,000 each for their re-election campaigns next year, even though they do not know who their opponents will be.
The annual income of the average New Jersey resident exceeds that of the average, New York State resident and the gap is widening, according to new Federal Census estimates released yesterday.

Carolyn Gale Patton of New York, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Patton of Jackson, Mich., was married yesterday afternoon to Thomas Edward Mancino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony T. Mancino of Linden, N.J.

Italy, to nobody's surprise, won the European championships, which ended Saturday in Brighton, England, but the glory went to Israel. An Israeli surge on the final day took them into second position behind the Italians, and thus qualified them to compete in the 1976 Bermuda Bowl world championship in Monte Carlo.

Dr. Michael Sosnowsky, associate editor of Svoboda, Ukrainian daily newspaper of Jersey City, died Saturday of a heart attack at the Jersey City Medical Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Irvington, N.J.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina outdueled Mexico's Raul Ramirez, 6-3, 6-4, and the defending titleholder, Harold Solomon, defeated Cliff Richey, 7-5, 6-0, today, to repeat as finalists in the $100,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 27 (UPI) Premier Kukrit Pramoj said today that military agreements with the United States were no longer valid and set next March 20 as a deadline for withdrawal of all American forces from Thailand.

CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., July 27 Officials dealing with the resettlement of 130,000 Vietnamese and Cambodians have discovered in refugee camps more than 300 children who arrived in this country unaccompanied by their parents.

Florence Linda Amzallag and Peter Alexis Tatistcheff were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Beadleston in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. Judge Robert S.D. Roy of the Town Court of Greenburg, N.Y., performed the ceremony.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 27 The Harold Lloyd estate was auctioned off this afternoon, but the fate of the silentfilm comedian's home remains unclear.

NEW DELHI, July 27 The two American correspondents in India of The New York Times, after extensive consultations with Indian officials, today signed a statement acknowledging "full responsibility" for their reports from here in regard to the Indian Government's rules for censorship.

Gus Campise, a long-time tennis official and tournament player, died Saturday of a heart attack while playing in the national clay-court championships for men 35 years and older at the Shelter Rock Club in Manhasset, L.I. He was 58 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

Americans got a clear view of crop conditions in the Soviet Union last Monday when television showed the Russian space capsule landing in a great cloud of dust in what was called a typical wheat field. To watchful commodity men, that indicated a severe drought.

In American cities with at least 500,000 population, 45 per cent of the people are afraid to walk in their neighborhoods at night, according to the latest Gallup poll. Seventy-seven per cent of the women in those areas fear for their safety on the streets at night, the survey found.

NEWARK For the first time since the tenants of the Stella Wright Homes ended their fouryear rent strike a year ago, residents of the seven 13-story buildings in the Central Ward here can see the beginnings of a new era in the management of this troubled, low-income, public housing complex.

Against this mixture of uncer tainty and hope, one thing is clear: Interest rates are moving up in the credit markets. This rising trend in rates, moreover, has caught many Wall Street analysts by surprise, although few of them are taking out advertising space to announce the fact.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 27 Silk Stockings, purchased as a yearling for $20,000 in the hope her earnings would help a needy cause, struck it rich today by winning the final dash in the $230,521 Monticello-New York City Offtrack Betting Classic with surprising ease at Monticello Raceway.
When the Yankees dropped far behind in the pennant race yesterday they didn't do it with a thud; they crept away silently, as if they did not want anyone to see them depart.
Henry E. Beretta, a wood carver and sculptor for more than 70 years, died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 431 East 20th Street.

Information clerks manning seven kiosks set up in strategic spots in midtown Manhattan two months ago to aid visitors are doing a rush-hour business helping New Yorkers.

CHARLEROI, Belgium New jobs are scarce in this gray mill city of 250,000 in the coal-producing Sambre River Valley. And now, due to the world steel slump, even the 14,000 steel workers' jobs, long the economic life blood of the city, are no longer secure.

FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 27 (UPI) Wim Boshuis, a Dutch driver, and a track marshal died last night in two mishaps at the controversial 24-hour Francorchamps road race for sedans, which ended today. Boshuis was killed after his Commodore, apparently malfunctioning, rammed into three other cars on the Ardennes circuit, known as the Spa.

MONTREAL, July 27 Canada seems ready and willing to meet its commitment for next summer's Olympic Games. But the nation has yet to convince everyone at the moment that she will be able to leave the starting blocks without wobbling.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 27 Someone mistook Carl Stokes for a bartender at a party here last night, but the former Mayor of Cleveland didn't mind because he was, in fact, serving as a bartender for the occasion.

Among the surprises American Ballet Theater has planned for its gala performance tonight at the New York State Theater is the first major performance here by a member of the Paris Opera Ballet since that company last appeared here in 1948.

WASHINGTON Have you ever seen an egg separator that you could call charming? Or a distinctly rococo pastry knife? An elegant carpenter's plane? An imposing rolling pin? A witty pair of crochet hooks? A ruggedly individual wooden bathtub?
PADANARAM, Mass., July 27 Salty Goose, a 52-foot sloop from Rye, N.Y., today won the Queen's Cup, one of the most-sought prizes in the trophy locker of the New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON The recent events in India, a culmination of a conflict between forces of change and forces of status quo that has been shaping up for a long time, have been misreported and misunderstood in the West partly because the revolution it is no less is so immediate that its implications and possible success or failure are not clearly assessed.

SEATTLE, July 27 The first Pacific Northwest Festival with a double cycle of Richard Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen," sung in German and English, closed last night here, with a performance of "Gotterdammerung" in English, to enthusiastic audiences and generally favorable critical attention.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission has voted to seek civil penalties against six cigarette companies for alleged violations of an agreement requiring them to advertise the dangers of smoking, an F.T.C. commissioner says.

He did not care what the makers of established opinion thought about him. He did not play the game of approval. He was prepared to be thought a nuisance, even a cad.

The Health Department has announced the names of 14 more food establishments cited for violations of the city's Health Code. These places had failed to correct violations found by inspectors on the initial inspection when they were inspected for a second time a month later.

Revenues of the American Electric Power Company, the nation's largest electric utility holding company, rose to $358.4-million in the 1975 second quarter, from $296.4-million in the same period in 1974, the company reported yesterday.
Edward W. Smith until recently senior vice president and editorial director of the American Book Company, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 33 Charles Street. He was 55 years old.

He picked two lobsters from a tank and held them out. They seemed much too small to make a meal for two people who had their mouths set for a real lobster dinner.

Deep-trolling anglers are doing well with the big rainbow trout of New York State's Lake George. The rainbows are running 12 to 20 inches, and an occasional landlocked salmon is also being caught. Going deep for trout with wire or lead core line lacks the excitement and pleasure of surface fishing, but there are times when it is the only technique that will succeed with any consistency.

WASHINGTON. July 30 After nearly eight hours of debate, much of it heated, the Senate passed a bill late tonight that would radically change the oil and gas leasing procedures on the outer continental shelf. It would enable the Federal Government to get more information on its resources there from private industry and provide funds for coastal states to deal with the effects of development programs.

NEW DELHI, July 30 (AP) The Indian Government today restored The Associated Press teleprinter link with London, ending a 61-hour shutdown ordered because of official objections to the news agency's dispatches.

The Washington Square Bicentennial Music Festival hit upon an interesting theme for its second concert this summer on Tuesday night: All the works on the program were drawn from the music library of Thomas Jefferson.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) A division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation violated a wire patent of the Raychem Corporation of Menlo Park, Calif., a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) A record high of more than 6.6 million persons were receiv- ing unemployment insurance benefits during the week ended July 19, the Labor Department announced today.

Federal and state criminal investigations of the nursing home industry are turning their attention to alleged political influence exerted on behalf of Bernard Bergman, whose indictment for stealing $1.2-million from Medicaid was announced Tuesday.

LUANDA, Angola, Aug. 7 (UPI) The National Front for the Liberation of Angola pulled out of the transitional government today pending fhe return of Portugal's High Commissioner, who has acted as a buffer between the warring factions.
WINDSOR, Vt., Aug. 7 Anybody want to buy a used, maximum security prison?

Alligood, the night jailer slain by Miss Little, had made sexual advances at them. A third said she had heard him ask Miss Little if she "missed her man."

Joan Klonsky and Martin Daniel Ustin of New York were married yesterday by Mayor William S. Hart of East Orange, N. J., who performed the ceremony in his office there.
