GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 8 The Orange County Legislature, aroused by steeply rising welfare costs, refused today to appropriate $5.5-million to maintain county welfare services through the end of the year. The denial of funds means that the county may be unable to support many recipients beyond October.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug. 8 Sandy Mayer defeated his old friend and doubles partner, Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-4, tonight and helped the New York Sets beat the Pittsburgh Triangles, 24-21 in World Team Tennis. MOSCOW, Aug. 8 The Communist party newspaper Pravda today invoked the Helsinki declaration of the European security conference to warn the Common Market countries against what it contended was new interference in Portugal.

MADRID, N.M. Somebody spotted a wisp of smoke near the old No. 4 coal mine shaft near town the other day and started shouting. Richard Blum stopped sawing. Demetrius Aiello stopped roofing. Terry Conrad stopped rolling a cigarette. Instead of leaving it to the county fire department, people all over town dropped what they were doing, rushed out with shovels and snuffed out the fire.

The United States and the world economy appear to have entered a transitional phase that will persist at least for the rest of this year. Transitional periods are seldom very satisfying and this is no exception. One era ends, people and policies change, foundations are laid, rebuilding begins, hopes are raised, patience is counseled and we grow tired waiting for the promsed results. Sometimes the transitional arrangements themselves become the new norm.

New York City's state-mandated 25 per cent share of federally sponsored welfare and Medicaid costs far exceeds the burden imposed upon any other local government outside of the state, according to Mitchell I. Ginsberg, dean of the Columbia University School of Social Work.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 10 Jack Greenwood, a star hurdler for Kansas University in the early nineteenfifties, increased his collection of gold medals to seven today as the three-day Amateur Athletic Union Masters national track and field championships concluded its stand at Glenn Loucks Memorial Field.

Two rulings on financial statements that may be useful to stockholders have been issued by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. One ruling requires detailed descriptions of auditors' responsibilities. The other concerns transactions that "may have been subject to undue influence."
Josephine Irish Millon, who was decorated by two Governments for her war work for children, died here Saturday. She was 75 years old and lived at 1192 Park Avenue.

WATERLOO VILLAGE, Aug. 10 This living museum of 200 years of New Jersey history is getting more attention these days because of the Bicentennial, but those who work here say it is just a case of the rest of the country catching up.
Manya Starr, a film writer, recently hailed a cab near her apartment on East 82d Street and told the driver to take her to CBS on West 52d Street.

The sharp cutback in the manning and maintenance of the city's parks because of the fiscal crisis is leading officials of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration to worry that a cycle of deterioration may have begun that will be impossible to reverse.

Carl T. Naumburg, a limited partner in the brokerage firm of Stern, Lower Co., who was a noted collector of the works of Rudyard Kipling, died yesterday at a nursing home in Chagrin Falls, Ohio, where he had been living for the last two years. He was 85 years old.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Aug. 10 Bad news has taken a back seat in this industrial town of 65,393 persons, the site of a visit from President Ford today.
Diane Martha Lavenda, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lavenda of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Kenneth Paul Traum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Traum of Oradell, N.J.

Hope Hartley Brock, a graduate of the Boston University Law School, was married yesterday afternoon to Grant Forbes Winthrop, who has a master's degree in journalism from Stanford University. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill of Brooklyn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Annisquam (Mass.) Church.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) Betty Ford said today that she wouldn't be surprised if her daughter. Susan, 18 years old, decided to have an affair. Mrs. Ford suggested that in general, premarital relations with the right partner might lower the divorce rate.

Doctors in Northern Ireland have developed a lightweight portable defibrillator that cardiologists believe may provide a major new tool in delivering emergency care to more persons who suffer heart attacks at home or at work.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Aug. 10 In barely 50 sunsoaked minutes on the clay courts of this mountain resort today, Jimmy Connors reaffirmed his mastery over Ken Rosewall in winning the $100,000 Volvo international tennis tournament. The scores were 6-2, 6-2.

A board member of the Municipal Assistance Corporation said yesterday that the corporation was likely to press again for Federal help despite a rebuff in Washington last week in an effort to sell $1billion in bonds next month.

SYDNEY, Australia Tough competition has closed out one of the American entrants in Australia's fast-growing fast-food business. But the three surviving chains are continuing their expansion plans.

Governor Carey has cut back air-conditioning in state office buildings, eliminated 338 more state jobs and imposed other economies in the third wave of a program to sweat excess fat from the $10.7-billion state budget. In addition, Mr. Carey has served notice on his department chiefs that their budgets for next year must be frozen at this year's levels except for increases attributable to inflation or the completion of new facilities.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP) An esteemed academic council charged today that Federal affirmative action programs to end discrimination in university and college faculties were confused and chaotic.

ALBANY, Aug. 10 Public authorities and other agencies that control highways, bridges and tunnels will be required to make financial disclosures and hold public hearings before raising tolls or fees under a bill signed today by Governor Carey.

ASBURY PARK On the official maps the name of Springwood Avenue, scene of the riots that injured more than 170 people and wiped out a half-mile-long stretch of a mainly black shopping district here five years ago, has been changed to Lake Avenue.
LEXINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 10 (UPI) Brian Redman drove past the disabled car of Mario Andretti on the 31st lap and won the Buckeye Cup Formula 5000 race at Mid-Ohio today.

It's musical chairs time for the beauty salons. If you can't find your favorite hairdressers at the same old stand, chances are he's opened a shop of his own, or the entire salon has moved to more resplendent quarters. Despite the moaning over hard times, a number of daring young men have recently left the security of established jobs to try out their own business wings.

CAMERA SPECTRUM Two new shows feature camera art in personalized perspectives. In the collection opening today at the Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street, Reginald Wickman uses darkroom techniques to give blackand-white pictures a lithographic quality, recording subjects suggestive of silhouettes, such as trees, barns and fences, portraits and candid action shots of nightclub musicians.

DARWIN, Australia, Monday, Aug. 11 (Reuters) A coup has been staged in Portuguese Timor, according to a radio message received here today from the airport control tower in the Portuguese island territory.

The international development bill voted out of the House International Relations Committee last week constitutes a major step toward improving the nation's battered foreign aid program. Bringing home the bacon is getting more expensive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Senator William Proxmire, who has begun investigating the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's overseas payments, has found that the payments ranged "from a few thousand dollars to several million dollars" and often went to foreign goverments' officials who were responsible for the award of contracts to Lockheed.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 10 A New York team, a Canadian team and two Californian teams, survivors of dramatic finishes in the early hours of this morning, battled this afternoon in the semifinal round of the Spingold knockout team championship.

LAKEWOOD, N.J. Aug. 10 For 35 years Wilbert Etter of Quakertown, Pa., has been breeding Welsh terriers. A year ago, he won his first best-in-show award with Ch. Licken Run's Two Pence Sam at Perkiomen.

BONN, Aug. 10 (AP) The people who make the Volkswagen insist that their cars are not being "dumped" in the United States market. This denial is in response to Friday's announcement in Washington by the Treasury Department of an investigation into whether foreign cars are being sold in America at a lower price than in their home markets.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 10 The first of two Viking spacecraft designed to land on Mars was declared today to be ready to take off tomorrow.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 10 Australians traditionally think of their land as a cornucopia, bountiful in beef and sheep, blessed with vast grazing areas and with huge mineral resources. Australia, as many put it, is "the lucky country."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Two children, one a 4-year-old girl, were shot dead in sporadic firing tonight at a Roman Catholic stronghold in Belfast, a military spokesman said. He also reported that army marksmen had hit five gunmen.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 10 Jack Nicklaus won the Professional Golfers' Association Championship today for the fourth time, but it wasn't as ho-hum as all that. It was not until the closing holes that the issue was settled, with Bruce Crampton trying gallantly to catch up, only to be thwarted by putts that lipped out or missed by inches.
SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10 Navy Seal commandos have received special training for possible assignment to American embassies in countries plagued by guerrilla terrorism, according to Navy sources here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 A Navy study has concluded that superiority of Soviet warships in firepower has been achieved by sacrificing the endurance, electronic sophistication and crew comforts emphasized in American ships.

A 58-year-old amateur photographer strolling in Central Park with a pair of cameras punched, kicked and fought off two gun-toting teen-aged robbers who accosted him on a footpath yesterday morning, but was slightly wounded when one of the fleeing thugs turned and fired a parting shot at him.
Pamela Sue Kalish and Martin David Edel were married yesterday morning at Temple Sinai in Roslyn Heights, L.I., by Rabbi Norman Kahan.

Jacob I. Gottlieb, a vice president of Food Fair Stores, Inc., and president of its J.M. Fields Discount Department Store division, died Saturday of a heart attack suffered while sailing near Loveladies, N.J. He was 57 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

Sanitationmen making their rounds today will fasten new schedules to garbage cans and slip schedules under doors or into mailboxes to tell superintendents, landlords and homeowners of the reduced collections going into effect tomorrow.

The bodies of two men, both of whom had arrest records on charges of narcotics peddling, were found in an abandoned van yesterday near West 122d Street and Claremont Avenue. Both men had been shot to death.

Young Rubicam International, which has more United States billings than any other advertising agency, has been adding to its strength in recent years by establishing affiliate agencies to specialize in particular industries or service categories.
Premier Takeo Miki of Japan said yesterday he saw "only a limited, if any, chance of major hostilities" recurring in Korea.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP) A mystery subplot about the missing James R. Hoffa is arising here in Pennsylvania coal country.

KLUNDERT, the Netherlands The Woodhouse Motel in this small farm town 30 miles south of Rotterdam is full this season as usual, but the guests aren't on vacation.

Dr. Morris Meister, the founder and first principal of the Bronx High School of Science and the founder and first president of the Bronx Community College, died last night at New York University Hospital after a short illness. Dr. Meister, who was 80 years old, lived at 315 Riverside Drive.

NASHVILLE Americans cannot regard with unconcern the worsening situation in sub-Sahara Africa. Around the Cape of Good Hope move the tankers that carry oil to fuel industries and homes in Europe and America.

The best way to hang on to a husband who is dynamic and successful is for the wife to be dynamic, too, Pamela Uttal, a student at Sarah Lawrence, has concluded after conducting a study. Ramon Martinez is a 50year-old unemployed dishwasher with a wife and two children to support and a $100-a-month apartment on 108th Street in East Harlem. Despite visits to the unemployment office every two weeks, he has been out of work since last November.

Rumania wants to buy F-5 jet fighters and other modern weaponry from the United States, Time magazine said today in its latest issue.

In what seemed like a footnote to his two-day state visit to Washington, Premier Takeo Miki of Japan announced what was far from a footnote for wildlife conservationists around the world. After years of Japanese leadership in the slaughtering of whales, the Premier quietly told reporters that Japan accepts "without any reservations" the quotas fixed by the International Whaling Commission at its meeting last June.

WASHINGTON To promote a "national dialogue" about issues and values in our Bicentennial Year, Walter Cronkite came up with a suggestion for a nationwide "American Issues Forum." That was a good idea.

Gail Frances LeBoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald LeBoff of Teaneck, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen Martin Zelman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Zelman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Judah Washer performed the ceremony in the Teaneck Jewish Community Center.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Gerald L. Warren, deputy press secretary to President Nixon, said today that he believed that Mr. Nixon was guilty of obstruction of justice. Asked if he thought Mr. Nixon had committed any crime in connection with Watergate, he responded, "Yes I do, I do indeed."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 A State Department spokesman said today that the United States had received a message from Hanoi declaring that North Vietnam was ready to return the bodies of three American pilots killed during the Vietnam war.

Sherman performed the ceremony in the Farmington Valley Jewish Congregation.

Seventh Avenue apparel manufacturers are in peak production for the back-to-school and fall season. By the end of this month, makers of coats, suits and sportswear for women and children will have shipped the bulk of merchandise that retailers have ordered for fall. Most of the producers report that their shipments this year are well ahead of those of a year ago.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 11 In reality, Darryl Dawkins, is a 6-foot-l0-inch, 240pound basketball player with a $1-million contract from the Philadelphia 76ers, who hope he can fill their great need for a center.

RICHMOND, Aug. 11 (UPI)? Five agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of a Federal grand jury investigation into a Richmond wiretap case, the F.B.I. said today.

Teachers from around the country who consider the nation's two major teacher organizations too liberal will gather this week in Anaheim, Calif., under the banner of a burgeoning third group, the National Association of Professional Educators.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 11 Two California teams clashed in the final of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship here today, fighting for a place in the International Team Playoffs in October and possible world championship honors. PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 11 After a week in which his wife underwent surgery, his home was ransacked and he played the entire preseason opener on defense for the New York Giants, Pat Hughes still had his sense of humor intact today.

The New York Ford Dealers Association, made up of 111 dealers in the New York metropolitan area and southern Connecticut, has begun a seven-week radio advertising campaign built around the theme, "Mustang II M.P.G. means 34 Miles Eer Gallon." MONTREAL, Aug. 11 Secretary of State Kissinger today offered the developing nations a compromise United States position on deep-sea mining in an effort to remove a major obstacle in negotiations over a new law of the sea.
Treasury issues finished fairly strong in trading yesterday to provide a firm undertone to a capital market that took a severe buffeting last week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission accused three of the biggest bearing manufacturers today of engaging in anticompetitive conduct through mergers and an inter-company agreement.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 (AP) Manuel Orantes of Spain upset Arthur Ashe, the Wimbledon champion, 6-2, 6-2, in the final of the United States clay-courts tennis championship tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Ford has put off indefinitely his plan to visit India this fall.

LISBON, Aug. 11 The Luanda radio in Angola reported tonight that the situation in the African territory was "extremely confused" and it said that communications with most of the interior had been lost.

The family of Edgar M. Bronfman, head of the billiondollar Seagram Company Ltd., with worldwide liquor and other interests, said yesterday it had received a "substantial" ransom demand in a letter from the asserted kidnappers of his oldest son, 21-year-old Samuel Bronfman 2d.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 11 Manager Billy Martin shook up the New York Yankee line-up tonight but the California Angels proceeded to shake up the New York Yankees by stealing six bases in an 8-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, following a report today by his department that dry weather in key producing areas had reduced the outlook for this year's corn crop, called on grain companies to withhold temporarily further sales to the Soviet Union.

A former United States Olympic team member, Philip K. Shinnick, who was questioned in the Patricia Hearst case, disclosed yesterday that he was dismissed effective next July as an assistant professor and director of sports studies at Rutgers University's Livingston College, united Press International reported.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) Jack Ford said today he had advised his father not to run for the Presidency in 1976, but that President Ford did not take the advice seriously.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The Federal agency responsible for maintaining the integrity of the nation's 4,700 national banks has not kept pace with new banking methods, often focuses on the wrong problems and has too many informal contacts with bankers, a study released today asserted.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11 The Long Island State Parkway policemen's union, angered by Governor Carey's veto of a bill that would have permitted it to act as its own bargaining agent, today threatened motor ists with rule-enforcement and safety checks that would result in huge traffic tie-ups.

A Minneapolis prosecutor has decided to drop all criminal charges against Dave Forbes, the Boston Bruins hockey player who was accused of aggravated assault for allegedly hitting another player in the eye with the butt end of his hockey stick. The incident occurred during a game in Bloomington, Minn., Jan. 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Coast Guard said today it would allow women to enter its academy for the first time beginning next July but the law still prevents them from going to sea on Coast Guard ships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration may ban some plastic food packages, such as vegetable oil bottles and some meat wrappers, because of a potential cancer link, a spokesman said today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11 The Soviet Union appears to be developing disarmament as a dominant new theme in its foreign policy, following visible satisfaction with the outcome of the European security conference.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 President Isabel Martinez de Per n reshuffled her Cabinet for the third time in a month today in the midst of Argentina's worst economic crisis in a generation and continued bickering between factions in the Peronist movement.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 11 A reported coup d' tat in the Portuguese part of the is land of Timor appears to have been carried out by a conservative, largely Roman Catholic and pro-independence political party, according to Indonesian sources that quoted monitored radio broadcasts from the island.

The Orange County Executive and his Commissioner of Social Services declared yesterday that there was no present alternative to continued county financing of welfare programs, and said that they would ask the County Legislature next month to reverse itself and appropriate additional money to maintain social services.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 11 (AP) Ten eastern Oklahoma residents were arrested today in connection with what the authorities described as a $360,000 grain sale fraud.

NEWARK, Aug. 11 (UPI) Anthony J. Grossi, President of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, stepped into a civil battle between Jersey City and a garbage contractor today in an effort to keep key depositions secret.

Governor Carey yesterday vetoed three of the more significant criminal-justice bills of the 1975 legislative session, including one that would have eased penalties under an important section of the strict socalled Rockefeller drug laws.
Msgr. John M. McNamara, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in the Crestwood section of Yonkers, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 64 years old.

Is there anything we can do to resolve the arguments that have been continuing about how the United States became involved in the war in the first place and what efforts the Government made to bring about an honorable settlement?

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., Aug. 10 Tons of spent munitions and historic artifacts lie beneath the corn rows and wood lots here that were once the bloodiest battlegrounds of the Civil War. And they have attracted a 20th century army that is well equipped and bent on collecting souvenirs.
Seventeen-year-old Michael L. Boodley rocketed off on the quest for his impossible dream yesterday afternoon at Coney Island.

Nothing lays a deader hand on art faster than the deification of the artist.

DALLAS, Aug. 11 (AP) Billie Sol Estes, the one-time West Texas wheeler-dealer who went to prison after his fertilizer tank enterprise collapsed in 1962, is reported to be the target of a new investigation by the Internal Revenue Service.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, announced late yesterday that it would change prices of various lines of its products in line with price changes announced last week by the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The opening of Boston public schools under a new integration program was ordered delayed three days yesterday until Sept. 8.

An analysis of the voting records of the seven members of the Federal Communications Commission has found dissent to be exceedingly rare, with the commissioners voting in agreement with Richard E. Wiley, Chairman, an average 97.6 per cent of the time.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) The president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and a president of a member college fired opening salvos today over a share-the-wealth proposal which threatens to split this week's special convention at which the nation's colleges will seek to cut escalating athletic costs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz, following a report today by his department that dry weather in key producing areas had reduced the outlook for this year's corn crop, called on grain companies to withhold temporarily further sales to the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Aug. 11 With violence mounting in Northern Ireland, British officials are expressing fears that the ceasefire in the province is in danger of collapse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba has returned the $2-million ransom paid by Southern Airways in November, 1972, for a hijacked airliner, Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today.

For those who consider that ballet depends upon stars (and not everybody does), then American Ballet Theater scored a coup at the State Theater here this summer by becoming the first company to present in one season Rudolf Nureyev, Natalia Makarova and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

The teaching of American history in the nation's public schools "is in crisis," a special report by the Organization of American Historians warns. BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 12 (UPI) The food stamp program is a haven for "chiselers and rip-off artists" and is one example of letting the Government solve problems that people should solve for themselves, Treasury Secretary William E. Simon said today.

The Manhattan telephone directory costs the phone company about $2 to publish; a set of 76 directories covering everyone listed in the state costs $96.25, weighs 71 pounds and costs an additional $35 to deliver.

Two symphonies and two concertos made up the generous program on Monday night that introduced George Cleve as conductor to the Mostly Mozart Festival audience in Avery Fisher Hall. The Viennese-born, Americantrained musician was heard here with the New York Philharmonic 10 years ago. He has been busy on the American scene elsewhere since then and currently is music director of the San Jose Symphony in California.

The drive to market $275million in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds was reported to be encountering difficulty yesterday, and bond sellers prepared for a meeting today or tomorrow to decide whether to raise the interest rates to spur sales.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Aug 12 (AP) President Ford's ap pointment secretary said here today that the recent snubbing of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn was the result of agreements between the United States and the Soviet Union at the time the writer was exiled from his home country.

Eight former officials and employes of the Franklin National Bank and its parent company, the Franklin New York Corporation, have been indicted on Federal charges involving the loss of more than $30-million of the bank's money in unauthorized speculation in foreign currencies.

Questionnaires are to be mailed within two weeks to 2,000 former city employes in an effort to uncover patterns of pilferage and other dishonest practices, investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 12 Premier Takeo Miki, fresh from his trip to America, turned his attention to domestic politics today and called on Japan's leftist opposition parties to stop blocking legislation.
A 71-year-old man, left alone in his 11th-story room in one of the towers of the Florence Nightingale nursing home, plunged to his death early yesterday morning.
Alexander's, the New York retail chain, announced yesterday that it was taking over the lease of the Klein's Department Stores in Flushing, Queens.

Gov. Hugh Carey, who has five daughters among his 12 children, indicated yesterday that he differed with Betty Ford, who said on a Sunday television program that she would not be surprised if her daughter, Susan, announced she was having an affair.
Prices of corn, wheat and soybeans the basic foodstuffs shot upward yesterday, the day following the Government's largely optimistic survey of crop conditions on Aug. 1.

Assembly Speaker Stanley Steingut accused the Federal Government yesterday of turning its back on the city's transit problems and then recommended a regional approach in finding new revenue to help stabilize the fare in the future.

The city's Teachers Retirement System, which provides retirement allowances from funds vested in it by the monthly contributions by teachers, filed suit yesterday against the United States Trust Company to recover losses totaling $13,313,000 sustained allegedly because of poor investments.

HIGHLAND LAKES, N.J. Aug, 11 (AP) Dr. Ward D O'Sullivan, chairman of the surgery department at Mercy Catholic Medical Center, Philadelphia, died today at his summer home here. He was 58 years old and lived in Rosemont, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Gulf Oil Corporation of violating the Truth in Lending Act by failing to tell customers that credit costs were hidden in the price of merchandise promoted through the mails.

Eight former officials and employes of the Franklin National Bank and its parent company, the Franklin New York Corporation, have been indicted on Federal charges involving the loss of more than $30-million of the bank's money in unauthorized speculation in foreign currencies.
LIGHT AND AIRY Since summer calls for cooler garb, two local restaurants have adopted a policy of bringing sports clothes and sports appointments to patrons as a midtown diversion.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Aug. 12 (UPI) A three-man military panel today found Marine Sgt. Michael Williams not guilty in the beating of a Navy recruit, Steven Stawnychy, at the Great Lakes Naval Training Center.

LISBON, Aug. 12 Military officers today petitioned President Francisco da Costa Gomes to end what the officers view as efforts by Premier Vasco Goncalves to turn Portugal into a Communist state on Eastern European lines.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 12 The Joan Little defense rested today after Miss Little underwent more than three hours of wheedling, battering crossexamination that failed to evoke any anger from the young black woman or elicit any alteration of her account of the stabbing of Clarence Alligood, a jailer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) Federal bank regulators kept from the public conditions at two major banks that eventually collapsed, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John R. Evans, said today.

Pinhas Sapir, a founder of the State of Israel and its Finance Minister for many years, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Beersheba, Israel. He was stricken on a visit to Moshav Nevatim, a cooperative settlement, in the Negev. He was 68 years old and had been out of public office since May, 1974.
Walt Whitman could never get enough of New York. He even loved it in August, when most people then as now found it unbearable.

The stock market rose for three and a half hours yesterday and then gave up roughly half its gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, up 10.02 points at 1:30 P.M., closed at 828.54. Its gain for the day was 4.78 points.

LONDON, Aug. 12 In the background are the blurred dials and switches of a walnut dashboard. Closer up, the tanned, confident hand of a man, a pilot perhaps, with two gold stripes on his cuff and a rugged steel watch. The hand grasps the floor-mounted gearshift and a newly lighted Rothman's kingsize cigarette. "... when you know what you're doing," reads the text of the advertisement.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) The deposed Nigerian head of state, Gen. Yakubu Gowon, arrived here by air today from Accra, Ghana, to join his family.
A four-day "sick-out" at Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx by employes protesting staff cuts ended yesterday and services at the municipal instituition returned to normal.

Since mid-January, investors have been able to buy a limited number of Treasury notes and bonds on the PBW and American Stock Exchanges. These are pilot programs that could open the door to widespread individual ownership of all government securities. Until recently the bulk of trading in government securities has been for institutions dealing in the over-the-counter market, with a limited amount of dealings on the New York Stock Exchange.

Frivolous news items like this about women breaking into nontraditional jobs really irritated Betty Medsger, a freelance photo-journalist who is "very much a feminist." But instead of sitting and stewing, she decided to do something about her anger.

The boys kept threatening to lose their roomy pants, and the babies tried to toddle into the pool at the Four Seasons restaurant yesterday morning. But they looked mighty cute in the Pierre Cardin clothes, and the store buyers were enchanted.
MONTREAL, Aug. 12 The American Bar Association approved today a resolution calling for legislation what would ban any statutory limitations on campaign expenditures.

ANCHORAGE, Aug. 12 Women considering pregnancy here are thinking twice about it these days. The state's malpractice dilemma has forced many of the city's obstetrician gynecologists into the growing list of doctors refusing to see new patients until insurance coverage that they regard as adequate is available.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has issued a preliminary directive to the Navy to stop planning more giant aircraft carriers and to start planning for smaller ones, and the admirals are fighting the order.
A new entry in the children's chewable-vitamin field will make its debut next week, bearing the name of one of the best-known children's characters these days Spider-Man.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 We are beginning to see already how the Soviet Union intends to interpret the principles of the Helsinki conference to promote its own revolutionary objectives even in Western Europe.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (AP) President Ford soon will send Congress proposed legislation that would "work major changes in the regulation of the, trucking industry," Harold R. Taylor Jr., Deputy United States Attorney General said today.

Congress has just passed a law establishing tighter rules than ever before to prevent abuse of fiduciary responsibility by the labor-management trustees of all pension funds. The degree to which that law can eradicate the flagrant malpractices in the Central States fund will be a crucial test of its effectiveness.

Lincoln Center shed its black-tie, mostly-Mozart image yesterday to celebrate its fifth annual outdoor festival of free events which, in the words of one young spectator, were "just right for old people and just right for young people, too."

Prices on the American Stock Exchange, which had lagged behind while Big Board prices were making small gains most of the last week, finally joined the advance yesterday. Prices were higher for the first time in eight trading days, but volume remained light.

Kleindienst has been suspended from practicing law for one month before the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia for not telling the truth about White House involvement in the antitrust case against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
The Army disclosed yesterday that a 42-year-old patient at the New York State Psychiatric Institute died 22 years ago in an Army-sponsored experiment with hallucinogenic drugs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) Japan, America's biggest overseas customer for farm goods, arranged to buy at least 14 million tons of grain and soybeans from United States companies in each of the next three years.

The proposal by the State Charter Revision Commission for common boundaries for most New York City departments would lead to "fragmentation" of police protection, heap an $85-million changeover bill on a financially pressed city, and risk intrusion of neighborhood politics into police decisions, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

TORONTO, Aug. 12 (UPI) Rod Laver of Australia, who won this tournament in 1970, whipped Mexico's Joaquin Loyo-Mayo, 6-2, 6-3, in his opening, match today at the $130,000 Rothmans Canadian open tennis championships.

A 27-year-old man was seized in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel after a robbery yesterday afternoon, and the police officers said he was a possible suspect in 20 or more recent holdups of guests in midtown hotels.

The baseball game at Shea Stadium last night sometimes resembled the theater of the absurd or a throwback to Met games of another era. But amid the strange doings, Tom Seaver won his 16th game and the Mets picked up a notch on the Pittsburgh Pirates and now trail the National League Eastern Division leaders by 6 games.

The beaver, an amphibious rodent that receives mixed notices from those who know it well, and the brook trout, an elusive quarry known for its shyness, have gained official recognition with the signing of two bills making them New York State's official animal and fish.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) Mortgage interest rates on loans guaranteed by the Federal Housing Adiministration and the Veterans Administration continued to climb in June, the Department of Housing and Urban Development reported today.

The U.S. Industrial Chemicals Company announced yesterday price increases ranging from 5 per cent to 12 per cent for all low, medium-and highdensity polyethylene resins, powdered polyolefins and ethylene-vinyl acetate copolymer resins. The increases are effective Sept. 1.
TRENTON, Aug. 12 New Jersey's Commuter Operating Agency today proposed railfare increases of up to 70 per cent and bus-fare increases of up to 100 per cent on state-subsidized intrastate lines.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 8 Local headmen near the Khyber Pass have voiced anger. Arms caches are being unearthed with ominous frequency. There are charges of outside meddling among the border tribes.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (AP) The organizing committee for the 1976 Olympics has rejected an offer of $9.3-million from five broadcasting unions outside Canada and the United States for television rights to the Games.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 A visiting Congressional delegation, wound up talks with Soviet legislators today, with at least one member warning that lack of movement on issues like emigration might put new strains on Soviet-American accommodation.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith made public yesterday a complaint to Secretary of Commerce Rogers C.B. Morton charging his department with "cooperating and assist ing" the Arab boycott of Israel although it warned American businesses that they must report demands for boycott compliance.
Isidore Waxman, a retired actor, died Monday at the Jewish Institute of Geriatric Care, 271-11 76th Avenue, New Hyde Park, Queens. He was 87 and a resident of the institute.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 A bill designed to eliminate the maze of bureaucratic prohititions against hiring released felons was vetoed today by Governor Carey, who called the purpose of the bill "commendable" but said its specific provisions were "vague, difficult to understand and impossible to implement."
LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) The Industrial and Mining Development Bank of Iran is raising a $100-million five-year Eurocurrency loan, the Iran Overseas Investment Bank, Ltd., said here today.
TRENTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) The State Health Department imposed cutbacks today in its $1.3-million program of hospital care for crippled children.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 12 (UPI) The dollar lost ground on some major world money markets today after four straight days of advances, but continued to fare well on others.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Several Congressional committees in a joint report gave unanimous support today to the Ford Administration's position in favor of floating currency exchange rates, and opposed any new rules of the International Monetary Fund aimed at an eventual return to fixed rates.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Senator Patrick J. Leahy and "six youthful snoopers," prowling the jungles of bureaucracy, have discovered a Federal agency that, the Senator says, does almost nothing and spends $67,000 a year doing it.
J.P. Morgan Co. Inc., parent of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, postponed yesterday its offering of $150-million of seven-year notes, citing unsettled market conditions.
Representative Elizabeth Ioltzman charged yesterday that Blue Cross-Blue Shield omputer errors may have cost elderly New Yorkers as much as $12.7-million in reduced Medicare payments last year.

CAPE MAY POINT, Aug. 12 (AP) Swimming is still officially forbidden here because of pollution from the sewagetreatment plant of neighboring Cape May City, but a health official said today that the problem was beginning to clear up.

The Drew National Corporation, a large door-to-door distributor of home furnishings and major appliances as well as women's apparel, filed a petition yesterday for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York. The company listed assets of $24.89-million and liabilities of $22.91-million.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (UPI) Charles M. Manson says that a pronouncement of his guilt by then-President Nixon prominently displayed in newspaper headlines was the main reason he and three female followers were found guilty of the Tate-Labianca slayings.

President Ford, writing as "a private American citizen with a lifetime interest in sports," has endorsed in a letter to Lord Killanin, president of the International Olympic Committee, a petition by the United States Olympic Committee requesting that the late Jim Thorpe be restored to recognition by the I.O.C.

HANCOCK, Mich., Aug. 12 School officials here are experimenting with a system that will allow them to broadcast locally produced instructional television programs over a radio station by electronically compressing the TV pictures into a narrow radio band signal.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) Early in the dim hours of morning, guards seal the corridor windows, disconnect telephones and look for hidden microphones in a quiet, undistinguished Washington basement.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 12 (UPI) The First National City Bank told the Colombian Government today that it would not turn over a controlling interest in its Colombian branches to local shareholders and that it would rather close than obey a Government order to cede majority control.
Herman Blank, a former New Jersey Assemblyman, died Monday at Martland Medical Center, Newark, N.J. He was 68 years old and lived in East Orange, N.J.

The deeper the law enforcement authorities dig into the mare's nest of underworld syndicates that envelops the two-millionmember International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the more baffled they seem to become about who or what might have caused the union's former leader to vanish as he started his comeback campaign.

VAIL, Colo., Aug. 12 "Ohhh!" exclaimed the President of the United States in mild exasperation as he threeputted the the third green of a golf course nestled nearly two miles up in the Rockies. Gerald R. Ford is on vacation.
OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 12 Walt Williams, Chris Chambliss and Thurman Munson got three hits apiece tonight as the New York Yankees accumulated 15 and scored a 7-2 victory over the Oakland A's.

MARGATE, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP) The police in this shore community are hot on the trail of someone who has been manufacturing counterfeit beach badges.
BONN, Aug 12 The elders of Oberammergau have decreed that the next version of the town's famous Passion Play will not use a sharply criticized text that blames the Jews for the death of Jesus.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 In Scottsdale, Ariz., they make burglary calls. In Atlanta they diagram crime scenes and photograph corpses. And here their voices crackle across the air waves ordering squad cars to city trouble spots.

NEWARK, Aug. 12 Virginia Long Annich, director of the Department of Consumer Affairs, announced today that a list of 125 pharmacists who have refused to fill prescriptions paid for with Medicaid cards will be presented to the State Board of Pharmacists tomorrow with a request for appropriate legal action.

Mayor Beame, overruling the decision of his Parks administrator, yesterday ordered that the Puerto Rican Fiesta Committee receive permission to hold a festival in Central Park in exchange for posting a $5,000 bond to cover the cost of a clean-up.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12 The Long Island State Parkway police said they issued more than twice as many summonses to motorists today than on a normal day, under their job action, which they described was a "super-enforcement" of vehicle and traffic laws.
